SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: THERE ARE CRIMES AND CRIMES

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: INTRODUCTION

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Strindberg was fifty years old when he wrote "There Are Crimes and

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Crimes." In the same year, 1899, he produced three of his finest

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: historical dramas: "The Saga of the Folkungs," "Gustavus Vasa,"

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: and "Eric XIV." Just before, he had finished "Advent," which he

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: described as "A Mystery," and which was published together with

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: "There Are Crimes and Crimes" under the common title of "In a

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Higher Court." Back of these dramas lay his strange confessional

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: works, "Inferno" and "Legends," and the first two parts of his

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: autobiographical dream-play, "Toward Damascus"--all of which were

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: finished between May, 1897, and some time in the latter part of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: 1898. And back of these again lay that period of mental crisis,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: when, at Paris, in 1895 and 1896, he strove to make gold by the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: transmutation of baser metals, while at the same time his spirit

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: was travelling through all the seven hells in its search for the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: heaven promised by the great mystics of the past.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: "There Are Crimes and Crimes" may, in fact, be regarded as his

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: first definite step beyond that crisis, of which the preceding

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: works were at once the record and closing chord. When, in 1909, he

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: issued "The Author," being a long withheld fourth part of his

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: first autobiographical series, "The Bondwoman's Son," he prefixed

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: to it an analytical summary of the entire body of his work.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Opposite the works from 1897-8 appears in this summary the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: following passage: "The great crisis at the age of fifty;

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: revolutions in the life of the soul, desert wanderings,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Swedenborgian Heavens and Hells." But concerning "There Are Crimes

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: and Crimes" and the three historical dramas from the same year he

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: writes triumphantly: "Light after darkness; new productivity, with

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: recovered Faith, Hope and Love--and with full, rock-firm

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Certitude."

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: In its German version the play is named "Rausch," or

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: "Intoxication," which indicates the part played by the champagne

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: in the plunge of _Maurice_ from the pinnacles of success to the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: depths of misfortune. Strindberg has more and more come to see

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: that a moderation verging closely on asceticism is wise for most

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: men and essential to the man of genius who wants to fulfil his

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: divine mission. And he does not scorn to press home even this

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: comparatively humble lesson with the naive directness and fiery

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: zeal which form such conspicuous features of all his work.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: But in the title which bound it to "Advent" at their joint

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: publication we have a better clue to what the author himself

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: undoubtedly regards as the most important element of his work--its

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: religious tendency. The "higher court," in which are tried the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: crimes of _Maurice_, _Adolphe_, and _Henriette_, is, of course,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: the highest one that man can imagine. And the crimes of which they

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: have all become guilty are those which, as _Adolphe_ remarks, "are

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: not mentioned in the criminal code"--in a word, crimes against the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: spirit, against the impalpable power that moves us, against God.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: The play, seen in this light, pictures a deep-reaching spiritual

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: change, leading us step by step from the soul adrift on the waters

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: of life to the state where it is definitely oriented and impelled.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: There are two distinct currents discernible in this dramatic

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: revelation of progress from spiritual chaos to spiritual order--

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: for to order the play must be said to lead, and progress is

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: implied in its onward movement, if there be anything at all in our

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: growing modern conviction that _any_ vital faith is better than none

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: at all. One of the currents in question refers to the means rather

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: than the end, to the road rather than the goal. It brings us back

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: to those uncanny soul-adventures by which Strindberg himself won

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: his way to the "full, rock-firm Certitude" of which the play in

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: its entirety is the first tangible expression. The elements

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: entering into this current are not only mystical, but occult. They

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: are derived in part from Swedenborg, and in part from that

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: picturesque French dreamer who signs himself "Sar Péladan"; but

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: mostly they have sprung out of Strindberg's own experiences in

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: moments of abnormal tension.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: What happened, or seemed to happen, to himself at Paris in 1895,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: and what he later described with such bewildering exactitude in

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: his "Inferno" and "Legends," all this is here presented in

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: dramatic form, but a little toned down, both to suit the needs of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: the stage and the calmer mood of the author. Coincidence is law.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: It is the finger-point of Providence, the signal to man that he

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: must beware. Mystery is the gospel: the secret knitting of man to

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: man, of fact to fact, deep beneath the surface of visible and

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: audible existence. Few writers could take us into such a realm of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: probable impossibilities and possible improbabilities without

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: losing all claim to serious consideration. If Strindberg has thus

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: ventured to our gain and no loss of his own, his success can be

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: explained only by the presence in the play of that second,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: parallel current of thought and feeling.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: This deeper current is as simple as the one nearer the surface is

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: fantastic. It is the manifestation of that "rock-firm Certitude"

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: to which I have already referred. And nothing will bring us nearer

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: to it than Strindberg's own confession of faith, given in his

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: "Speeches to the Swedish Nation" two years ago. In that pamphlet

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: there is a chapter headed "Religion," in which occurs this

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: passage: "Since 1896 I have been calling myself a Christian. I am

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: not a Catholic, and have never been, but during a stay of seven

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: years in Catholic countries and among Catholic relatives, I

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: discovered that the difference between Catholic and Protestant

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: tenets is either none at all, or else wholly superficial, and that

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: the division which once occurred was merely political or else

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: concerned with theological problems not fundamentally germane to

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: the religion itself. A registered Protestant I am and will remain,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: but I can hardly be called orthodox or evangelistic, but come

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: nearest to being a Swedenborgian. I use my Bible Christianity

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: internally and privately to tame my somewhat decivilized nature--

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: decivilised by that veterinary philosophy and animal science

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: And I assure my fellow-beings that they have no right to complain

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: because, according to my ability, I practise the Christian

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: teachings. For only through religion, or the hope of something

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: better, and the recognition of the innermost meaning of life as

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: that of an ordeal, a school, or perhaps a penitentiary, will it be

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: possible to bear the burden of life with sufficient resignation."

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Here, as elsewhere, it is made patent that Strindberg's

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: religiosity always, on closer analysis, reduces itself to

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: morality. At bottom he is first and last, and has always been, a

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: moralist--a man passionately craving to know what is RIGHT and to

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: do it. During the middle, naturalistic period of his creative

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: career, this fundamental tendency was in part obscured, and he

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: engaged in the game of intellectual curiosity known as "truth for

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: truth's own sake." One of the chief marks of his final and

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: mystical period is his greater courage to "be himself" in this

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: respect--and this means necessarily a return, or an advance, to a

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: position which the late William James undoubtedly would have

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: acknowledged as "pragmatic." To combat the assertion of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: over-developed individualism that we are ends in ourselves,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: that we have certain inalienable personal "rights" to pleasure

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: and happiness merely because we happen to appear here in human

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: shape, this is one of Strindberg's most ardent aims in all his

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: later works.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: As to the higher and more inclusive object to which our lives must

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: be held subservient, he is not dogmatic. It may be another life.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: He calls it God. And the code of service he finds in the tenets of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: all the Christian churches, but principally in the Commandments.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: The plain and primitive virtues, the faith that implies little

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: more than square dealing between man and man--these figure

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: foremost in Strindberg's ideals. In an age of supreme self-seeking

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: like ours, such an outlook would seem to have small chance of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: popularity, but that it embodies just what the time most needs is,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: perhaps, made evident by the reception which the public almost

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: invariably grants "There Are Crimes and Crimes" when it is staged.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: With all its apparent disregard of what is commonly called

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: realism, and with its occasional, but quite unblushing, use of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: methods generally held superseded--such as the casual introduction

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: of characters at whatever moment they happen to be needed on the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: stage--it has, from the start, been among the most frequently

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: played and most enthusiastically received of Strindberg's later

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: dramas. At Stockholm it was first taken up by the Royal Dramatic

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Theatre, and was later seen on the tiny stage of the Intimate

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Theatre, then devoted exclusively to Strindberg's works. It was

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: one of the earliest plays staged by Reinhardt while he was still

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: experimenting with his Little Theatre at Berlin, and it has also

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: been given in numerous German cities, as well as in Vienna.

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Concerning my own version of the play I wish to add a word of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: explanation. Strindberg has laid the scene in Paris. Not only the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: scenery, but the people and the circumstances are French. Yet he

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: has made no attempt whatever to make the dialogue reflect French

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: manners of speaking or ways of thinking. As he has given it to us,

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: the play is French only in its most superficial aspect, in its

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: setting--and this setting he has chosen simply because he needed a

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: certain machinery offered him by the Catholic, but not by the

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Protestant, churches. The rest of the play is purely human in its

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: note and wholly universal in its spirit. For this reason I have

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: retained the French names and titles, but have otherwise striven

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: to bring everything as close as possible to our own modes of

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: expression. Should apparent incongruities result from this manner

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: of treatment, I think they will disappear if only the reader will

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: try to remember that the characters of the play move in an

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: existence cunningly woven by the author out of scraps of ephemeral

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: reality in order that he may show us the mirage of a more enduring

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: one.

SPEAKER: STAGE

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: EMILE, a workman, brother of Jeanne

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: THERE ARE CRIMES AND CRIMES

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: ACT I FIRST SCENE

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: Paris. The background shows mortuary chapels, stone crosses on

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: which are inscribed "O Crux! Ave Spes Unica!" and the ruins of a

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: wind-mill covered with ivy.)

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: prayers in front of a grave decorated with flowers.)

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: rubbish heap on the ground.)

SPEAKER: STAGE
TEXT: end of the avenue.)

SPEAKER: WATCHMAN
TEXT: [Enters and goes up to JEANNE] Look here, this is no

SPEAKER: WATCHMAN
TEXT: playground.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: [Submissively] I am only waiting for somebody who'll soon

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: be here--

SPEAKER: WATCHMAN
TEXT: All right, but you're not allowed to pick any flowers.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: [To MARION] Drop the flowers, dear.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. [Comes forward and is saluted by the WATCHMAN] Can't the

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: child play with the flowers that have been thrown away?

SPEAKER: WATCHMAN
TEXT: The regulations don't permit anybody to touch even the

SPEAKER: WATCHMAN
TEXT: flowers that have been thrown away, because it's believed they may

SPEAKER: WATCHMAN
TEXT: spread infection--which I don't know if it's true.

SPEAKER: WATCHMAN
TEXT: ABBÉ. [To MARION] In that case we have to obey, of course. What's

SPEAKER: WATCHMAN
TEXT: your name, my little girl?

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: My name is Marion.

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: ABBÉ. And who is your father?

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: ABBÉ. Pardon my question, madame. I had no intention--I was just

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: talking to keep the little one quiet.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I understood it, Reverend Father, and I wish you would say

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: something to quiet me also. I feel very much disturbed after

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: having waited here two hours.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Two hours--for him! How these human beings torture each

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: other! O Crux! Ave spes unica!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: What do they mean, those words you read all around here?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. They mean: O cross, our only hope!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Is it the only one?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. The only certain one.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I shall soon believe that you are right, Father.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. May I ask why?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: You have already guessed it. When he lets the woman and

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: the child wait two hours in a cemetery, then the end is not far

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: off.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. And when he has left you, what then?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Then we have to go into the river.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Oh, no, no!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Yes, yes!

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: Mamma, I want to go home, for I am hungry.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Just a little longer, dear, and we'll go home.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Woe unto those who call evil good and good evil.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: What is that woman doing at the grave over there?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. She seems to be talking to the dead.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: But you cannot do that?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. She seems to know how.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: This would mean that the end of life is not the end of our

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: misery?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. And you don't know it?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Where can I find out?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Hm! The next time you feel as if you wanted to learn about

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: this well-known matter, you can look me up in Our Lady's Chapel at

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: the Church of St. Germain--Here comes the one you are waiting for,

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I guess.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: [Embarrassed] No, he is not the one, but I know him.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. [To MARION] Good-bye, little Marion! May God take care of

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: you! [Kisses the child and goes out] At St. Germain des Prés.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: [Enters] Good morning, sister. What are you doing here?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I am waiting for Maurice.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Then I guess you'll have a lot of waiting to do, for I saw

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: him on the boulevard an hour ago, taking breakfast with some

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: friends. [Kissing the child] Good morning, Marion.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Ladies also?

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Of course. But that doesn't mean anything. He writes plays,

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: and his latest one has its first performance tonight. I suppose he

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: had with him some of the actresses.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Did he recognise you?

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: No, he doesn't know who I am, and it is just as well. I

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: know my place as a workman, and I don't care for any condescension

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: from those that are above me.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: But if he leaves us without anything to live on?

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Well, you see, when it gets that far, then I suppose I

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: shall have to introduce myself. But you don't expect anything of

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: the kind, do you--seeing that he is fond of you and very much

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: attached to the child?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I don't know, but I have a feeling that something dreadful

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: is in store for me.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Has he promised to marry you?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: No, not promised exactly, but he has held out hopes.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Hopes, yes! Do you remember my words at the start: don't

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: hope for anything, for those above us don't marry downward.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: But such things have happened.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Yes, they have happened. But, would you feel at home in his

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: world? I can't believe it, for you wouldn't even understand what

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: they were talking of. Now and then I take my meals where he is

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: eating--out in the kitchen is my place, of course--and I don't

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: make out a word of what they say.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: So you take your meals at that place?

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Yes, in the kitchen.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: And think of it, he has never asked me to come with him.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Well, that's rather to his credit, and it shows he has some

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: respect for the mother of his child. The women over there are a

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: queer lot.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Is that so?

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: But Maurice never pays any attention to the women. There is

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: something _square_ about that fellow.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: That's what I feel about him, too, but as soon as there is

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: a woman in it, a man isn't himself any longer.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: [Smiling] You don't tell me! But listen: are you hard up

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: for money?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: No, nothing of that kind.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Well, then the worst hasn't come yet--Look! Over there!

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: There he comes. And I'll leave you. Good-bye, little girl.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Is he coming? Yes, that's him.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Don't make him mad now--with your jealousy, Jeanne! [Goes

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: out.]

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: No, I won't.

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: [Runs up to him and is lifted up into his arms] Papa,

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: papa!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: My little girl! [Greets JEANNE] Can you forgive me,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Jeanne, that I have kept you waiting so long?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Of course I can.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But say it in such a way that I can hear that you are

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: forgiving me.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Come here and let me whisper it to you.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I didn't hear.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Now I heard! Well--you know, I suppose that this is the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: day that will settle my fate? My play is on for tonight, and there

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: is every chance that it will succeed--or fail.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I'll make sure of success by praying for you.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Thank you. If it doesn't help, it can at least do no

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: harm--Look over there, down there in the valley, where the haze is

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: thickest: there lies Paris. Today Paris doesn't know who Maurice

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: is, but it is going to know within twenty-four hours. The haze,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: which has kept me obscured for thirty years, will vanish before my

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: breath, and I shall become visible, I shall assume definite shape

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: and begin to be somebody. My enemies--which means all who would

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: like to do what I have done--will be writhing in pains that shall

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: be my pleasures, for they will be suffering all that I have

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: suffered.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Don't talk that way, don't!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But that's the way it is.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Yes, but don't speak of it--And then?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Then we are on firm ground, and then you and Marion will

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: bear the name I have made famous.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: You love me then?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I love both of you, equally much, or perhaps Marion a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: little more.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I am glad of it, for you can grow tired of me, but not of

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: her.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Have you no confidence in my feelings toward you?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I don't know, but I am afraid of something, afraid of

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: something terrible--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: You are tired out and depressed by your long wait, which

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: once more I ask you to forgive. What have you to be afraid of?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: The unexpected: that which you may foresee without having

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: any particular reason to do so.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But I foresee only success, and I have particular reasons

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: for doing so: the keen instincts of the management and their

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: knowledge of the public, not to speak of their personal

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: acquaintance with the critics. So now you must be in good spirits--

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I can't, I can't! Do you know, there was an Abbé here a

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: while ago, who talked so beautifully to us. My faith--which you

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: haven't destroyed, but just covered up, as when you put chalk on a

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: window to clean it--I couldn't lay hold on it for that reason, but

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: this old man just passed his hand over the chalk, and the light

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: came through, and it was possible again to see that the people

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: within were at home--To-night I will pray for you at St. Germain.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Now I am getting scared.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Fear of God is the beginning of wisdom.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: God? What is that? Who is he?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: It was he who gave joy to your youth and strength to your

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: manhood. And it is he who will carry us through the terrors that

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: lie ahead of us.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What is lying ahead of us? What do you know? Where have

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: you learned of this? This thing that I don't know?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: I can't tell. I have dreamt nothing, seen nothing, heard

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: nothing. But during these two dreadful hours I have experienced

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: such an infinity of pain that I am ready for the worst.

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: Now I want to go home, mamma, for I am hungry.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, you'll go home now, my little darling. [Takes her

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: into his arms.]

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: [Shrinking] Oh, you hurt me, papa!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Yes, we must get home for dinner. Good-bye then, Maurice.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: And good luck to you!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [To MARION] How did I hurt you? Doesn't my little girl

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: know that I always want to be nice to her?

SPEAKER: MARION
TEXT: If you are nice, you'll come home with us.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [To JEANNE] When I hear the child talk like that, you

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: know, I feel as if I ought to do what she says. But then reason

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: and duty protest--Good-bye, my dear little girl! [He kisses the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: child, who puts her arms around his neck.]

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: When do we meet again?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: We'll meet tomorrow, dear. And then we'll never part

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: again.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: [Embraces him] Never, never to part again! [She makes the

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: sign of the cross on his forehead] May God protect you!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Moved against his own will] My dear, beloved Jeanne!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Both turn around simultaneously and throw kisses at each other.)

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Comes back] Jeanne, I am ashamed of myself. I am always

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: forgetting you, and you are the last one to remind me of it. Here

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: are the tickets for tonight.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Thank you, dear, but--you have to take up your post of

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: duty alone, and so I have to take up mine--with Marion.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Your wisdom is as great as the goodness of your heart.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, I am sure no other woman would have sacrificed a pleasure to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: serve her husband--I must have my hands free tonight, and there is

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: no place for women and children on the battle-field--and this you

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: understood!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Don't think too highly of a poor woman like myself, and

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: then you'll have no illusions to lose. And now you'll see that I

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: can be as forgetful as you--I have bought you a tie and a pair of

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: gloves which I thought you might wear for my sake on your day of

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: honour.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Kissing her hand] Thank you, dear.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: And then, Maurice, don't forget to have your hair fixed,

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: as you do all the time. I want you to be good-looking, so that

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: others will like you too.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: There is no jealousy in _you_!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Don't mention that word, for evil thoughts spring from it.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Just now I feel as if I could give up this evening's

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: victory--for I am going to win--

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Hush, hush!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And go home with you instead.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: But you mustn't do that! Go now: your destiny is waiting

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: for you.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Good-bye then! And may that happen which must happen!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: [Alone with MARION] O Crux! Ave spes unica!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: SECOND SCENE

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: an aquarium with goldfish and dishes containing vegetables, fruit,

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: preserves, etc. In the background is a door leading to the

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: kitchen, where workmen are taking their meals. At the other end of

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: the kitchen can be seen a door leading out to a garden. On the

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: left, in the background, stands a counter on a raised platform,

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: and back of it are shelves containing all sorts of bottles. On the

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: right, a long table with a marble top is placed along the wall,

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: and another table is placed parallel to the first further out on

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: the floor. Straw-bottomed chairs stand around the tables. The

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: walls are covered with oil-paintings.)

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: smoking a cigarette.)

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. So it's tonight the great event comes off,

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: Monsieur Maurice?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, tonight.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Do you feel upset?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Cool as a cucumber.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Well, I wish you luck anyhow, and you have

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: deserved it, Monsieur Maurice, after having had to fight against

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: such difficulties as yours.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Thank you, Madame Catherine. You have been very kind to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: me, and without your help I should probably have been down and out

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: by this time.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Don't let us talk of that now. I help along where

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: I see hard work and the right kind of will, but I don't want to be

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: exploited--Can we trust you to come back here after the play and

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: let us drink a glass with you?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, you can--of course, you can, as I have already

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: promised you.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: who looks him over carefully.)

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Monsieur Adolphe is not here yet?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. No, madame. But he'll soon be here now. Won't you

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: sit down?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, thank you, I'll rather wait for him outside. [Goes

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: out.]

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Who--was--that?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Why, that's Monsieur Adolphe's friend.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Was--that--her?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Have you never seen her before?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, he has been hiding her from me, just as if he was

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: afraid I might take her away from him.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Ha-ha!--Well, how did you think she looked?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: How she looked? Let me see: I can't tell--I didn't see

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: her, for it was as if she had rushed straight into my arms at once

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: and come so close to me that I couldn't make out her features at

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: all. And she left her impression on the air behind her. I can

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: still see her standing there. [He goes toward the door and makes a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: gesture as if putting his arm around somebody] Whew! [He makes a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: gesture as if he had pricked his finger] There are pins in her

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: waist. She is of the kind that stings!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Oh, you are crazy, you with your ladies!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, it's craziness, that's what it is. But do you know,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Madame Catherine, I am going before she comes back, or else, or

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: else--Oh, that woman is horrible!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Are you afraid?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, I am afraid for myself, and also for some others.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Well, go then.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: She seemed to suck herself out through the door, and in

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: her wake rose a little whirlwind that dragged me along--Yes, you

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: may laugh, but can't you see that the palm over there on the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: buffet is still shaking? She's the very devil of a woman!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Oh, get out of here, man, before you lose all your

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: reason.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I want to go, but I cannot--Do you believe in fate,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Madame Catherine?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. No, I believe in a good God, who protects us

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: against evil powers if we ask Him in the right way.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: So there are evil powers after all! I think I can hear

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: them in the hallway now.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Yes, her clothes rustle as when the clerk tears

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: off a piece of linen for you. Get away now--through the kitchen.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: I beg your pardon. [He retires the way he came.]

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [Comes in first; after him HENRIETTE] Why, there's

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Maurice. How are you? Let me introduce this lady here to my oldest

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and best friend. Mademoiselle Henriette--Monsieur Maurice.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Saluting stiffly] Pleased to meet you.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTA
TEXT: We have seen each other before.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Is that so? When, if I may ask?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: A moment ago. Right here.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: O-oh!--But now you must stay and have a chat with us.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [After a glance at MME. CATHERINE] If I only had time.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Take the time. And we won't be sitting here very long.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I won't interrupt, if you have to talk business.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: The only business we have is so bad that we don't want to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: talk of it.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Then we'll talk of something else. [Takes the hat away

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: from MAURICE and hangs it up] Now be nice, and let me become

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: acquainted with the great author.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE signals to MAURICE, who doesn't notice her.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: That's right, Henriette, you take charge of him. [They

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: seat themselves at one of the tables.]

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [To MAURICE] You certainly have a good friend in

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Adolphe, Monsieur Maurice. He never talks of anything but you, and

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: in such a way that I feel myself rather thrown in the background.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You don't say so! Well, Henriette on her side never

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: leaves me in peace about you, Maurice. She has read your works,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and she is always wanting to know where you got this and where

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that. She has been questioning me about your looks, your age, your

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: tastes. I have, in a word, had you for breakfast, dinner, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: supper. It has almost seemed as if the three of us were living

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: together.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [To HENRIETTE] Heavens, why didn't you come over here and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: have a look at this wonder of wonders? Then your curiosity could

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: have been satisfied in a trice.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Adolphe didn't want it.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Not that he was jealous--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And why should he be, when he knows that my feelings are

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: tied up elsewhere?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Perhaps he didn't trust the stability of your feelings.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I can't understand that, seeing that I am notorious for

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: my constancy.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Well, it wasn't that--

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Interrupting him] Perhaps that is because you have not

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: faced the fiery ordeal--

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Oh, you don't know--

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Interrupting]--for the world has not yet beheld a

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: faithful man.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Then it's going to behold one.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Where?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Here.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Well, that's going it--

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Interrupting him and directing herself continuously to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: MAURICE] Do you think I ever trust my dear Adolphe more than a

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: month at a time?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I have no right to question your lack of confidence, but

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I can guarantee that Adolphe is faithful.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: You don't need to do so--my tongue is just running away

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: with me, and I have to take back a lot--not only for fear of

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: feeling less generous than you, but because it is the truth. It is

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: a bad habit I have of only seeing the ugly side of things, and I

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: keep it up although I know better. But if I had a chance to be

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: with you two for some time, then your company would make me good

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: once more. Pardon me, Adolphe! [She puts her hand against his

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: cheek.]

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You are always wrong in your talk and right in your

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: actions. What you really think--that I don't know.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Who does know that kind of thing?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Well, if we had to answer for our thoughts, who could

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: then clear himself?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Do you also have evil thoughts?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Certainly; just as I commit the worst kind of cruelties

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: in my dreams.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Oh, when you are dreaming, of course--Just think of it—-

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, I am ashamed of telling--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Go on, go on!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Last night I dreamt that I was coolly dissecting the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: muscles on Adolphe's breast--you see, I am a sculptor--and he,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: with his usual kindness, made no resistance, but helped me instead

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: with the worst places, as he knows more anatomy than I.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Was he dead?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, he was living.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But that's horrible! And didn't it make YOU suffer?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Not at all, and that astonished me most, for I am

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: rather sensitive to other people's sufferings. Isn't that so,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Adolphe?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: That's right. Rather abnormally so, in fact, and not the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: least when animals are concerned.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And I, on the other hand, am rather callous toward the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: sufferings both of myself and others.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Now he is not telling the truth about himself. Or what do

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: you say, Madame Catherine?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. I don't know of anybody with a softer heart than

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: Monsieur Maurice. He came near calling in the police because I

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: didn't give the goldfish fresh water--those over there on the

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: buffet. Just look at them: it is as if they could hear what I am

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: saying.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, here we are making ourselves out as white as angels,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: and yet we are, taking it all in all, capable of any kind of

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: polite atrocity the moment glory, gold, or women are concerned--So

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: you are a sculptor, Mademoiselle Henriette?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: A bit of one. Enough to do a bust. And to do one of

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: you--which has long been my cherished dream--I hold myself quite

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: capable.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Go ahead! That dream at least need not be long in coming

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: true.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: But I don't want to fix your features in my mind until

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: this evening's success is over. Not until then will you have

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: become what you should be.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: How sure you are of victory!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, it is written on your face that you are going to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: win this battle, and I think you must feel that yourself.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Why do you think so?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Because I can feel it. This morning I was ill, you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: know, and now I am well.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Embarrassed] Listen, I have a single ticket left--only

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: one. I place it at your disposal, Adolphe.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Thank you, but I surrender it to Henriette.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: But that wouldn't do?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Why not? And I never go to the theatre anyhow, as I

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: cannot stand the heat.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: But you will come and take us home at least after the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: show is over.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: If you insist on it. Otherwise Maurice has to come back

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: here, where we shall all be waiting for him.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: You can just as well take the trouble of meeting us. In

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: fact, I ask, I beg you to do so--And if you don't want to wait

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: outside the theatre, you can meet us at the Auberge des Adrets--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That's settled then, isn't it?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Wait a little. You have a way of settling things to suit

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: yourself, before other people have a chance to consider them.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What is there to consider--whether you are to see your

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: lady home or not?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You never know what may be involved in a simple act like

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that, but I have a sort of premonition.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Hush, hush, hush! Don't talk of spooks while the sun is

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: shining. Let him come or not, as it pleases him. We can always

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: find our way back here.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [Rising] Well, now I have to leave you--model, you know.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Good-bye, both of you. And good luck to you, Maurice. To-morrow

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: you will be out on the right side. Good-bye, Henriette.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Do you really have to go?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I must.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Good-bye then. We'll meet later.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Think of it, that we should meet at last!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Do you find anything remarkable in that?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: It looks as if it had to happen, for Adolphe has done

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: his best to prevent it.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Has he?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Oh, you must have noticed it.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I have noticed it, but why should you mention it?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I had to.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, and I don't have to tell you that I wanted to run

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: away through the kitchen in order to avoid meeting you and was

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: stopped by a guest who closed the door in front of me.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Why do you tell me about it now?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I don't know.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That's all right, Madame Catherine. There's nothing to be

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: afraid of.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Was that meant as a signal or a warning?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Probably both.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Do they take me for a locomotive that has to have

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: flagmen ahead of it?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And switchmen! The danger is always greatest at the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: switches.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: How nasty you can be!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Monsieur Maurice isn't nasty at all. So far nobody

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: has been kinder than he to those that love him and trust in him.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Sh, sh, sh!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [To MAURICE] The old lady is rather impertinent.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: We can walk over to the boulevard, if you care to do so.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: With pleasure. This is not the place for me. I can just

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: feel their hatred clawing at me. [Goes out.]

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Starts after her] Good-bye, Madame Catherine.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. A moment! May I speak a word to you, Monsieur

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: Maurice?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Stops unwillingly] What is it?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Don't do it! Don't do it!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Don't do it!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Don't be scared. This lady is not my kind, but she

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: interests me. Or hardly that even.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE, Don't trust yourself!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, I do trust myself. Good-bye. [Goes out.]

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ACT II

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: FIRST SCENE

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: suggestion of stage effect. Tables and easy-chairs are scattered

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: in corners and nooks. The walls are decorated with armour and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: weapons. Along the ledge of the wainscoting stand glasses and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: jugs.)

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: other at a table on which stands a bottle of champagne and three

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: filled glasses. The third glass is placed at that side of the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: table which is nearest the background, and there an easy-chair is

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: kept ready for the still missing "third man.")

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Puts his watch in front of himself on the table] If he

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: doesn't get here within the next five minutes, he isn't coming at

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: all. And suppose in the meantime we drink with his ghost. [Touches

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the third glass with the rim of his own.]

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Doing the same] Here's to you, Adolphe!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: He won't come.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: He will come.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: He won't.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: He will.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What an evening! What a wonderful day! I can hardly grasp

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: that a new life has begun. Think only: the manager believes that I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: may count on no less than one hundred thousand francs. I'll spend

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: twenty thousand on a villa outside the city. That leaves me eighty

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: thousand. I won't be able to take it all in until to-morrow, for I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: am tired, tired, tired. [Sinks back into the chair] Have you ever

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: felt really happy?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Never. How does it feel?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I don't quite know how to put it. I cannot express it,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: but I seem chiefly to be thinking of the chagrin of my enemies. It

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: isn't nice, but that's the way it is.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Is it happiness to be thinking of one's enemies?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Why, the victor has to count his killed and wounded

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: enemies in order to gauge the extent of his victory.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Are you as bloodthirsty as all that?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Perhaps not. But when you have felt the pressure of other

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: people's heels on your chest for years, it must be pleasant to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: shake off the enemy and draw a full breath at last.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Don't you find it strange that yon are sitting here,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: alone with me, an insignificant girl practically unknown to you--

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: and on an evening like this, when you ought to have a craving to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: show yourself like a triumphant hero to all the people, on the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: boulevards, in the big restaurants?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Of course, it's rather funny, but it feels good to be

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: here, and your company is all I care for.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: You don't look very hilarious.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, I feel rather sad, and I should like to weep a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: little.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: What is the meaning of that?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It is fortune conscious of its own nothingness and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: waiting for misfortune to appear.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Oh my, how sad! What is it you are missing anyhow?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I miss the only thing that gives value to life.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: So you love her no longer then?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Not in the way I understand love. Do you think she has

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: read my play, or that she wants to see it? Oh, she is so good, so

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: self-sacrificing and considerate, but to go out with me for a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: night's fun she would regard as sinful. Once I treated her to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: champagne, you know, and instead of feeling happy over it, she

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: picked up the wine list to see what it cost. And when she read the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: price, she wept--wept because Marion was in need of new stockings.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It is beautiful, of course: it is touching, if you please. But I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: can get no pleasure out of it. And I do want a little pleasure

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: before life runs out. So far I have had nothing but privation, but

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: now, now--life is beginning for me. [The clock strikes twelve] Now

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: begins a new day, a new era!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Adolphe is not coming.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, now he won't, come. And now it is too late to go back

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: to the Crêmerie.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: But they are waiting for you.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Let them wait. They have made me promise to come, and I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: take back my promise. Are you longing to go there?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: On the contrary!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Will you keep me company then?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: With pleasure, if you care to have me.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Otherwise I shouldn't be asking you. It is strange, you

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: know, that the victor's wreath seems worthless if you can't place

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: it at the feet of some woman--that everything seems worthless when

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: you have not a woman.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: You don't need to be without a woman--you?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Well, that's the question.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Don't you know that a man is irresistible in his hour

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: of success and fame?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, I don't know, for I have had no experience of it.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: You are a queer sort! At this moment, when you are the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: most envied man in Paris, you sit here and brood. Perhaps your

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: conscience is troubling you because you have neglected that

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: invitation to drink chicory coffee with the old lady over at the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: milk shop?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, my conscience is troubling me on that score, and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: even here I am aware of their resentment, their hurt feelings,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: their well-grounded anger. My comrades in distress had the right

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: to demand my presence this evening. The good Madame Catherine had

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: a privileged claim on my success, from which a glimmer of hope was

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: to spread over the poor fellows who have not yet succeeded. And I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: have robbed them of their faith in me. I can hear the vows they

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: have been making: "Maurice will come, for he is a good fellow; he

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: doesn't despise us, and he never fails to keep his word." Now I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: have made them forswear themselves.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: to play the finale of Beethoven's Sonata in D-minor (Op. 31, No.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: 3). The allegretto is first played piano, then more forte, and at

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: last passionately, violently, with complete abandon.)

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Who can be playing at this time of the night?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Probably some nightbirds of the same kind as we. But

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: listen! Your presentation of the case is not correct. Remember

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: that Adolphe promised to meet us here. We waited for him, and he

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: failed to keep his promise. So that you are not to blame--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: You think so? While you are speaking, I believe you, but

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: when you stop, my conscience begins again. What have you in that

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: package?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Oh, it is only a laurel wreath that I meant to send up

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: to the stage, but I had no chance to do so. Let me give it to you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: now--it is said to have a cooling effect on burning foreheads.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: the forehead] Hail to the victor!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Don't!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Kneeling] Hail to the King!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Rising] No, now you scare me.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: You timid man! You of little faith who are afraid of

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: fortune even! Who robbed you of your self-assurance and turned you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: into a dwarf?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: A dwarf? Yes, you are right. I am not working up in the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: clouds, like a giant, with crashing and roaring, but I forge my

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: weapons deep down in the silent heart of the mountain. You think

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: that my modesty shrinks before the victor's wreath. On the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: contrary, I despise it: it is not enough for me. You think I am

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: afraid of that ghost with its jealous green eyes which sits over

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: there and keeps watch on my feelings--the strength of which you

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: don't suspect. Away, ghost! [He brushes the third, untouched glass

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: off the table] Away with you, you superfluous third person--you

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: absent one who has lost your rights, if you ever had any. You

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: stayed away from the field of battle because you knew yourself

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: already beaten. As I crush this glass under my foot, so I will

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: crush the image of yourself which you have reared in a temple no

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: longer yours.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Good! That's the way! Well spoken, my hero!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Now I have sacrificed my best friend, my most faithful

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: helper, on your altar, Astarte! Are you satisfied?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Astarte is a pretty name, and I'll keep it--I think you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: love me, Maurice.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Of course I do--Woman of evil omen, you who stir up man's

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: courage with your scent of blood, whence do you come and where do

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: you lead me? I loved you before I saw you, for I trembled when I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: heard them speak of you. And when I saw you in the doorway, your

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: soul poured itself into mine. And when you left, I could still

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: feel your presence in my arms. I wanted to flee from you, but

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: something held me back, and this evening we have been driven

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: together as the prey is driven into the hunter's net. Whose is the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: fault? Your friend's, who pandered for us!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Fault or no fault: what does it matter, and what does

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: it mean?--Adolphe has been at fault in not bringing us together

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: before. He is guilty of having stolen from us two weeks of bliss,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: to which he had no right himself. I am jealous of him on your

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: behalf. I hate him because he has cheated you out of your

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: mistress. I should like to blot him from the host of the living,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: and his memory with him--wipe him out of the past even, make him

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: unmade, unborn!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Well, we'll bury him beneath our own memories. We'll

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: cover him with leaves and branches far out in the wild woods, and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: then we'll pile stone on top of the mound so that he will never

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: look up again. [Raising his glass] Our fate is sealed. Woe unto

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: us! What will come next?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Next comes the new era--What have you in that package?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I cannot remember.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Opens the package and takes out a tie and a pair of

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: gloves] That tie is a fright! It must have cost at least fifty

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: centimes.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Snatching the things away from her] Don't you touch

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: them!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: They are from her?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, they are.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Give them to me.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, she's better than we, better than everybody else.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I don't believe it. She is simply stupider and

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: stingier. One who weeps because you order champagne--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: When the child was without stockings. Yes, she is a good

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: woman.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Philistine! You'll never be an artist. But I am an

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: artist, and I'll make a bust of you with a shopkeeper's cap

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: instead of the laurel wreath--Her name is Jeanne?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: How do you know?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Why, that's the name of all housekeepers.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Henriette!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: fireplace.)

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Weakly] Astarte, now you demand the sacrifice of women.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: You shall have them, but if you ask for innocent children, too,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: then I'll send you packing.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Can you tell me what it is that binds you to me?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: If I only knew, I should be able to tear myself away. But

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I believe it must be those qualities which you have and I lack. I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: believe that the evil within you draws me with the irresistible

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: lure of novelty.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Have you ever committed a crime?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No real one. Have you?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Well, how did you find it?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: It was greater than to perform a good deed, for by that

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: we are placed on equality with others; it was greater than to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: perform some act of heroism, for by that we are raised above

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: others and rewarded. That crime placed me outside and beyond life,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: society, and my fellow-beings. Since then I am living only a

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: partial life, a sort of dream life, and that's why reality never

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: gets a hold on me.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What was it you did?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I won't tell, for then you would get scared again.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Can you never be found out?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Never. But that does not prevent me from seeing,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: frequently, the five stones at the Place de Roquette, where the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: scaffold used to stand; and for this reason I never dare to open a

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: pack of cards, as I always turn up the five-spot of diamonds.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Was it that kind of a crime?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, it was that kind.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Of course, it's horrible, but it is interesting. Have you

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: no conscience?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: None, but I should be grateful if you would talk of

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: something else.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Suppose we talk of--love?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Of that you don't talk until it is over.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Have you been in love with Adolphe?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I don't know. The goodness of his nature drew me like

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: some beautiful, all but vanished memory of childhood. Yet there

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: was much about his person that offended my eye, so that I had to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: spend a long time retouching, altering, adding, subtracting,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: before I could make a presentable figure of him. When he talked, I

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: could notice that he had learned from you, and the lesson was

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: often badly digested and awkwardly applied. You can imagine then

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: how miserable the copy must appear now, when I am permitted to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: study the original. That's why he was afraid of having us two

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: meet; and when it did happen, he understood at once that his time

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: was up.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Poor Adolphe!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I feel sorry for him, too, as I know he must be

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: suffering beyond all bounds--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Sh! Somebody is coming.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I wonder if it could be he?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That would be unbearable.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, it isn't he, but if it had been, how do you think

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: the situation would have shaped itself?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: At first he would have been a little sore at you because

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: he had made a mistake in regard to the meeting-place--and tried to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: find us in several other cafes--but his soreness would have

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: changed into pleasure at finding us--and seeing that we had not

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: deceived him. And in the joy at having wronged us by his

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: suspicions, he would love both of us. And so it would make him

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: happy to notice that we had become such good friends. It had

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: always been his dream--hm! he is making the speech now--his dream

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: that the three of us should form a triumvirate that could set the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: world a great example of friendship asking for nothing--"Yes, I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: trust you, Maurice, partly because you are my friend, and partly

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: because your feelings are tied up elsewhere."

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Bravo! You must have been in a similar situation

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: before, or you couldn't give such a lifelike picture of it. Do you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: know that Adolphe is just that kind of a third person who cannot

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: enjoy his mistress without having his friend along?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That's why I had to be called in to entertain you--Hush!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: There is somebody outside--It must be he.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, don't you know these are the hours when ghosts

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: walk, and then you can see so many things, and hear them also. To

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: keep awake at night, when you ought to be sleeping, has for me the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: same charm as a crime: it is to place oneself above and beyond the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: laws of nature.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But the punishment is fearful--I am shivering or

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: quivering, with cold or with fear.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Wraps her opera cloak about him] Put this on. It will

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: make you warm.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That's nice. It is as if I were inside of your skin, as

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: if my body had been melted up by lack of sleep and were being

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: remoulded in your shape. I can feel the moulding process going on.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But I am also growing a new soul, new thoughts, and here, where

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: your bosom has left an impression, I can feel my own beginning to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: bulge.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: practicing the Sonata in D-minor, sometimes pianissimo, sometimes

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: wildly fortissimo; now and then he has kept silent for a little

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: while, and at other times nothing has been heard but a part of the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: finale: bars 96 to 107.)

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What a monster, to sit there all night practicing on the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: piano. It gives me a sick feeling. Do you know what I propose? Let

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: us drive out to the Bois de Boulogne and take breakfast in the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Pavilion, and see the sun rise over the lakes.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Bully!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But first of all I must arrange to have my mail and the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: morning papers sent out by messenger to the Pavilion. Tell me,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Henriette: shall we invite Adolphe?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Oh, that's going too far! But why not? The ass can also

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: be harnessed to the triumphal chariot. Let him come. [They get

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: up.]

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Taking off the cloak] Then I'll ring.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Wait a moment! [Throws herself into his arms.]

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: SECOND SCENE

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Boulogne. It is richly carpeted and full of mirrors, easy-chairs,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: and divans. There are glass doors in the background, and beside

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: them windows overlooking the lakes. In the foreground a table is

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: spread, with flowers in the centre, bowls full of fruit, wine in

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: decanters, oysters on platters, many different kinds of wine

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: glasses, and two lighted candelabra. On the right there is a round

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: table full of newspapers and telegrams.)

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: small table.)

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: There is no longer any doubt about it. The newspapers

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: tell me it is so, and these telegrams congratulate me on my

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: success. This is the beginning of a new life, and my fate is

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: wedded to yours by this night, when you were the only one to share

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: my hopes and my triumph. From your hand I received the laurel, and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: it seems to me as if everything had come from you.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: What a wonderful night! Have we been dreaming, or is

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: this something we have really lived through?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Rising] And what a morning after such a night! I feel as

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: if it were the world's first day that is now being illumined by

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the rising sun. Only this minute was the earth created and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: stripped of those white films that are now floating off into

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: space. There lies the Garden of Eden in the rosy light of dawn,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: and here is the first human couple--Do you know, I am so happy I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: could cry at the thought that all mankind is not equally happy--Do

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: you hear that distant murmur as of ocean waves beating against a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: rocky shore, as of winds sweeping through a forest? Do you know

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: what it is? It is Paris whispering my name. Do you see the columns

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: of smoke that rise skyward in thousands and tens of thousands?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: They are the fires burning on my altars, and if that be not so,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: then it must become so, for I will it. At this moment all the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: telegraph instruments of Europe are clicking out my name. The

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Oriental Express is carrying the newspapers to the Far East,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: toward the rising sun; and the ocean steamers are carrying them to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the utmost West. The earth is mine, and for that reason it is

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: beautiful. Now I should like to have wings for us two, so that we

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: might rise from here and fly far, far away, before anybody can

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: soil my happiness, before envy has a chance to wake me out of my

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: dream--for it is probably a dream!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Holding out her hand to him] Here you can feel that

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: you are not dreaming.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It is not a dream, but it has been one. As a poor young

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: man, you know, when I was walking in the woods down there, and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: looked up to this Pavilion, it looked to me like a fairy castle,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: and always my thoughts carried me up to this room, with the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: balcony outside and the heavy curtains, as to a place of supreme

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: bliss. To be sitting here in company with a beloved woman and see

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the sun rise while the candles were still burning in the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: candelabra: that was the most audacious dream of my youth. Now it

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: has come true, and now I have no more to ask of life--Do you want

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: to die now, together with me?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, you fool! Now I want to begin living.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Rising] To live: that is to suffer! Now comes reality. I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: can hear his steps on the stairs. He is panting with alarm, and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: his heart is beating with dread of having lost what it holds most

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: precious. Can you believe me if I tell you that Adolphe is under

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: this roof? Within a minute he will be standing in the middle of

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: this floor.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Alarmed] It was a stupid trick to ask him to come

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: here, and I am already regretting it--Well, we shall see anyhow if

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: your forecast of the situation proves correct.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Oh, it is easy to be mistaken about a person's feelings.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Ask the gentleman to step in. [To HENRIETTE] I am afraid

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: we'll regret this.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Too late to think of that now--Hush!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Trying to speak unconcernedly] There you are! What

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: became of you last night?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I looked for you at the Hotel des Arrets and waited a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: whole hour.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: So you went to the wrong place. We were waiting several

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: hours for you at the Auberge des Adrets, and we are still waiting

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: for you, as you see.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [Relieved] Thank heaven!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Good morning, Adolphe. You are always expecting the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: worst and worrying yourself needlessly. I suppose you imagined

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: that we wanted to avoid your company. And though you see that we

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: sent for you, you are still thinking yourself superfluous.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Pardon me: I was wrong, but the night was dreadful.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [To ADOLPHE] Well, are you not going to congratulate

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Maurice on his great success?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Oh, yes! Your success is the real thing, and envy itself

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: cannot deny it. Everything is giving way before you, and even I

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: have a sense of my own smallness in your presence.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Nonsense!--Henriette, are you not going to offer Adolphe

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: a glass of wine?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Thank you, not for me--nothing at all!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [To ADOLPHE] What's the matter with you? Are you ill?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Not yet, but--

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Your eyes--

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: What of them?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What happened at the Crêmerie last night? I suppose they

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: are angry with me?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Nobody is angry with you, but your absence caused a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: depression which it hurt me to watch. But nobody was angry with

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: you, believe me. Your friends understood, and they regarded your

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: failure to come with sympathetic forbearance. Madame Catherine

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: herself defended you and proposed your health. We all rejoiced in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: your success as if it had been our own.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Well, those are nice people! What good friends you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: have, Maurice.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, better than I deserve.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Nobody has better friends than he deserves, and you are a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: man greatly blessed in his friends--Can't you feel how the air is

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: softened to-day by all the kind thoughts and wishes that stream

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: toward you from a thousand breasts?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: From a thousand breasts that you have rid of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: nightmare that had been crushing them during a lifetime. Humanity

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: had been slandered--and you have exonerated it: that's why men

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: feel grateful toward you. To-day they are once more holding their

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: heads high and saying: You see, we are a little better than our

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: reputation after all. And that thought makes them better.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Am I in the way? Just let me warm myself a little in your

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: sunshine, Maurice, and then I'll go.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Why should you go when you have only just arrived?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Why? Because I have seen what I need not have seen;

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: because I know now that my hour is past. [Pause] That you sent for

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: me, I take as an expression of thoughtfulness, a notice of what

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: has happened, a frankness that hurts less than deceit. You hear

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that I think well of my fellow-beings, and this I have learned

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: from you, Maurice. [Pause] But, my friend, a few moments ago I

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: passed through the Church of St. Germain, and there I saw a woman

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and a child. I am not wishing that you had seen them, for what has

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: happened cannot be altered, but if you gave a thought or a word to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: them before you set them adrift on the waters of the great city,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: then you could enjoy your happiness undisturbed. And now I bid you

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: good-by.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Why must you go?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: And you ask that? Do you want me to tell you?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, I don't.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Good-by then! [Goes out.]

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: The Fall: and lo! "they knew that they were naked."

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: What a difference between this scene and the one we

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: imagined! He is better than we.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It seems to me now as if all the rest were better than

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: we.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Do you see that the sun has vanished behind clouds, and

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: that the woods have lost their rose colour?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, I see, and the blue lake has turned black. Let us

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: flee to some place where the sky is always blue and the trees are

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: always green.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, let us--but without any farewells.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, with farewells.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: We were to fly. You spoke of wings--and your feet are

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: of lead. I am not jealous, but if you go to say farewell and get

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: two pairs of arms around your neck--then you can't tear yourself

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: away.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Perhaps you are right, but only one pair of little arms

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: is needed to hold me fast.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: It is the child that holds you then, and not the woman?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It is the child.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: The child! Another woman's child! And for the sake of

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: it I am to suffer. Why must that child block the way where I want

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: to pass, and must pass?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, why? It would be better if it had never existed.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Walks excitedly back and forth] Indeed! But now it

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: does exist. Like a rock on the road, a rock set firmly in the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: ground, immovable, so that it upsets the carriage.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: The triumphal chariot!--The ass is driven to death, but

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the rock remains. Curse it! [Pause.]

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: There is nothing to do.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, we must get married, and then our child will make us

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: forget the other one.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: This will kill this!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Kill! What kind of word is that?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Changing tone] Your child will kill our love.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, girl, our love will kill whatever stands in its way,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: but it will not be killed.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Opens a deck of cards lying on the mantlepiece] Look

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: at it! Five-spot of diamonds--the scaffold! Can it be possible

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: that our fates are determined in advance? That our thoughts are

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: guided as if through pipes to the spot for which they are bound,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: without chance for us to stop them? But I don't want it, I don't

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
