TEXT: want it!--Do you realise that I must go to the scaffold if my

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: crime should be discovered?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Tell me about your crime. Now is the time for it.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, I should regret it afterward, and you would despise

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: me--no, no, no!--Have you ever heard that a person could be hated

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: to death? Well, my father incurred the hatred of my mother and my

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: sisters, and he melted away like wax before a fire. Ugh! Let us

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: talk of something else. And, above all, let us get away. The air

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: is poisoned here. To-morrow your laurels will be withered, the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: triumph will be forgotten, and in a week another triumphant hero

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: will hold the public attention. Away from here, to work for new

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: victories! But first of all, Maurice, you must embrace your child

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: and provide for its immediate future. You don't have to see the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: mother at all.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Thank you! Your good heart does you honour, and I love

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: you doubly when you show the kindness you generally hide.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: And then you go to the Crêmerie and say good-by to the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: old lady and your friends. Leave no unsettled business behind to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: make your mind heavy on our trip.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I'll clear up everything, and to-night we meet at the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: railroad station.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Agreed! And then: away from here--away toward the sea

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: and the sun!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: ACT III

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: FIRST SCENE

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: counter, ADOLPHE at a table.)

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Such is life, Monseiur Adolphe. But you young ones

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: are always demanding too much, and then you come here and blubber

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: over it afterward.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: No, it isn't that. I reproach nobody, and I am as fond as

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ever of both of them. But there is one thing that makes me sick at

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: heart. You see, I thought more of Maurice than of anybody else; so

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: much that I wouldn't have grudged him anything that could give him

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: pleasure--but now I have lost him, and it hurts me worse than the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: loss of her. I have lost both of them, and so my loneliness is

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: made doubly painful. And then there is still something else which

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I have not yet been able to clear up.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Don't brood so much. Work and divert yourself.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: Now, for instance, do you ever go to church?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: What should I do there?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Oh, there's so much to look at, and then there is

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: the music. There is nothing commonplace about it, at least.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Perhaps not. But I don't belong to that fold, I guess,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: for it never stirs me to any devotion. And then, Madame Catherine,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: faith is a gift, they tell me, and I haven't got it yet.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Well, wait till you get it--But what is this I

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: heard a while ago? Is it true that you have sold a picture in

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: London for a high price, and that you have got a medal?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Yes, it's true.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Merciful heavens!--and not a word do you say about

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: it?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I am afraid of fortune, and besides it seems almost

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: worthless to me at this moment. I am afraid of it as of a spectre:

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: it brings disaster to speak of having seen it.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. You're a queer fellow, and that's what you have

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: always been.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Not queer at all, but I have seen so much misfortune come

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in the wake of fortune, and I have seen how adversity brings out

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: true friends, while none but false ones appear in the hour of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: success--You asked me if I ever went to church, and I answered

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: evasively. This morning I stepped into the Church of St. Germain

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: without really knowing why I did so. It seemed as if I were

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: looking for somebody in there--somebody to whom I could silently

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: offer my gratitude. But I found nobody. Then I dropped a gold coin

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in the poor-box. It was all I could get out of my church-going,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and that was rather commonplace, I should say.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. It was always something; and then it was fine to

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: think of the poor after having heard good news.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: It was neither fine nor anything else: it was something I

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: did because I couldn't help myself. But something more occurred

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: while I was in the church. I saw Maurice's girl friend, Jeanne,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and her child. Struck down, crushed by his triumphal chariot, they

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: seemed aware of the full extent of their misfortune.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Well, children, I don't know in what kind of shape

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: you keep your consciences. But how a decent fellow, a careful and

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: considerate man like Monsieur Maurice, can all of a sudden desert

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: a woman and her child, that is something I cannot explain.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Nor can I explain it, and he doesn't seem to understand

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: it himself. I met them this morning, and everything appeared quite

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: natural to them, quite proper, as if they couldn't imagine

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: anything else. It was as if they had been enjoying the satisfaction

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of a good deed or the fulfilment of a sacred duty. There are things,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Madame Catherine, that we cannot explain, and for this reason it

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: is not for us to judge. And besides, you saw how it happened.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Maurice felt the danger in the air. I foresaw it and tried to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: prevent their meeting. Maurice wanted to run away from it, but

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: nothing helped. Why, it was as if a plot had been laid by some

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: invisible power, and as if they had been driven by guile into

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: each other's arms. Of course, I am disqualified in this case, but

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I wouldn't hesitate to pronounce a verdict of "not guilty."

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Well, now, to be able to forgive as you do, that's

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: what I call religion.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Heavens, could it be that I am religious without knowing

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: it.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. But then, to _let_ oneself be driven or tempted

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: into evil, as Monsieur Maurice has done, means weakness or bad

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: character. And if you feel your strength failing you, then you ask

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: for help, and then you get it. But he was too conceited to do

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: that--Who is this coming? The Abbé, I think.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: What does he want here?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. [Enters] Good evening, madame. Good evening, Monsieur.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Can I be of any service?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: ABBÉ. Has Monsieur Maurice, the author, been here to-day?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Not to-day. His play has just been put on, and

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: that is probably keeping him busy.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: ABBÉ. I have--sad news to bring him. Sad in several respects.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. May I ask of what kind?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: ABBÉ. Yes, it's no secret. The daughter he had with that girl,

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: Jeanne, is dead.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Dead!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Marion dead!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Yes, she died suddenly this morning without any previous

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: illness.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. O Lord, who can tell Thy ways!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: ABBÉ. The mother's grief makes it necessary that Monsieur Maurice

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: look after her, so we must try to find him. But first a question

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: in confidence: do you know whether Monsieur Maurice was fond of

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: the child, or was indifferent to it?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. If he was fond of Marion? Why, all of us know how

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: he loved her.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: There's no doubt about that.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. I am glad to hear it, and it settles the matter so far as I

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: am concerned.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Has there been any doubt about it?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: ABBÉ. Yes, unfortunately. It has even been rumoured in the

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: neighbourhood that he had abandoned the child and its mother in

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: order to go away with a strange woman. In a few hours this rumour

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: has grown into definite accusations, and at the same time the

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: feeling against him has risen to such a point that his life is

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: threatened and he is being called a murderer.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Good God, what is _this_? What does it mean?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: ABBÉ. Now I'll tell you my opinion--I am convinced that the man is

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: innocent on this score, and the mother feels as certain about it

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: as I do. But appearances are against Monsieur Maurice, and I think

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: he will find it rather hard to clear himself when the police come

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: to question him.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Have the police got hold of the matter?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Yea, the police have had to step in to protect him against

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: all those ugly rumours and the rage of the people. Probably the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Commissaire will be here soon.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. [To ADOLPHE] There you see what happens when a man

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: cannot tell the difference between good and evil, and when he

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: trifles with vice. God will punish!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Then he is more merciless than man.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. What do you know about that?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Not very much, but I keep an eye on what happens--

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. And you understand it also?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Not yet perhaps.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Let us look more closely at the matter--Oh, here comes the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Commissaire.

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: [Enters] Gentlemen--Madame Catherine--I have to

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: trouble you for a moment with a few questions concerning Monsieur

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: Maurice. As you have probably heard, he has become the object of a

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: hideous rumour, which, by the by, I don't believe in.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. None of us believes in it either.

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: That strengthens my own opinion, but for his own sake

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: I must give him a chance to defend himself.

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: ABBÉ. That's right, and I guess he will find justice, although it

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: may come hard.

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: Appearances are very much against him, but I have

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: seen guiltless people reach the scaffold before their innocence

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: was discovered. Let me tell you what there is against him. The

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: little girl, Marion, being left alone by her mother, was secretly

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: visited by the father, who seems to have made sure of the time

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: when the child was to be found alone. Fifteen minutes after his

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: visit the mother returned home and found the child dead. All this

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: makes the position of the accused man very unpleasant--The post-

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: mortem examination brought out no signs of violence or of poison,

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: but the physicians admit the existence of new poisons that leave

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: no traces behind them. To me all this is mere coincidence of the

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: kind I frequently come across. But here's something that looks

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: worse. Last night Monsieur Maurice was seen at the Auberge des

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: Adrets in company with a strange lady. According to the waiter,

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: they were talking about crimes. The Place de Roquette and the

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: scaffold were both mentioned. A queer topic of conversation for a

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: pair of lovers of good breeding and good social position! But even

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: this may be passed over, as we know by experience that people who

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: have been drinking and losing a lot of sleep seem inclined to dig

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: up all the worst that lies at the bottom of their souls. Far more

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: serious is the evidence given by the head waiter as to their

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: champagne breakfast in the Bois de Boulogne this morning. He says

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: that he heard them wish the life out of a child. The man is said

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: to have remarked that, "It would be better if it had never

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: existed." To which the woman replied: "Indeed! But now it does

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: exist." And as they went on talking, these words occurred: "This

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: will kill this!" And the answer was: "Kill! What kind of word is

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: that?" And also: "The five-spot of diamonds, the scaffold, the

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: Place de Roquette." All this, you see, will be hard to get out of,

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: and so will the foreign journey planned for this evening. These

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: are serious matters.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: He is lost!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. That's a dreadful story. One doesn't know what to

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: believe.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: ABBÉ. This is not the work of man. God have mercy on him!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: He is in the net, and he will never get out of it.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. He had no business to get in.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Do you begin to suspect him also, Madame Catherine?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Yes and no. I have got beyond having an opinion in

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: this matter. Have you not seen angels turn into devils just as you

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: turn your hand, and then become angels again?

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: It certainly does look queer. However, we'll have to

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: wait and hear what explanations he can give. No one will be judged

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: unheard. Good evening, gentlemen. Good evening, Madame Catherine.

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: ABBÉ. This is not the work of man.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: No, it looks as if demons had been at work for the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: undoing of man.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. It is either a punishment for secret misdeeds, or it is a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: terrible test.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: [Enters, dressed in mourning] Good evening. Pardon me for

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: asking, but have you seen Monsieur Maurice?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. No, madame, but I think he may be here any minute.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: You haven't met him then since--

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Not since this morning.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Let me tell you that I share in your great sorrow.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Thank you, madame. [To the ABBÉ] So you are here, Father.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Yes, my child. I thought I might be of some use to you. And

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: it was fortunate, as it gave me a chance to speak to the

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Commissaire.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: The Commissaire! He doesn't suspect Maurice also, does he?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. No, he doesn't, and none of us here do. But appearances are

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: against him in a most appalling manner.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: You mean on account of the talk the waiters overheard--it

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: means nothing to me, who has heard such things before when Maurice

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: had had a few drinks. Then it is his custom to speculate on crimes

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: and their punishment. Besides it seems to have been the woman in

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: his company who dropped the most dangerous remarks. I should like

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: to have a look into that woman's eyes.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: My dear Jeanne, no matter how much harm that woman may

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: have done you, she did nothing with evil intention--in fact, she

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: had no intention whatever, but just followed the promptings of her

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: nature. I know her to be a good soul and one who can very well

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: bear being looked straight in the eye.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Your judgment in this matter, Adolphe, has great value to

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: me, and I believe what you say. It means that I cannot hold

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: anybody but myself responsible for what has happened. It is my

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: carelessness that is now being punished. [She begins to cry.]

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Don't accuse yourself unjustly! I know you, and the serious

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: spirit in which you have regarded your motherhood. That your

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: assumption of this responsibility had not been sanctioned by

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: religion and the civil law was not your fault. No, we are here

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: facing something quite different.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: What then?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Who can tell?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [Rises with an air of determination and goes to meet

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: HENRIETTE] You here?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, where is Maurice?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Do you know--or don't you?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I know everything. Excuse me, Madame Catherine, but I

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: was ready to start and absolutely had to step in here a moment.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [To JEANNE] I ought to say something, but it matters

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: very little, for anything I can say must sound like an insult or a

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: mockery. But if I ask you simply to believe that I share your deep

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: sorrow as much as anybody standing closer to you, then you must

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: not turn away from me. You mustn't, for I deserve your pity if not

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: your forbearance. [Holds out her hand.]

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: [Looks hard at her] I believe you now--and in the next

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: moment I don't. [Takes HENRIETTE'S hand.]

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Kisses JEANNE'S hand] Thank you!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: [Drawing back her hand] Oh, don't! I don't deserve it! I

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: don't deserve it!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Pardon me, but while we are gathered here and peace seems to

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: prevail temporarily at least, won't you, Mademoiselle Henriette,

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: shed some light into all the uncertainty and darkness surrounding

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: the main point of accusation? I ask you, as a friend among

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: friends, to tell us what you meant with all that talk about

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: killing, and crime, and the Place de Roquette. That your words had

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: no connection with the death of the child, we have reason to

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: believe, but it would give us added assurance to hear what you

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: were really talking about. Won't you tell us?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [After a pause] That I cannot tell! No, I cannot!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Henriette, do tell! Give us the word that will relieve us

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: all.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I cannot! Don't ask me!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: ABBÉ. This is not the work of man!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Oh, that this moment had to come! And in this manner!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: death. Is that enough?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Enough for us, but not for Justice.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Justice! If you knew how true your words are!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: ABBÉ. [To HENRIETTE] And if you knew what you were saying just

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: now!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Do you know that better than I?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Yes, I do.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Have no fear, for even if I guess your secret, it will not

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: be exposed. Besides, I have nothing to do with human justice, but

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: a great deal with divine mercy.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Enters hastily, dressed for travelling. He doesn't look

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: at the others, who are standing in the background, but goes

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: straight up to the counter, where MME. CATHERINE is sitting.] You

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: are not angry at me, Madame Catherine, because I didn't show up. I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: have come now to apologise to you before I start for the South at

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: eight o'clock this evening.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Then you are angry at me? [Looks around] What does all

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: this mean? Is it a dream, or what is it? Of course, I can see that

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: it is all real, but it looks like a wax cabinet--There is Jeanne,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: looking like a statue and dressed in black--And Henriette looking

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: like a corpse--What does it mean?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Nobody answers. It must mean something dreadful.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: it? [Pointing to EMILE] And there is a detective!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [Comes forward] You don't know then?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Nothing at all. But I must know!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Well, then--Marion is dead.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Marion--dead?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Yes, she died this morning.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [To JEANNE] So that's why you are in mourning. Jeanne,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Jeanne, who has done this to us?

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: He who holds life and death in his hand.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But I saw her looking well and happy this morning. How

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: did it happen? Who did it? Somebody must have done it? [His eyes

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: seek HENRIETTE.]

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Don't look for the guilty one here, for there is none to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: he found. Unfortunately the police have turned their suspicion in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: a direction where none ought to exist.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What direction is that?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Well--you may as well know that, your reckless talk last

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: night and this morning has placed you in a light that is anything

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: but favourable.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: MAURICE, So they were listening to us. Let me see, what were we

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: saying--I remember!--Then I am lost!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: But if you explain your thoughtless words we will believe

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: you.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I cannot! And I will not! I shall be sent to prison, but

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: it doesn't matter. Marion is dead! Dead! And I have killed her!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Think of what you are saying! Weigh your words! Do you

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: realise what you said just now?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What did I say?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You said that you had killed Marion.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Is there a human being here who could believe me a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: murderer, and who could hold me capable of taking my own child's

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: life? You who know me, Madame Catherine, tell me: do you believe,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: can you believe--

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. I don't know any longer what to believe. What the

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: heart thinketh the tongue speaketh. And your tongue has spoken

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: evil words.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: She doesn't believe me!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: But explain your words, man! Explain what you meant by

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: saying that "your love would kill everything that stood in its

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: way."

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: So they know that too--Are you willing to explain it,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Henriette?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, I cannot do that.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: ABBÉ. There is something wrong behind all this and you have lost

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: our sympathy, my friend. A while ago I could have sworn that you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: were innocent, and I wouldn't do that now.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [To JEANNE] What you have to say means more to me than

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: anything else. JEANNE. [Coldly] Answer a question first: who was

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: it you cursed during that orgie out there?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Have I done that too? Maybe. Yes, I am guilty, and yet I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: am guiltless. Let me go away from here, for I am ashamed of

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: myself, and I have done more wrong than I can forgive myself.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [To ADOLPHE] Go with him and see that he doesn't do

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: himself any harm.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Shall I--?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Who else?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [Without bitterness] You are nearest to it--Sh! A

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: carriage is stopping outside.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. It's the Commissaire. Well, much as I have seen of

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: life, I could never have believed that success and fame were such

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: short-lived things.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [To HENRIETTE] From the triumphal chariot to the patrol

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: wagon!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: [Simply] And the ass--who was that?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Oh, that must have been me.

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: [Enters with a paper in his hand] A summons to Police

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: Headquarters--to-night, at once--for Monsieur Maurice Gérard--and

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: for Mademoiselle Henrietta Mauclerc--both here?

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: MAURICE and HENRIETTE. Yes.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Is this an arrest?

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: Not yet. Only a summons.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And then?

SPEAKER: COMMISSAIRE
TEXT: We don't know yet.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Good-bye to all!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: go out.)

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: [Enters and goes up to JEANNE] Now I'll take you home,

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: sister.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: And what do you think of all this?

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: The man is innocent.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: ABBÉ. But as I see it, it is, and must always be, something

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: despicable to break one's promise, and it becomes unpardonable

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: when a woman and her child are involved.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Well, I should rather feel that way, too, now when it

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: concerns my own sister, but unfortunately I am prevented from

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: throwing the first stone because I have done the same thing

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: myself.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Although I am free from blame in that respect, I am not

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: throwing any stones either, but the act condemns itself and is

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: punished by its consequences.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: Pray for him! For both of them!

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ABBÉ. No, I'll do nothing of the kind, for it is an impertinence

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: to want to change the counsels of the Lord. And what has happened

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: here is, indeed, not the work of man.

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: SECOND SCENE

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: same table where MAURICE and HENRIETTE were sitting in the second

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: act. A cup of coffee stands in front of ADOLPHE. HENRIETTE has

SPEAKER: JEANNE
TEXT: ordered nothing.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You believe then that he will come here?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I am sure. He was released this noon for lack of

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: evidence, but he didn't want to show himself in the streets before

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: it was dark.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Poor fellow! Oh, I tell you, life seems horrible to me

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: since yesterday.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: And what about me? I am afraid to live, dare hardly

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: breathe, dare hardly think even, since I know that somebody is

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: spying not only on my words but on my thoughts.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: So it was here you sat that night when I couldn't find

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: you?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, but don't talk of it. I could die from shame when

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I think of it. Adolphe, you are made of a different, a better,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: stuff than he or I--

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Sh, sh, sh!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, indeed! And what was it that made me stay here? I

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: was lazy; I was tired; his success intoxicated me and bewitched

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: me--I cannot explain it. But if you had come, it would never have

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: happened. And to-day you are great, and he is small--less than the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: least of all. Yesterday he had one hundred thousand francs. To-day

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: he has nothing, because his play has been withdrawn. And public

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: opinion will never excuse him, for his lack of faith will be

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: judged as harshly as if he were the murderer, and those that see

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: farthest hold that the child died from sorrow, so that he was

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: responsible for it anyhow.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You know what my thoughts are in this matter, Henriette,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: but I should like to know that both of you are spotless. Won't you

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: tell me what those dreadful words of yours meant? It cannot be a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: chance that your talk in a festive moment like that dealt so

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: largely with killing and the scaffold.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: It was no chance. It was something that had to be said,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: something I cannot tell you--probably because I have no right to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: appear spotless in your eyes, seeing that I am not spotless.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: All this is beyond me.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Let us talk of something else--Do you believe there are

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: many unpunished criminals at large among us, some of whom may even

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: be our intimate friends?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [Nervously] Why? What do you mean?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Don't you believe that every human being at some time

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: or another has been guilty of some kind of act which would fall

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: under the law if it were discovered?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Yes, I believe that is true, but no evil act escapes

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: being punished by one's own conscience at least. [Rises and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: unbuttons his coat] And--nobody is really good who has not erred.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: have been in need of forgiveness--I had a friend whom we used to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: regard as a model man. He never spoke a hard word to anybody; he

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: forgave everything and everybody; and he suffered insults with a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: strange satisfaction that we couldn't explain. At last, late in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: life, he gave me his secret in a single word: I am a penitent! [He

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: sits down again.]

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [As if speaking to himself] There are crimes not

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: mentioned in the Criminal Code, and these are the worse ones, for

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: they have to be punished by ourselves, and no judge could be more

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: severe than we are against our own selves.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [After a pause] Well, that friend of yours, did he find

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: peace?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: After endless self-torture he reached a certain degree of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: composure, but life had never any real pleasures to offer him. He

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: never dared to accept any kind of distinction; he never dared to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: feel himself entitled to a kind word or even well-earned praise:

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in a word, he could never quite forgive himself.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Never? What had he done then?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: He had wished the life out of his father. And when his

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: father suddenly died, the son imagined himself to have killed him.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Those imaginations were regarded as signs of some mental disease,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and he was sent to an asylum. From this he was discharged after a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: time as wholly recovered--as they put it. But the sense of guilt

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: remained with him, and so he continued to punish himself for his

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: evil thoughts.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Are you sure the evil will cannot kill?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You mean in some mystic way?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: As you please. Let it go at mystic. In my own family--I

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: am sure that my mother and my sisters killed my father with their

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: hatred. You see, he had the awful idea that he must oppose all our

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: tastes and inclinations. Wherever he discovered a natural gift, he

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: tried to root it out. In that way he aroused a resistance that

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: accumulated until it became like an electrical battery charged

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: with hatred. At last it grew so powerful that he languished away,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: became depolarised, lost his will-power, and, in the end, came to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: wish himself dead.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: And your conscience never troubled you?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, and furthermore, I don't know what conscience is.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You don't? Well, then you'll soon learn. [Pause] How do

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: you believe Maurice will look when he gets here? What do you think

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: he will say?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yesterday morning, you know, he and I tried to make the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: same kind of guess about you while we were waiting for you.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Well?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: We guessed entirely wrong.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Can you tell me why you sent for me?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Malice, arrogance, outright cruelty!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: How strange it is that you can admit your faults and yet

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: not repent of them.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: It must be because I don't feel quite responsible for

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: them. They are like the dirt left behind by things handled during

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: the day and washed off at night. But tell me one thing: do you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: really think so highly of humanity as you profess to do?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Yes, we are a little better than our reputation--and a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: little worse.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: That is not a straightforward answer.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: No, it isn't. But are you willing to answer me frankly

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: when I ask you: do you still love Maurice?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I cannot tell until I see him. But at this moment I

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: feel no longing for him, and it seems as if I could very well live

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: without him.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: It's likely you could, but I fear you have become chained

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to his fate--Sh! Here he comes.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: How everything repeats itself. The situation is the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: same, the very words are the same, as when we were expecting you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: yesterday.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Enters, pale as death, hollow-eyed, unshaven] Here I am,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: my dear friends, if this be me. For that last night in a cell

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: changed me into a new sort of being. [Notices HENRIETTE and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Sit down and pull yourself together, and then we can talk

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: things over.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [To HENRIETTE] Perhaps I am in the way?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Now, don't get bitter.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I have grown bad in these twenty-four hours, and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: suspicious also, so I guess I'll soon be left to myself. And who

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: wants to keep company with a murderer?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: But you have been cleared of the charge.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Picks up a newspaper] By the police, yes, but not by

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: public opinion. Here you see the murderer Maurice Gérard, once a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: playwright, and his mistress, Henriette Mauclerc--

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: O my mother and my sisters--my mother! Jesus have

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: mercy!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And can you see that I actually look like a murderer? And

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: then it is suggested that my play was stolen. So there isn't a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: vestige left of the victorious hero from yesterday. In place of my

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: own, the name of Octave, my enemy, appears on the bill-boards, and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: he is going to collect my one hundred thousand francs. O Solon,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Solon! Such is fortune, and such is fame! You are fortunate,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Adolphe, because you have not yet succeeded.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: So you don't know that Adolphe has made a great success

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: in London and carried off the first prize?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Darkly] No, I didn't know that. Is it true, Adolphe?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: It is true, but I have returned the prize.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [With emphasis] That I didn't know! So you are also

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: prevented from accepting any distinctions--like your friend?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: My friend? [Embarrassed] Oh, yes, yes!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Your success gives me pleasure, but it puts us still

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: farther apart.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: That's what I expected, and I suppose I'll be as lonely

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: with my success as you with your adversity. Think of it--that

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: people feel hurt by your fortune! Oh, it's ghastly to be alive!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: You say that! What am I then to say? It is as if my eyes

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: had been covered with a black veil, and as if the colour and shape

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: of all life had been changed by it. This room looks like the room

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I saw yesterday, and yet it is quite different. I recognise both

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: of you, of course, but your faces are new to me. I sit here and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: search for words because I don't know what to say to you. I ought

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: to defend myself, but I cannot. And I almost miss the cell, for it

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: protected me, at least, against the curious glances that pass

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: right through me. The murderer Maurice and his mistress! You don't

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: love me any longer, Henriette, and no more do I care for you. To-

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: day you are ugly, clumsy, insipid, repulsive.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: table in the background.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Wait a little and get your thoughts together. That you

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: have been discharged and cleared of all suspicion must appear in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: some of the evening papers. And that puts an end to the whole

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: matter. Your play will be put on again, and if it comes to the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: worst, you can write a new one. Leave Paris for a year and let

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: everything become forgotten. You who have exonerated mankind will

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: be exonerated yourself.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Ha-ha! Mankind! Ha-ha!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You have ceased to believe in goodness? MAURICE. Yes, if

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I ever did believe in it. Perhaps it was only a mood, a manner of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: looking at things, a way of being polite to the wild beasts. When

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I, who was held among the best, can be so rotten to the core, what

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: must then be the wretchedness of the rest?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Now I'll go out and get all the evening papers, and then

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: we'll undoubtedly have reason to look at things in a different

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: way.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Turning toward the background] Two detectives!--It means

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: that I am released under surveillance, so that I can give myself

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: away by careless talking.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Those are not detectives. That's only your imagination. I

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: recognise both of them. [Goes toward the door.]

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Don't leave us alone, Adolphe. I fear that Henriette and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I may come to open explanations.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Oh, be sensible, Maurice, and think of your future. Try

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to keep him quiet, Henriette. I'll be back in a moment. [Goes

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: out.]

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Well, Maurice, what do you think now of our guilt or

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: guiltlessness?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I have killed nobody. All I did was to talk a lot of

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: nonsense while I was drunk. But it is your crime that comes back,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: and that crime you have grafted on to me.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Oh, that's the tone you talk in now!--Was it not you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: who cursed your own child, and wished the life out of it, and

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: wanted to go away without saying good-bye to anybody? And was it

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: not I who made you visit Marion and show yourself to Madame

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Catherine?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, you are right. Forgive me! You proved yourself more

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: human than I, and the guilt is wholly my own. Forgive me! But all

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the same I am without guilt. Who has tied this net from which I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: can never free myself? Guilty and guiltless; guiltless and yet

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: guilty! Oh, it is driving me mad--Look, now they sit over there

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: and listen to us--And no waiter comes to take our order. I'll go

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: out and order a cup of tea. Do you want anything?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Nothing.

SPEAKER: FIRST DETECTIVE
TEXT: [Goes up to HENRIETTE] Let me look at your

SPEAKER: FIRST DETECTIVE
TEXT: papers.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: How dare you speak to me?

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: Dare? I'll show you!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: What do you mean?

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: It's my job to keep an eye on street-walkers. Yesterday

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: you came here with one man, and today with another. That's as good

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: as walking the streets. And unescorted ladies don't get anything

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: here. So you'd better get out and come along with me.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: My escort will be back in a moment.

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: Yes, and a pretty kind of escort you've got--the kind

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: that doesn't help a girl a bit!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: O God! My mother, my sisters!--I am of good family, I

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: tell you.

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: Yes, first-rate family, I am sure. But you are too well

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: known through the papers. Come along!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Where? What do you mean?

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: Oh, to the Bureau, of course. There you'll get a nice

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: little card and a license that brings you free medical care.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: O Lord Jesus, you don't mean it!

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: [Grabbing HENRIETTE by the arm] Don't I mean it?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Falling on her knees] Save me, Maurice! Help!

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: Shut up, you fool!

SPEAKER: WAITER
TEXT: Gentlemen of that kind are not served here. You just pay

SPEAKER: WAITER
TEXT: and get out! And take the girl along!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Crushed, searches his pocket-book for money] Henriette,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: pay for me, and let us get away from this place. I haven't a sou

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: left.

SPEAKER: WAITER
TEXT: So the lady has to put up for her Alphonse! Alphonse! Do

SPEAKER: WAITER
TEXT: you know what that is?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Looking through her pocket-book] Oh, merciful heavens!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I have no money either!--Why doesn't Adolphe come back?

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: Well, did you ever see such rotters! Get out of here,

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: and put up something as security. That kind of ladies generally

SPEAKER: DETECTIVE
TEXT: have their fingers full of rings.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Can it be possible that we have sunk so low?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Takes off a ring and hands it to the WAITER] The Abbé

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: was right: this is not the work of man.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, it's the devil's!--But if we leave before Adolphe

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: returns, he will think that we have deceived him and run away.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: That would be in keeping with the rest--But we'll go

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: into the river now, won't we?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Takes HENRIETTE by the hand as they walk out together]

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Into the river--yes!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ACT IV

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: FIRST SCENE

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: is shaking the trees and stirring up dead leaves, straws, and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: pieces of paper from the ground.)

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: So you don't want to die?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, I am afraid. I imagine that I am going to be very

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: cold down there in the grave, with only a sheet to cover me and a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: few shavings to lie on. And besides that, it seems to me as if

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: there were still some task waiting for me, but I cannot make out

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: what it is.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: But I can guess what it is.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Tell me.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: It is revenge. You, like me, must have suspected Jeanne

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: and Emile of sending the detectives after me yesterday. Such a

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: revenge on a rival none but a woman could devise.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Exactly what I was thinking. But let me tell you that my

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: suspicions go even further. It seems as if my sufferings during

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: these last few days had sharpened my wits. Can you explain, for

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: instance, why the waiter from the Auberge des Adrets and the head

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: waiter from the Pavilion were not called to testify at the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: hearing?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I never thought of it before. But now I know why. They

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: had nothing to tell, because they had not been listening.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But how could the Commissaire then know what we had been

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: saying?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: He didn't know, but he figured it out. He was guessing,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: and he guessed right. Perhaps he had had to deal with some similar

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: case before.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Or else he concluded from our looks what we had been

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: saying. There are those who can read other people's thoughts--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Adolphe being the dupe, it seemed quite natural that we should

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: have called him an ass. It's the rule, I understand, although it's

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: varied at times by the use of "idiot" instead. But ass was nearer

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: at hand in this case, as we had been talking of carriages and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: triumphal chariots. It is quite simple to figure out a fourth

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: fact, when you have three known ones to start from.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Just think that we have let ourselves be taken in so

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: completely.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That's the result of thinking too well of one's fellow

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: beings. This is all you get out of it. But do you know, _I_

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: suspect somebody else back of the Commissaire, who, by-the-bye,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: must be a full-fledged scoundrel.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: You mean the Abbé, who was taking the part of a private

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: detective.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That's what I mean. That man has to receive all kinds of

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: confessions. And note you: Adolphe himself told us he had been at

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the Church of St. Germain that morning. What was he doing there?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: He was blabbing, of course, and bewailing his fate. And then the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: priest put the questions together for the Commissaire.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Tell me something: do you trust Adolphe?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I trust no human being any longer.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Not even Adolphe?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Him least of all. How could I trust an enemy--a man from

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: whom I have taken away his mistress?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Well, as you were the first one to speak of this, I'll

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: give you some data about our friend. You heard he had returned

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: that medal from London. Do you know his reason for doing so?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: He thinks himself unworthy of it, and he has taken a

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: penitential vow never to receive any kind of distinction.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Can that he possible? But what has he done?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: He has committed a crime of the kind that is not

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: punishable under the law. That's what he gave me to understand

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: indirectly.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: He, too! He, the best one of all, the model man, who

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: never speaks a hard word of anybody and who forgives everything.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Well, there you can see that we are no worse than

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: others. And yet we are being hounded day and night as if devils

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: were after us.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: He, also! Then mankind has not been slandered--But if he

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: has been capable of _one_ crime, then you may expect anything of

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: him. Perhaps it was he who sent the police after you yesterday.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Coming to think of it now, it was he who sneaked away from us when

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: he saw that we were in the papers, and he lied when he insisted

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: that those fellows were not detectives. But, of course, you may

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: expect anything from a deceived lover.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Could he be as mean as that? No, it is impossible,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: impossible!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Why so? If he is a scoundrel?--What were you two talking

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: of yesterday, before I came?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: He had nothing but good to say of you.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That's a lie!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Controlling herself and changing her tone] Listen.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: There is one person on whom you have cast no suspicion whatever--

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: for what reason, I don't know. Have you thought of Madame

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Catherine's wavering attitude in this matter? Didn't she say

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: finally that she believed you capable of anything?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, she did, and that shows what kind of person she is.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: To think evil of other people without reason, you must be a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: villain yourself.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: To think evil of others, you must be a villain

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: yourself.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What do you mean?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: What I said.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Do you mean that I--?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, that's what I mean now! Look here! Did you meet

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: anybody but Marion when you called there yesterday morning?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Why do you ask?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Guess!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Well, as you seem to know--I met Jeanne, too.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Why did you lie to me?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I wanted to spare you.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: And now you want me to believe in one who has been

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: lying to me? No, my boy, now I believe you guilty of that murder.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Wait a moment! We have now reached the place for which my

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: thoughts have been heading all the time, though I resisted as long

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: as possible. It's queer that what lies next to one is seen last of

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: all, and what one doesn't _want_ to believe cannot be believed--Tell

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: me something: where did you go yesterday morning, after we parted

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: in the Bois?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Alarmed] Why?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: You went either to Adolphe--which you couldn't do, as he

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: was attending a lesson--or you went to--Marion!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Now I am convinced that you are the murderer.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And I, that you are the murderess! You alone had an

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: interest in getting the child out of the way--to get rid of the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: rock on the road, as you so aptly put it.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: It was you who said that.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And the one who had an interest in it must have committed

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the crime.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Now, Maurice, we have been running around and around in

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: this tread-mill, scourging each other. Let us quit before we get

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: to the point of sheer madness.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: You have reached that point already.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Don't you think it's time for us to part, before we

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: drive each other insane?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, I think so.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Rising] Good-bye then!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [Turns and comes back to MAURICE] There they are again!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: The dark angels that want to drive us out of the garden.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: And force us back upon each other as if we were chained

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: together.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Or as if we were condemned to lifelong marriage. Are we

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: really to marry? To settle down in the same place? To be able to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: close the door behind us and perhaps get peace at last?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: And shut ourselves up in order to torture each other to

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: death; get behind locks and bolts, with a ghost for marriage

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: portion; you torturing me with the memory of Adolphe, and I

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: getting back at you with Jeanne--and Marion.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Never mention the name of Marion again! Don't you know

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: that she was to be buried today--at this very moment perhaps?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: And you are not there? What does that mean?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It means that both Jeanne and the police have warned me

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: against the rage of the people.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: A coward, too?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: All the vices! How could you ever have cared for me?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Because two days ago you were another person, well

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: worthy of being loved--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And now sunk to such a depth!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: It isn't that. But you are beginning to flaunt bad

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: qualities which are not your own.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But yours?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Perhaps, for when you appear a little worse I feel

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: myself at once a little better.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It's like passing on a disease to save one's self-

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: respect.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: And how vulgar you have become, too!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, I notice it myself, and I hardly recognise myself

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: since that night in the cell. They put in one person and let out

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: another through that gate which separates us from the rest of

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: society. And now I feel myself the enemy of all mankind: I should

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: like to set fire to the earth and dry up the oceans, for nothing

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: less than a universal conflagration can wipe out my dishonour.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I had a letter from my mother today. She is the widow

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: of a major in the army, well educated, with old-fashioned ideas of

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: honour and that kind of thing. Do you want to read the letter? No,

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: you don't!--Do you know that I am an outcast? My respectable

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: acquaintances will have nothing to do with me, and if I show

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: myself on the streets alone the police will take me. Do you

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: realise now that we have to get married?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: We despise each other, and yet we have to marry: that is

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: hell pure and simple! But, Henriette, before we unite our

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: destinies you must tell me your secret, so that we may be on more

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: equal terms.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: All right, I'll tell you. I had a friend who got into

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: trouble--you understand. I wanted to help her, as her whole future

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: was at stake--and she died!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That was reckless, but one might almost call it noble,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: too.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: You say so now, but the next time you lose your temper

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: you will accuse me of it.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, I won't. But I cannot deny that it has shaken my

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: faith in you and that it makes me afraid of you. Tell me, is her

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: lover still alive, and does he know to what extent you were

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: responsible?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: He was as guilty as I.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And if his conscience should begin to trouble him--such

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: things do happen--and if he should feel inclined to confess: then

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: you would be lost.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I know it, and it is this constant dread which has made

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: me rush from one dissipation to another--so that I should never

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: have time to wake up to full consciousness.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And now you want me to take my marriage portion out of

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: your dread. That's asking a little too much.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: But when I shared the shame of Maurice the murderer--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Oh, let's come to an end with it!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, the end is not yet, and I'll not let go my hold

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: until I have put you where you belong. For you can't go around

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: thinking yourself better than I am.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: So you want to fight me then? All right, as you please!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: A fight on life and death!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: The garden is to be closed. "Cursed is the ground for thy

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: sake; thorns and thistles shall it bring forth to thee."

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: "And the Lord God said unto the woman--"

SPEAKER: A GUARD
TEXT: [In uniform, speaking very politely] Sorry, but the

SPEAKER: A GUARD
TEXT: garden has to be closed.

SPEAKER: A GUARD
TEXT: SECOND SCENE

SPEAKER: A GUARD
TEXT: entries into an account book. ADOLPHE and HENRIETTE are seated at

SPEAKER: A GUARD
TEXT: a table.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [Calmly and kindly] But if I give you my final assurance

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that I didn't run away, but that, on the contrary, I thought you

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: had played me false, this ought to convince you.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: But why did you fool us by saying that those fellows

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: were not policemen?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I didn't think myself that they were, and then I wanted

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to reassure you.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: When you say it, I believe you. But then you must also

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: believe me, if I reveal my innermost thoughts to you.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Go on.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: But you mustn't come back with your usual talk of

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: fancies and delusions.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You seem to have reason to fear that I may.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I fear nothing, but I know you and your scepticism--

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Well, and then you mustn't tell this to anybody--promise me!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I promise.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Now think of it, although I must say it's something

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: terrible: I have partial evidence that Maurice is guilty, or at

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: least, I have reasonable suspicions--

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You don't mean it!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Listen, and judge for yourself. When Maurice left me in

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: the Bois, he said he was going to see Marion alone, as the mother

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: was out. And now I have discovered afterward that he did meet the

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: mother. So that he has been lying to me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: That's possible, and his motive for doing so may have

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: been the best, but how can anybody conclude from it that he is

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: guilty of a murder?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Can't you see that?--Don't you understand?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Not at all.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Because you don't want to!--Then there is nothing left

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: for me but to report him, and we'll see whether he can prove an

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: alibi.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Henriette, let me tell you the grim truth. You, like he,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: have reached the border line of--insanity. The demons of distrust

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: have got hold of you, and each of you is using his own sense of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: partial guilt to wound the other with. Let me see if I can make a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: straight guess: he has also come to suspect you of killing his

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: child?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, he's mad enough to do so.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You call his suspicions mad, but not your own.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: You have first to prove the contrary, or that I suspect

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: him unjustly.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Yes, that's easy. A new autopsy has proved that Marion

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: died of a well-known disease, the queer name of which I cannot

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: recall just now.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Is it true?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: The official report is printed in today's paper.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I don't take any stock in it. They can make up that

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: kind of thing.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Beware, Henriette--or you may, without knowing it, pass

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: across that border line. Beware especially of throwing out

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: accusations that may put you into prison. Beware! [He places his

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: hand on her head] You hate Maurice?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Beyond all bounds!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: When love turns into hatred, it means that it was tainted

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: from the start.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [In a quieter mood] What am I to do? Tell me, you who

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: are the only one that understands me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: But you don't want any sermons.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Have you nothing else to offer me?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Nothing else. But they have helped me.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Preach away then!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Try to turn your hatred against yourself. Put the knife

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to the evil spot in yourself, for it is there that _your_ trouble

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: roots.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Explain yourself.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Part from Maurice first of all, so that you cannot nurse

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: your qualms of conscience together. Break off your career as an

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: artist, for the only thing that led you into it was a craving for

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: freedom and fun--as they call it. And you have seen now how much

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: fun there is in it. Then go home to your mother.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Never!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Some other place then.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: I suppose you know, Adolphe, that I have guessed your

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: secret and why you wouldn't accept the prize?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Oh, I assumed that you would understand a half-told

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: story.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Well--what did you do to get peace?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: What I have suggested: I became conscious of my guilt,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: repented, decided to turn over a new leaf, and arranged my life

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: like that of a penitent.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: How can you repent when, like me, you have no

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: conscience? Is repentance an act of grace bestowed on you as faith

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: is?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Everything is a grace, but it isn't granted unless you

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: seek it--Seek!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: But don't wait beyond the allotted time, or you may

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: harden yourself until you tumble down into the irretrievable.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: [After a pause] Is conscience fear of punishment?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: No, it is the horror inspired in our better selves by the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: misdeeds of our lower selves.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Then I must have a conscience also?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Of course you have, but--

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: HENRIETTE, Tell me, Adolphe, are you what they call religious?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Not the least bit.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: It's all so queer--What is religion?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Frankly speaking, I don't know! And I don't think anybody

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: else can tell you. Sometimes it appears to me like a punishment,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: for nobody becomes religious without having a bad conscience.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, it is a punishment. Now I know what to do.

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Good-bye, Adolphe!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You'll go away from here?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes, I am going--to where you said. Good-bye my friend!

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Good-bye, Madame Catherine!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Have you to go in such a hurry?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Do you want me to go with you?

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: No, it wouldn't do. I am going alone, alone as I came

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: here, one day in Spring, thinking that I belonged where I don't

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: belong, and believing there was something called freedom, which

SPEAKER: HENRIETTE
TEXT: does not exist. Good-bye! [Goes out.]

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. I hope that lady never comes back, and I wish she

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: had never come here at all!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Who knows but that she may have had some mission to fill

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: here? And at any rate she deserves pity, endless pity.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. I don't, deny it, for all of us deserve that.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: And she has even done less wrong than the rest of us.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. That's possible, but not probable.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You are always so severe, Madame Catherine. Tell me: have

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: you never done anything wrong?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. [Startled] Of course, as I am a sinful human creature.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: But if you have been on thin ice and fallen in, you have a right to

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: tell others to keep away. And you may do so without being held severe

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: or uncharitable. Didn't I say to Monsieur Maurice the moment that lady

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: entered here: Look out! Keep away! And he didn't, and so he fell in. Just

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: like a naughty, self-willed child. And when a man acts like that he has

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: to have a spanking, like any disobedient youngster.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Well, hasn't he had his spanking?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Yes, but it does not seem to have been enough, as

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: he is still going around complaining.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: That's a very popular interpretation of the whole

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: intricate question.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Oh, pish! You do nothing but philosophise about

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: your vices, and while you are still at it the police come along

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: and solve the riddle. Now please leave me alone with my accounts!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: There's Maurice now.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Yes, God bless him!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Enters, his face very flushed, and takes a seat near

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ADOLPHE] Good evening.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Well, how's everything with you?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Oh, beginning to clear up.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: [Hands him a newspaper, which MAURICE does not take] So

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: you have read the paper?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, I don't read the papers any longer. There's nothing

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: but infamies in them.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: But you had better read it first--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, I won't! It's nothing but lies--But listen: I have

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: found a new clue. Can you guess who committed that murder?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Nobody, nobody!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Do you know where Henriette was during that quarter hour

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: when the child was left alone?--She was _there_! And it is she who

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: has done it!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: You are crazy, man.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Not I, but Henriette, is crazy. She suspects me and has

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: threatened to report me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Henriette was here a while ago, and she used the self-

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: same words as you. Both of you are crazy, for it has been proved

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: by a second autopsy that the child died from a well-known disease,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the name of which I have forgotten.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It isn't true!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: That's what she said also. But the official report is

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: printed in the paper.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: A report? Then they have made it up!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: And that's also what she said. The two of you are

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: suffering from the same mental trouble. But with her I got far

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: enough to make her realise her own condition.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Where did she go?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: She went far away from here to begin a new life.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Hm, hm!--Did you go to the funeral?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I did.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Well?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Well, Jeanne seemed resigned and didn't have a hard word

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to say about you.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: She is a good woman.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Why did you desert her then?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Because I _was_ crazy--blown up with pride especially--and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: then we had been drinking champagne--

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Can you understand now why Jeanne wept when you drank

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: champagne?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, I understand now--And for that reason I have already

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: written to her and asked her to forgive me--Do you think she will

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: forgive me?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I think so, for it's not like her to hate anybody.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Do you think she will forgive me completely, so that she

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: will come back to me?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Well, I don't know about _that_. You have shown yourself so

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: poor in keeping faith that it is doubtful whether she will trust

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: her fate to you any longer.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But I can feel that her fondness for me has not ceased,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: and I know she will come back to me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: How can you know that? How can you believe it? Didn't you

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: even suspect her and that decent brother of hers of having sent

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the police after Henriette out of revenge?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But I don't believe it any longer--that is to say, I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: guess that fellow Emile is a pretty slick customer.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Now look here! What are you saying of Monsieur

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: Emile? Of course, he is nothing but a workman, but if everybody

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: kept as straight as he--There is no flaw in him, but a lot of

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: sense and tact.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: [Enters] Monsieur Gérard?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That's me.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Pardon me, but I have something to say to you in private.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Go right on. We are all friends here.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: [With a glance at the ABBÉ] Perhaps after--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Never mind. The Abbé is also a friend, although he and I

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: differ.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: You know who I am, Monsieur Gérard? My sister has asked me

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: to give you this package as an answer to your letter.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: And now I have only to add, seeing as I am in a way my

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: sister's guardian, that, on her behalf as well as my own, I

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: acknowledge you free of all obligations, now when the natural tie

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: between you does not exist any longer.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But you must have a grudge against me?

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Must I? I can't see why. On the other hand, I should like

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: to have a declaration from you, here in the presence of your

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: friends, that you don't think either me or my sister capable of

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: such a meanness as to send the police after Mademoiselle

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: Henriette.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: I wish to take back what I said, and I offer you my

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: apology, if you will accept it.

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: It is accepted. And I wish all of you a good evening. [Goes

SPEAKER: EMILE
TEXT: out.]

SPEAKER: EVERYBODY
TEXT: Good evening!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: The tie and the gloves which Jeanne gave me for the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: opening night of my play, and which I let Henrietta throw into the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: fireplace. Who can have picked them up? Everything is dug up;

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: everything comes back!--And when she gave them to me in the

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: cemetery, she said she wanted me to look fine and handsome, so

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: that other people would like me also--And she herself stayed at

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: home--This hurt her too deeply, and well it might. I have no right

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: to keep company with decent human beings. Oh, have I done this?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Scoffed at a gift coming from a good heart; scorned a sacrifice

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: offered to my own welfare. This was what I threw away in order to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: get--a laurel that is lying on the rubbish heap, and a bust that

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: would have belonged in the pillory--Abbé, now I come over to you.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Welcome!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Give me the word that I need.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Do you expect me to contradict your self-accusations and

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: inform you that you have done nothing wrong?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Speak the right word!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. With your leave, I'll say then that I have found your

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: behaviour just as abominable as you have found it yourself.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What can I do, what can I do, to get out of this?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. You know as well as I do.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: No, I know only that I am lost, that my life is spoiled,

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: my career cut off, my reputation in this world ruined forever.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. And so you are looking for a new existence in some better

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: world, which you are now beginning to believe in?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, that's it.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. You have been living in the flesh and you want now to live

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: in the spirit. Are you then so sure that this world has no more

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: attractions for you?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: None whatever! Honour is a phantom; gold, nothing but dry

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: leaves; women, mere intoxicants. Let me hide myself behind your

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: consecrated walls and forget this horrible dream that has filled

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: two days and lasted two eternities.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. All right! But this is not the place to go into the matter

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: more closely. Let us make an appointment for this evening at nine

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: o'clock in the Church of St. Germain. For I am going to preach to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the inmates of St. Lazare, and that may be your first step along

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: the hard road of penitence.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Penitence?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
