TEXT: ABBÉ. Well, didn't you wish--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: Yes, yes!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Then we have vigils between midnight and two o'clock.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: That will be splendid!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Give me your hand that you will not look back.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Rising, holds out his hand] Here is my hand, and my will

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: goes with it.

SPEAKER: SERVANT GIRL
TEXT: [Enters from the kitchen] A telephone call for

SPEAKER: SERVANT GIRL
TEXT: Monsieur Maurice.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: From whom?

SPEAKER: SERVANT GIRL
TEXT: From the theatre.

SPEAKER: SERVANT GIRL
TEXT: ABBÉ. [To the SERVANT GIRL] Find out what it is.

SPEAKER: SERVANT GIRL
TEXT: They want to know if Monsieur Maurice is going to

SPEAKER: SERVANT GIRL
TEXT: attend the performance tonight.

SPEAKER: SERVANT GIRL
TEXT: ABBÉ. [To MAURICE, who is trying to get away] No, I won't let you

SPEAKER: SERVANT GIRL
TEXT: go.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: What performance is that?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Why don't you read the paper?

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE and the ABBÉ. He hasn't read the paper?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It's all lies and slander. [To the SERVANT GIRL] Tell

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: them that I am engaged for this evening: I am going to church.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: As you don't want to read the paper, I shall have to tell

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: you that your play has been put on again, now when you are

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: exonerated. And your literary friends have planned a demonstration

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: for this evening in recognition of your indisputable talent.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: It isn't true.

SPEAKER: EVERYBODY
TEXT: It is true.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [After a pause] I have not deserved it!

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Good!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: And furthermore, Maurice--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Hiding his face in his hands] Furthermore!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. One hundred thousand francs! Do you see now that

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: they come back to you? And the villa outside the city. Everything

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: is coming back except Mademoiselle Henriette.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: ABBÉ. [Smiling] You ought to take this matter a little more

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: seriously, Madame Catherine.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Oh, I cannot--I just can't keep serious any

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: longer!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: with her handkerchief.]

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Say, Maurice, the play begins at eight.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. But the church services are at nine.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Maurice!

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. Let us hear what the end is going to be, Monsieur

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: Maurice.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Loose him, Abbé!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. No, it is not for me to loose or bind. He must do that

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: himself.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: [Rising] Well, I go with the Abbé.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. No, my young friend. I have nothing to give you but a

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: scolding, which you can give yourself. And you owe a duty to

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: yourself and to your good name. That you have got through with

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: this as quickly as you have is to me a sign that you have suffered

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: your punishment as intensely as if it had lasted an eternity. And

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: when Providence absolves you there is nothing for me to add.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: But why did the punishment have to be so hard when I was

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: innocent?

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Hard? Only two days! And you were not innocent. For we have

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: to stand responsible for our thoughts and words and desires also.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: And in your thought you became a murderer when your evil self

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: wished the life out of your child.

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: You are right. But my decision is made. To-night I will

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: meet you at the church in order to have a reckoning with myself--

SPEAKER: MAURICE
TEXT: but to-morrow evening I go to the theatre.

SPEAKER: MME
TEXT: CATHERINE. A good solution, Monsieur Maurice.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Yes, that is the solution. Whew!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ABBÉ. Yes, so it is!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: MISS JULIA

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: INTRODUCTION

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: The volume containing the translation of "There Are Crimes and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Crimes" had barely reached the public when word came across the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ocean that August Strindberg had ended his long fight with life.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: His family had long suspected some serious organic trouble. Early

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in the year, when lie had just recovered from an illness of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: temporary character, their worst fears became confirmed. An

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: examination disclosed a case of cancer in the stomach, and the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: disease progressed so rapidly that soon all hope of recovery was

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: out of the question. On May 14, 1912, Strindberg died.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: With his death peace came in more senses than one. All the fear and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: hatred which he had incurred by what was best as well as worst in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: him seemed to be laid at rest with his own worn-out body. The love

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and the admiration which he had son in far greater measure were

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: granted unchecked expression. His burial, otherwise as simple as he

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: himself had prescribed, was a truly national event. At the grave of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the arch-rebel appeared a royal prince as official representative

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of the reigning house, the entire cabinet, and numerous members of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the Riksdag. Thousands of men and women representing the best of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Sweden's intellectual and artistic life went to the cemetery,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: though the hour of the funeral was eight o'clock in the morning. It

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: was an event in which the masses and the classes shared a common

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: sorrow, the standards of student organizations mingling with the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: banners of labour unions. And not only the capital, but the whole

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: country, observed the day as one of mourning.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: A thought frequently recurring in the comment passed on Strindberg's

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: death by the European press was that, in some mysterious manner,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: he, more than any other writer, appeared to be the incarnation of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the past century, with its nervous striving after truth, its fear

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of being duped, and its fretting dread that evolution and progress

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: might prove antagonistic terms. And at that simple grave in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Stockholm more than one bareheaded spectator must have heard the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: gravel rattle on the coffin-lid with a feeling that not only a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: great individual, but a whole human period--great in spite of all

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: its weaknesses--was being laid away for ever.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Among more than half a hundred plays produced by Strindberg during

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: his lifetime, none has won such widespread attention as "Miss

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Julia," both on account of its masterful construction and its

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: gripping theme. Whether liking or disliking it, critics have

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: repeatedly compared it with Ibsen's "Ghosts," and not always to the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: advantage of the latter work. It represents, first of all, its

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: author's most determined and most daring endeavour to win the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: modern stage for Naturalism. If he failed in this effort, it must

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: be recalled to his honour that he was among the first to proclaim

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: his own failure and to advocate the seeking of new paths. When the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: work was still hot from his hands, however, he believed in it with

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: all the fervour of which his spirit was capable, and to bring home

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: its lesson the more forcibly, he added a preface, a sort of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: dramatic creed, explaining just what he had tried to do, and why.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: This preface, which has become hardly less famous than the play

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: itself, is here, as I believe, for the first time rendered into

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: English. The acuteness and exhaustiveness of its analysis serves

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: not only to make it a psychological document of rare value, but

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: also to save me much of the comment which without it might be

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: deemed needful.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Years later, while engaged in conducting a theatre for the exclusive

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: performance of his own plays at Stockholm, Strindberg formulated a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: new dramatic creed--that of his mystical period, in which he was

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: wont to sign himself "the author of 'Gustavus Vasa,' 'The Dream

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Play,' 'The Last Knight,' etc." It took the form of a pamphlet

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: entitled "A Memorandum to the Members of the Intimate Theatre from

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the Stage Director" (Stockholm, 1908). There he gave the following

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: data concerning "Miss Julia," and the movement which that play

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: helped to start:

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: "In the '80's the new time began to extend its demands for reform

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to the stage also. Zola declared war against the French comedy,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: with its Brussels carpets, its patent-leather shoes and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: patent-leather themes, and its dialogue reminding one of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: questions and answers of the Catechism. In 1887 Antoine opened his

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Théâtre Libre at Paris, and 'Thérèse Raquin,' although nothing but

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: an adapted novel, became the dominant model. It was the powerful

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: theme and the concentrated form that showed innovation, although

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the unity of time was not yet observed, and curtain falls were

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: retained. It was then I wrote my dramas: 'Miss Julia,' 'The

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Father,' and 'Creditors.'

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: "'Miss Julia,' which was equipped with a now well-known preface,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: was staged by Antoine, but not until 1892 or 1893, having previously

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: been played by the Students' Association of the Copenhagen

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: University in 1888 or 1889. In the spring of 1893 'Creditors' was

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: put on at the Théâtre L'OEuvre, in Paris, and in the fall of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: same year 'The Father' was given at the same theatre, with Philippe

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Garnier in the title part.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: "But as early as 1889 the Freie Bühne had been started at Berlin,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and before 1893 all three of my dramas had been performed. 'Miss

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Julia' was preceded by a lecture given by Paul Schlenther, now

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: director of the Hofburg Theater at Vienna. The principal parts were

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: played by Rosa Bertens, Emanuel Reicher, Rittner and Jarno. And

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Sigismund Lautenburg, director of the Residenz Theater, gave more

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: than one hundred performances of 'Creditors.'

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: "Then followed a period of comparative silence, and the drama sank

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: back into the old ruts, until, with the beginning of the new

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: century, Reinhardt opened his Kleines Theater. There I was played

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: from the start, being represented by the long one-act drama 'The

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Link,' as well as by 'Miss Julia' (with Eysoldt in the title part),

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and 'There Are Crimes and Crimes.'"

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: He went on to tell how one European city after another had got its

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: "Little," or "Free," or "Intimate" theatre. And had he known of it,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: he might have added that the promising venture started by Mr.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Winthrop Ames at New York comes as near as any one of its earlier

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: rivals in the faithful embodiment of those theories which, with

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Promethean rashness, he had flung at the head of a startled world in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: 1888. For the usual thing has happened: what a quarter-century ago

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: seemed almost ludicrous in its radicalism belongs to-day to the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: established traditions of every progressive stage.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Had Strindberg been content with his position of 1888, many honours

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: now withheld might have fallen to his share. But like Ibsen, he was

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: first and last--and to the very last!--an innovator, a leader of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: human thought and human endeavour. And so it happened that when the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: rest thought to have overtaken him, he had already hurried on to a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: more advanced position, heedless of the scorn poured on him by

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: those to whom "consistency" is the foremost of all human virtues.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Three years before his death we find him writing as follows in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: another pamphlet "An Open Letter to the Intimate Theatre,"

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Stockholm, 1909--of the position once assumed so proudly and so

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: confidently by himself:

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: "As the Intimate Theatre counts its inception from the successful

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: performance of 'Miss Julia' in 1900, it was quite natural that the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: young director (August Falck) should feel the influence of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Preface, which recommended a search for actuality. But that was

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: twenty years ago, and although I do not feel the need of attacking

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: myself in this connection, I cannot but regard all that pottering

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: with stage properties as useless."

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: It has been customary in this country to speak of the play now

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: presented to the public as "Countess Julie." The noble title is, of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: course, picturesque, but incorrect and unwarranted. It is, I fear,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: another outcome of that tendency to exploit the most sensational

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: elements in Strindberg's art which has caused somebody to translate

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the name of his first great novel as "The Scarlet Room,"--instead

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of simply "The Red Room,"--thus hoping to connect it in the reader's

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: mind with the scarlet woman of the Bible.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In Sweden, a countess is the wife or widow of a count. His daughter

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: is no more a countess than is the daughter of an English earl. Her

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: title is that of "Fröken," which corresponds exactly to the German

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: "Fräulein" and the English "Miss." Once it was reserved for the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: young women of the nobility. By an agitation which shook all Sweden

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: with mingled fury and mirth, it became extended to all unmarried

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: women.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: The French form of _Miss Julia's_ Christian name is, on the other

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: hand, in keeping with the author's intention, aiming at an

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: expression of the foreign sympathies and manners which began to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: characterize the Swedish nobility in the eighteenth century, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: which continued to assert themselves almost to the end of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: nineteenth. But in English that form would not have the same

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: significance, and nothing in the play makes its use imperative. The

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: valet, on the other hand, would most appropriately be named _Jean_

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: both in England and here, and for that reason I have retained this

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: form of his name.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Almost every one translating from the Scandinavian languages

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: insists on creating a difficulty out of the fact that the three

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: northern nations--like the Germans and the French--still use the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: second person singular of the personal pronoun to indicate a closer

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: degree of familiarity. But to translate the Swedish "du" with the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: English "thou" is as erroneous as it is awkward. Tytler laid down

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: his "Principles of Translation" in 1791--and a majority of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: translators are still unaware of their existence. Yet it ought to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: seem self-evident to every thinking mind that idiomatic

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: equivalence, not verbal identity, must form the basis of a good and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: faithful translation. When an English mother uses "you" to her

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: child, she establishes thereby the only rational equivalent for the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: "du" used under similar circumstances by her Swedish sister.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Nobody familiar with the English language as it actually springs

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: from the lips of living men and women can doubt that it offers ways

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of expressing varying shades of intimacy no less effective than any

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: found in the Swedish tongue. Let me give an illustration from the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: play immediately under discussion. Returning to the stage after the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ballet scene, _Jean_ says to _Miss Julia_: "I love you--can you

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: doubt it?" And her reply, literally, is: "You?--Say thou!" I have

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: merely made him say: "Can you doubt it, Miss Julia?" and her

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: answer: "Miss?--Call me Julia!" As that is just what would happen

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: under similar circumstances among English-speaking people, I

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: contend that not a whit of the author's meaning or spirit has been

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: lost in this translation.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: If ever a play was written for the stage, it is this one. And on

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the stage there is nothing to take the place of the notes and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: introductory explanations that so frequently encumber the printed

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: volume. On the stage all explanations must lie within the play

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: itself, and so they should in the book also, I believe. The

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: translator is either an artist or a man unfit for his work. As an

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: artist he must have a courage that cannot even be cowed by his

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: reverence for the work of a great creative genius. If, mistakenly,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: he revere the letter of that work instead of its spirit, then he

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: will reduce his own task to mere literary carpentry, and from his

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: pen will spring not a living form, like the one he has been set to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: transplant, but only a death mask!

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: AUTHOR'S PREFACE

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Like almost all other art, that of the stage has long seemed to me

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: a sort of _Biblia Pauperum_, or a Bible in pictures for those who

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: cannot read what is written or printed. And in the same way the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: playwright has seemed to me a lay preacher spreading the thoughts

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of his time in a form so popular that the middle classes, from

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: which theatrical audiences are mainly drawn, can know what is being

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: talked about without troubling their brains too much. For this

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: reason the theatre has always served as a grammar-school to young

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: people, women, and those who have acquired a little knowledge, all

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of whom retain the capacity for deceiving themselves and being

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: deceived--which means again that they are susceptible to illusions

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: produced by the suggestions of the author. And for the same reason

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I have had a feeling that, in our time, when the rudimentary,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: incomplete thought processes operating through our fancy seem to be

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: developing into reflection, research, and analysis, the theatre

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: might stand on the verge of being abandoned as a decaying form, for

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the enjoyment of which we lack the requisite conditions. The

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: prolonged theatrical crisis now prevailing throughout Europe speaks

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in favour of such a supposition, as well as the fact that, in the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: civilised countries producing the greatest thinkers of the age,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: namely, England and Germany, the drama is as dead as are most of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the other fine arts.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In some other countries it has, however, been thought possible to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: create a new drama by filling the old forms with the contents of a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: new time. But, for one thing, there has not been time for the new

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: thoughts to become so popularized that the public might grasp the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: questions raised; secondly, minds have been so inflamed by party

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: conflicts that pure and disinterested enjoyment has been excluded

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: from places where one's innermost feelings are violated and the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: tyranny of an applauding or hissing majority is exercised with the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: openness for which the theatre gives a chance; and, finally, there

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: has been no new form devised for the new contents, and the new wine

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: has burst the old bottles.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In the following drama I have not tried to do anything new--for

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that cannot be done--but I have tried to modernize the form in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: accordance with the demands which I thought the new men of a new

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: time might be likely to make on this art. And with such a purpose

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in view, I have chosen, or surrendered myself to, a theme that

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: might well be said to lie outside the partisan strife of the day:

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: for the problem of social ascendancy or decline, of higher or

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: lower, of better or worse, of men or women, is, has been, and will

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: be of lasting interest. In selecting this theme from real life, as

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: it was related to me a number of years ago, when the incident

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: impressed me very deeply, I found it suited to a tragedy, because

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: it can only make us sad to see a fortunately placed individual

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: perish, and this must be the case in still higher degree when we

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: see an entire family die out. But perhaps a time will arrive when

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: we have become so developed, so enlightened, that we can remain

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: indifferent before the spectacle of life, which now seems so

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: brutal, so cynical, so heartless; when we have closed up those

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: lower, unreliable instruments of thought which we call feelings,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and which have been rendered not only superfluous but harmful by

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the final growth of our reflective organs.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: The fact that the heroine arouses our pity depends only on our

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: weakness in not being able to resist the sense of fear that the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: same fate could befall ourselves. And yet it is possible that a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: very sensitive spectator might fail to find satisfaction in this

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: kind of pity, while the man believing in the future might demand

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: some positive suggestion for the abolition of evil, or, in other

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: words, some kind of programme. But, first of all, there is no

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: absolute evil. That one family perishes is the fortune of another

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: family, which thereby gets a chance to rise. And the alternation of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ascent and descent constitutes one of life's main charms, as

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: fortune is solely determined by comparison. And to the man with a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: programme, who wants to remedy the sad circumstance that the hawk

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: eats the dove, and the flea eats the hawk, I have this question to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: put: why should it be remedied? Life is not so mathematically

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: idiotic that it lets only the big eat the small, but it happens

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: just as often that the bee kills the lion, or drives it to madness

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: at least.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: That my tragedy makes a sad impression on many is their own fault.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: When we grow strong as were the men of the first French revolution,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: then we shall receive an unconditionally good and joyful impression

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: from seeing the national forests rid of rotting and superannuated

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: trees that have stood too long in the way of others with equal

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: right to a period of free growth--an impression good in the same

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: way as that received from the death of one incurably diseased.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Not long ago they reproached my tragedy "The Father" with being too

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: sad--just as if they wanted merry tragedies. Everybody is clamouring

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: arrogantly for "the joy of life," and all theatrical managers are

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: giving orders for farces, as if the joy of life consisted in being

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: silly and picturing all human beings as so many sufferers from St.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Vitus' dance or idiocy. I find the joy of life in its violent and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: cruel struggles, and my pleasure lies in knowing something and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: learning something. And for this reason I have selected an unusual

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: but instructive case--an exception, in a word--but a great

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: exception, proving the rule, which, of course, will provoke all

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: lovers of the commonplace. And what also will offend simple brains

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: is that my action cannot be traced back to a single motive, that

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the view-point is not always the same. An event in real life--and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: this discovery is quite recent--springs generally from a whole

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: series of more or less deep-lying motives, but of these the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: spectator chooses as a rule the one his reason can master most

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: easily, or else the one reflecting most favourably on his power of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: reasoning. A suicide is committed. Bad business, says the merchant.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Unrequited love, say the ladies. Sickness, says the sick man.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Crushed hopes, says the shipwrecked. But now it may be that the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: motive lay in all or none of these directions. It is possible that

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the one who is dead may have hid the main motive by pushing forward

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: another meant to place his memory in a better light.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In explanation of _Miss Julia's_ sad fate I have suggested many

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: factors: her mother's fundamental instincts; her father's mistaken

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: upbringing of the girl; her own nature, and the suggestive influence

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of her fiancé on a weak and degenerate brain; furthermore, and more

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: directly: the festive mood of the Midsummer Eve; the absence of her

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: father; her physical condition; her preoccupation with the animals;

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the excitation of the dance; the dusk of the night; the strongly

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: aphrodisiacal influence of the flowers; and lastly the chance

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: forcing the two of them together in a secluded room, to which must

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: be added the aggressiveness of the excited man.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Thus I have neither been one-sidedly physiological nor one-sidedly

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: psychological in my procedure. Nor have I merely delivered a moral

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: preachment. This multiplicity of motives I regard as praiseworthy

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: because it is in keeping with the views of our own time. And if

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: others have done the same thing before me, I may boast of not being

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the sole inventor of my paradoxes--as all discoveries are named.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In regard to the character-drawing I may say that I have tried to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: make my figures rather "characterless," and I have done so for

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: reasons I shall now state.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In the course of the ages the word character has assumed many

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: meanings. Originally it signified probably the dominant ground-note

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in the complex mass of the self, and as such it was confused with

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: temperament. Afterward it became the middle-class term for an

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: automaton, so that an individual whose nature had come to a stand

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: still, or who had adapted himself to a certain part in life--who

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: had ceased to grow, in a word--was named a character; while one

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: remaining in a state of development--a skilful navigator on life's

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: river, who did not sail with close-tied sheets, but knew when to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: fall off before the wind and when to luff again--was called lacking

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in character. And he was called so in a depreciatory sense, of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: course, because he was so hard to catch, to classify, and to keep

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: track of. This middle-class notion about the immobility of the soul

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: was transplanted to the stage, where the middle-class element has

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: always held sway. There a character became synonymous with a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: gentleman fixed and finished once for all--one who invariably

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: appeared drunk, jolly, sad. And for the purpose of characterisation

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: nothing more was needed than some physical deformity like a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: clubfoot, a wooden leg, a red nose; or the person concerned was

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: made to repeat some phrase like "That's capital!" or "Barkis is

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: willin'," or something of that kind. This manner of regarding human

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: beings as homogeneous is preserved even by the great Molière.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: _Harpagon_ is nothing but miserly, although _Harpagon_ might as

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: well have been at once miserly and a financial genius, a fine

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: father, and a public-spirited citizen. What is worse yet, his

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: "defect" is of distinct advantage to his son-in-law and daughter,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: who are his heirs, and for that reason should not find fault with

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: him, even if they have to wait a little for their wedding. I do not

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: believe, therefore, in simple characters on the stage. And the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: summary judgments of the author upon men--this one stupid, and that

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: one brutal, this one jealous, and that one stingy--should be

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: challenged by the naturalists, who know the fertility of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: soul-complex, and who realise that "vice" has a reverse very much

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: resembling virtue.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Because they are modern characters, living in a period of transition

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: more hysterically hurried than its immediate predecessor at least,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I have made my figures vacillating, out of joint, torn between the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: old and the new. And I do not think it unlikely that, through

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: newspaper reading and overheard conversations, modern ideas may

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: have leaked down to the strata where domestic servants belong.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: My souls (or characters) are conglomerates, made up of past and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: present stages of civilisation, scraps of humanity, torn-off pieces

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of Sunday clothing turned into rags--all patched together as is the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: human soul itself. And I have furthermore offered a touch of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: evolutionary history by letting the weaker repeat words stolen from

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the stronger, and by letting different souls accept "ideas"--or

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: suggestions, as they are called--from each other.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: _Miss Julia_ is a modern character, not because the man-hating

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: half-woman may not have existed in all ages, but because now, after

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: her discovery, she has stepped to the front and begun to make a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: noise. The half-woman is a type coming more and more into

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: prominence, selling herself nowadays for power, decorations,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: distinctions, diplomas, as formerly for money, and the type

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: indicates degeneration. It is not a good type, for it does not

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: last, but unfortunately it has the power of reproducing itself and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: its misery through one more generation. And degenerate men seem

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: instinctively to make their selection from this kind of women, so

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that they multiply and produce indeterminate sexes to whom life is

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: a torture. Fortunately, however, they perish in the end, either

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: from discord with real life, or from the irresistible revolt of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: their suppressed instincts, or from foiled hopes of possessing the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: man. The type is tragical, offering us the spectacle of a desperate

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: struggle against nature. It is also tragical as a Romantic

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: inheritance dispersed by the prevailing Naturalism, which wants

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: nothing but happiness: and for happiness strong and sound races are

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: required.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: But _Miss Julia_ is also a remnant of the old military nobility

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: which is now giving way to the new nobility of nerves and brain.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: She is a victim of the discord which a mother's "crime" produces in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: a family, and also a victim of the day's delusions, of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: circumstances, of her defective constitution--all of which may be

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: held equivalent to the old-fashioned fate or universal law. The

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: naturalist has wiped out the idea of guilt, but he cannot wipe out

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the results of an action--punishment, prison, or fear--and for the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: simple reason that they remain without regard to his verdict. For

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: fellow-beings that have been wronged are not so good-natured as

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: those on the outside, who have not been wronged at all, can be

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: without cost to themselves.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Even if, for reasons over which he could have no control, the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: father should forego his vengeance, the daughter would take

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: vengeance upon herself, just as she does in the play, and she would

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: be moved to it by that innate or acquired sense of honour which the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: upper classes inherit--whence? From the days of barbarism, from the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: original home of the Aryans, from the chivalry of the Middle Ages?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: It is beautiful, but it has become disadvantageous to the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: preservation of the race. It is this, the nobleman's _harakiri_--or

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the law of the inner conscience compelling the Japanese to cut open

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: his own abdomen at the insult of another--which survives, though

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: somewhat modified, in the duel, also a privilege of the nobility.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: For this reason the valet, _Jean_, continues to live, but _Miss

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Julia_ cannot live on without honour. In so far as he lacks this

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: life—endangering superstition about honour, the serf takes

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: precedence of the earl, and in all of us Aryans there is something

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of the nobleman, or of Don Quixote, which makes us sympathise with

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the man who takes his own life because he has committed a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: dishonourable deed and thus lost his honour. And we are noblemen to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the extent of suffering from seeing the earth littered with the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: living corpse of one who was once great--yes, even if the one thus

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: fallen should rise again and make restitution by honourable deeds.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: _Jean_, the valet, is of the kind that builds new stock--one in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: whom the differentiation is clearly noticeable. He was a cotter's

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: child, and he has trained himself up to the point where the future

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: gentleman has become visible. He has found it easy to learn, having

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: finely developed senses (smell, taste, vision) and an instinct for

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: beauty besides. He has already risen in the world, and is strong

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: enough not to be sensitive about using other people's services. He

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: has already become a stranger to his equals, despising them as so

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: many outlived stages, but also fearing and fleeing them because

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: they know his secrets, pry into his plans, watch his rise with

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: envy, and look forward to his fall with pleasure. From this

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: relationship springs his dual, indeterminate character, oscillating

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: between love of distinction and hatred of those who have already

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: achieved it. He says himself that he is an aristocrat, and has

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: learned the secrets of good company. He is polished on the outside

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and coarse within. He knows already how to wear the frock-coat with

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ease, but the cleanliness of his body cannot be guaranteed.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: He feels respect for the young lady, but he is afraid of _Christine_,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: who has his dangerous secrets in her keeping. His emotional

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: callousness is sufficient to prevent the night's happenings from

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: exercising a disturbing influence on his plans for the future.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Having at once the slave's brutality and the master's lack of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: squeamishness, he can see blood without fainting, and he can also

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: bend his back under a mishap until able to throw it off. For this

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: reason he will emerge unharmed from the battle, and will probably

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: end his days as the owner of a hotel. And if he does not become a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Roumanian count, his son will probably go to a university, and may

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: even become a county attorney.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Otherwise, he furnishes us with rather significant information as

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to the way in which the lower classes look at life from beneath—-

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that is, when he speaks the truth, which is not often, as he

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: prefers what seems favourable to himself to what is true. When

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: _Miss Julia_ suggests that the lower classes must feel the pressure

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: from above very heavily, _Jean_ agrees with her, of course, because

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: he wants to gain her sympathy. But he corrects himself at once, the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: moment he realises the advantage of standing apart from the herd.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: And _Jean_ stands above _Miss Julia_ not only because his fate is in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ascendancy, but because he is a man. Sexually he is the aristocrat

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: because of his male strength, his more finely developed senses, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: his capacity for taking the initiative. His inferiority depends

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: mainly on the temporary social environment in which he has to live,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and which he probably can shed together with the valet's livery.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: The mind of the slave speaks through his reverence for the count

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: superstition. But he reveres the count principally as a possessor

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of that higher position toward which he himself is striving. And

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: this reverence remains even when he has won the daughter of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: house, and seen that the beautiful shell covered nothing but

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: emptiness.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I don't believe that any love relation in a "higher" sense can

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: spring up between two souls of such different quality. And for this

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: reason I let _Miss Julia_ imagine her love to be protective or

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: commiserative in its origin. And I let _Jean_ suppose that, under

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: different social conditions, he might feel something like real love

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: for her. I believe love to be like the hyacinth, which has to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: strike roots in darkness _before_ it can bring forth a vigorous

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: flower. In this case it shoots up quickly, bringing forth blossom

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and seed at once, and for that reason the plant withers so soon.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: _Christine_, finally, is a female slave, full of servility and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: sluggishness acquired in front of the kitchen fire, and stuffed

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: full of morality and religion that are meant to serve her at once

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: as cloak and scapegoat. Her church-going has for its purpose to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: bring her quick and easy riddance of all responsibility for her

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: domestic thieveries and to equip her with a new stock of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: guiltlessness. Otherwise she is a subordinate figure, and therefore

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: purposely sketched in the same manner as the minister and the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: doctor in "The Father," whom I designed as ordinary human beings,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: like the common run of country ministers and country doctors. And

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: if these accessory characters have seemed mere abstractions to some

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: people, it depends on the fact that ordinary men are to a certain

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: extent impersonal in the exercise of their callings. This means

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that they are without individuality, showing only one side of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: themselves while at work. And as long as the spectator does not

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: feel the need of seeing them from other sides, my abstract

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: presentation of them remains on the whole correct.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In regard to the dialogue, I want to point out that I have departed

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: somewhat from prevailing traditions by not turning my figures into

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: catechists who make stupid questions in order to call forth witty

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: answers. I have avoided the symmetrical and mathematical

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: construction of the French dialogue, and have instead permitted the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: minds to work irregularly as they do in reality, where, during

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: conversation, the cogs of one mind seem more or less haphazardly to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: engage those of another one, and where no topic is fully exhausted.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Naturally enough, therefore, the dialogue strays a good deal as, in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the opening scenes, it acquires a material that later on is worked

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: over, picked up again, repeated, expounded, and built up like the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: theme in a musical composition.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: The plot is pregnant enough, and as, at bottom, it is concerned

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: only with two persons, I have concentrated my attention on these,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: introducing only one subordinate figure, the cook, and keeping the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: unfortunate spirit of the father hovering above and beyond the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: action. I have done this because I believe I have noticed that the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: psychological processes are what interest the people of our own day

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: more than anything else. Our souls, so eager for knowledge, cannot

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: rest satisfied with seeing what happens, but must also learn how it

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: comes to happen! What we want to see are just the wires, the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: machinery. We want to investigate the box with the false bottom,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: touch the magic ring in order to find the suture, and look into the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: cards to discover how they are marked.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In this I have taken for models the monographic novels of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: brothers de Goncourt, which have appealed more to me than any other

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: modern literature.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Turning to the technical side of the composition, I have tried to

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: abolish the division into acts. And I have done so because I have

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: come to fear that our decreasing capacity for illusion might be

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: unfavourably affected by intermissions during which the spectator

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: would have time to reflect and to get away from the suggestive

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: influence of the author-hypnotist. My play will probably last an

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: hour and a half, and as it is possible to listen that length of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: time, or longer, to a lecture, a sermon, or a debate, I have

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: imagined that a theatrical performance could not become fatiguing

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in the same time. As early as 1872, in one of my first dramatic

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: experiments, "The Outlaw," I tried the same concentrated form, but

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: with scant success. The play was written in five acts and wholly

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: completed when I became aware of the restless, scattered effect it

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: produced. Then I burned it, and out of the ashes rose a single,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: well-built act, covering fifty printed pages, and taking hour for

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: its performance. Thus the form of the present play is not new, but

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: it seems to be my own, and changing aesthetical conventions may

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: possibly make it timely.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: My hope is still for a public educated to the point where it can

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: sit through a whole-evening performance in a single act. But that

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: point cannot be reached without a great deal of experimentation. In

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the meantime I have resorted to three art forms that are to provide

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: resting-places for the public and the actors, without letting the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: public escape from the illusion induced. All these forms are

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: subsidiary to the drama. They are the monologue, the pantomime, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the dance, all of them belonging originally to the tragedy of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: classical antiquity. For the monologue has sprung from the monody,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and the chorus has developed into the ballet.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Our realists have excommunicated the monologue as improbable, but

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: if I can lay a proper basis for it, I can also make it seem

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: probable, and then I can use it to good advantage. It is probable,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: for instance, that a speaker may walk back and forth in his room

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: practising his speech aloud; it is probable that an actor may read

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: through his part aloud, that a servant-girl may talk to her cat,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that a mother may prattle to her child, that an old spinster may

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: chatter to her parrot, that a person may talk in his sleep. And in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: order that the actor for once may have a chance to work independently,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and to be free for a moment from the author's pointer, it is better

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that the monologues be not written out, but just indicated. As it

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: matters comparatively little what is said to the parrot or the cat,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: or in one's sleep--because it cannot influence the action--it is

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: possible that a gifted actor, carried away by the situation and the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: mood of the occasion, may improvise such matters better than they

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: could be written by the author, who cannot figure out in advance

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: how much may be said, and how long the talk may last, without

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: waking the public out of their illusions.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: It is well known that, on certain stages, the Italian theatre has

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: returned to improvisation and thereby produced creative actors—

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: who, however, must follow the author's suggestions--and this may be

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: counted a step forward, or even the beginning of a new art form

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that might well be called _productive_.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Where, on the other hand, the monologue would seem unreal, I have

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: used the pantomime, and there I have left still greater scope for

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the actor's imagination--and for his desire to gain independent

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: honours. But in order that the public may not be tried beyond

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: endurance, I have permitted the music--which is amply warranted by

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the Midsummer Eve's dance--to exercise its illusory power while the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: dumb show lasts. And I ask the musical director to make careful

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: selection of the music used for this purpose, so that incompatible

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: moods are not induced by reminiscences from the last musical comedy

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: or topical song, or by folk-tunes of too markedly ethnographical

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: distinction.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: The mere introduction of a scene with a lot of "people" could not

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: have taken the place of the dance, for such scenes are poorly acted

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and tempt a number of grinning idiots into displaying their own

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: smartness, whereby the illusion is disturbed. As the common people

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: do not improvise their gibes, but use ready-made phrases in which

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: stick some double meaning, I have not composed their lampooning

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: song, but have appropriated a little known folk-dance which I

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: personally noted down in a district near Stockholm. The words don't

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: quite hit the point, but hint vaguely at it, and this is

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: intentional, for the cunning (i. e., weakness) of the slave keeps

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: him from any direct attack. There must, then, be no chattering

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: clowns in a serious action, and no coarse flouting at a situation

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that puts the lid on the coffin of a whole family.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: As far as the scenery is concerned, I have borrowed from

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: impressionistic painting its asymmetry, its quality of abruptness,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and have thereby in my opinion strengthened the illusion. Because

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the whole room and all its contents are not shown, there is a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: chance to guess at things--that is, our imagination is stirred into

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: complementing our vision. I have made a further gain in getting rid

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of those tiresome exits by means of doors, especially as stage

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: doors are made of canvas and swing back and forth at the lightest

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: touch. They are not even capable of expressing the anger of an

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: irate _pater familias_ who, on leaving his home after a poor

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: dinner, slams the door behind him "so that it shakes the whole

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: house." (On the stage the house sways.) I have also contented

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: myself with a single setting, and for the double purpose of making

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the figures become parts of their surroundings, and of breaking

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: with the tendency toward luxurious scenery. But having only a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: single setting, one may demand to have it real. Yet nothing is more

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: difficult than to get a room that looks something like a room,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: although the painter can easily enough produce waterfalls and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: flaming volcanoes. Let it go at canvas for the walls, but we might

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: be done with the painting of shelves and kitchen utensils on the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: canvas. We have so much else on the stage that is conventional, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: in which we are asked to believe, that we might at least be spared

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the too great effort of believing in painted pans and kettles.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I have placed the rear wall and the table diagonally across the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: stage in order to make the actors show full face and half profile

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to the audience when they sit opposite each other at the table. In

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the opera "Aïda" I noticed an oblique background, which led the eye

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: out into unseen prospects. And it did not appear to be the result

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of any reaction against the fatiguing right angle.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Another novelty well needed would be the abolition of the foot-lights.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: The light from below is said to have for its purpose to make the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: faces of the actors look fatter. But I cannot help asking: why must

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: all actors be fat in the face? Does not this light from below tend

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to wipe out the subtler lineaments in the lower part of the face,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and especially around the jaws? Does it not give a false appearance

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: to the nose and cast shadows upward over the eyes? If this be not

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: so, another thing is certain: namely, that the eyes of the actors

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: suffer from the light, so that the effective play of their glances

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: is precluded. Coming from below, the light strikes the retina in

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: places generally protected (except in sailors, who have to see the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: sun reflected in the water), and for this reason one observes

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: hardly anything but a vulgar rolling of the eyes, either sideways

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: or upwards, toward the galleries, so that nothing but the white of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the eye shows. Perhaps the same cause may account for the tedious

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: blinking of which especially the actresses are guilty. And when

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: anybody on the stage wants to use his eyes to speak with, no other

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: way is left him but the poor one of staring straight at the public,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: with whom he or she then gets into direct communication outside of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the frame provided by the setting. This vicious habit has, rightly

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: or wrongly, been named "to meet friends." Would it not be possible

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: by means of strong side-lights (obtained by the employment of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: reflectors, for instance) to add to the resources already possessed

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: by the actor? Could not his mimicry be still further strengthened

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: by use of the greatest asset possessed by the face: the play of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: eyes?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: Of course, I have no illusions about getting the actors to play

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: _for_ the public and not _at_ it, although such a change would be

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: highly desirable. I dare not even dream of beholding the actor's

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: back throughout an important scene, but I wish with all my heart

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: that crucial scenes might not be played in the centre of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: proscenium, like duets meant to bring forth applause. Instead, I

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: should like to have them laid in the place indicated by the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: situation. Thus I ask for no revolutions, but only for a few minor

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: modifications. To make a real room of the stage, with the fourth

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: wall missing, and a part of the furniture placed back toward the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: audience, would probably produce a disturbing effect at present.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In wishing to speak of the facial make-up, I have no hope that the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: ladies will listen to me, as they would rather look beautiful than

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: lifelike. But the actor might consider whether it be to his

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: advantage to paint his face so that it shows some abstract type

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: which covers it like a mask. Suppose that a man puts a markedly

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: choleric line between the eyes, and imagine further that some

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: remark demands a smile of this face fixed in a state of continuous

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: wrath. What a horrible grimace will be the result? And how can the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: wrathful old man produce a frown on his false forehead, which is

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: smooth as a billiard ball?

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: In modern psychological dramas, where the subtlest movements of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: soul are to be reflected on the face rather than by gestures and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: noise, it would probably be well to experiment with strong side-light

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: on a small stage, and with unpainted faces, or at least with a

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: minimum of make-up.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: If, in additon, we might escape the visible orchestra, with its

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: disturbing lamps and its faces turned toward the public; if we

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: could have the seats on the main floor (the orchestra or the pit)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: raised so that the eyes of the spectators would be above the knees

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of the actors; if we could get rid of the boxes with their

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: tittering parties of diners; if we could also have the auditorium

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: completely darkened during the performance; and if, first and last,

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: we could have a small stage and a small house: then a new dramatic

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: art might rise, and the theatre might at least become an

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: institution for the entertainment of people with culture. While

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: waiting for this kind of theatre, I suppose we shall have to write

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: for the "ice-box," and thus prepare the repertory that is to come.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: I have made an attempt. If it prove a failure, there is plenty of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: time to try over again.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: MISS JULIA

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: A NATURALISTIC TRAGEDY

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: PERSONS

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: MISS JULIA, aged twenty-five

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: JEAN, a valet, aged thirty

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: CHRISTINE, a cook, aged thirty-five

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: The action takes place on Midsummer Eve, in the kitchen of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: count's country house.

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: MISS JULIA

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: SCENE

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: draperies and hangings. The rear wall runs diagonally across the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: stage, from the left side and away from the spectators. On this

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: wall, to the left, there are two shelves full of utensils made of

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: copper, iron, and tin. The shelves are trimmed with scalloped

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: paper.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: doorway leading to the outside. It has double glass doors, through

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: which are seen a fountain with a cupid, lilac shrubs in bloom, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: the tops of some Lombardy poplars.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: stove built of glazed bricks; also a part of the smoke-hood above

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: it.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: of white pine, with a few chairs about it.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: juniper are scattered on the floor.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: blossoms.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: and the mouthpiece of a speaking-tube appears at the left of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: door.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: has on a dress of light-coloured cotton, which she has covered up

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: with a big kitchen apron.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: riding boots, which he places on the floor in such manner that they

SPEAKER: ADOLPHE
TEXT: remain visible to the spectators.)

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: To-night Miss Julia is crazy again; absolutely crazy.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: So you're back again?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I took the count to the station, and when I came back by the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: barn, I went in and had a dance, and there I saw the young lady

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: leading the dance with the gamekeeper. But when she caught sight of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: me, she rushed right up to me and asked me to dance the ladies'

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: waltz with her. And ever since she's been waltzing like--well, I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: never saw the like of it. She's crazy!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: And has always been, but never the way it's been this

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: last fortnight, since her engagement was broken.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, what kind of a story was that anyhow? He's a fine

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: fellow, isn't he, although he isn't rich? Ugh, but they're so full

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: of notions. [Sits down at the end of the table] It's peculiar

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: anyhow, that a young lady--hm!--would rather stay at home with the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: servants--don't you think?--than go with her father to their

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: relatives!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Oh, I guess she feels sort of embarrassed by that rumpus

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: with her fellow.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Quite likely. But there was some backbone to that man just

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the same. Do you know how it happened, Christine? I saw it,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: although I didn't care to let on.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: No, did you?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Sure, I did. They were in the stable-yard one evening, and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the young lady was training him, as she called it. Do you know what

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: that meant? She made him leap over her horse-whip the way you teach

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: a dog to jump. Twice he jumped and got a cut each time. The third

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: time he took the whip out of her hand and broke it into a thousand

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: bits. And then he got out.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: So that's the way it happened! You don't say!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, that's how that thing happened. Well, Christine, what

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: have you got that's tasty?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [Serves from the pan and puts the plate before Jean] Oh,

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: just some kidney which I cut out of the veal roast.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Smelling the food] Fine! That's my great _délice_. [Feeling

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the plate] But you might have warmed the plate.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Well, if you ain't harder to please than the count

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: himself! [Pulls his hair playfully.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Irritated] Don't pull my hair! You know how sensitive I am.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Well, well, it was nothing but a love pull, you know.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Beer-on Midsummer Eve? No, thank you! Then I have something

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: better myself. [Opens a table-drawer and takes out a bottle of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: claret with yellow cap] Yellow seal, mind you! Give me a glass—-and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you use those with stems when you drink it _pure_.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [Returns to the stove and puts a small pan on the fire]

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Heaven preserve her that gets you for a husband, Mr. Finicky!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, rot! You'd be glad enough to get a smart fellow like me.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And I guess it hasn't hurt you that they call me your beau.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: warms the glass with his hand.] We got this at Dijon. It cost us

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: four francs per litre, not counting the bottle. And there was the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: duty besides. What is it you're cooking--with that infernal smell?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Oh, it's some deviltry the young lady is going to give

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Diana.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You should choose your words with more care, Christine. But

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: why should you be cooking for a bitch on a holiday eve like this?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Is she sick?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Ye-es, she is sick. She's been running around with the

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: gate-keeper's pug--and now's there's trouble--and the young lady

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: just won't hear of it.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: The young lady is too stuck up in some ways and not proud

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: enough in others--just as was the countess while she lived. She was

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: most at home in the kitchen and among the cows, but she would never

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: drive with only one horse. She wore her cuffs till they were dirty,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: but she had to have cuff buttons with a coronet on them. And

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: speaking of the young lady, she doesn't take proper care of herself

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: and her person. I might even say that she's lacking in refinement.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Just now, when she was dancing in the barn, she pulled the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: gamekeeper away from Anna and asked him herself to come and dance

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: with her. We wouldn't act in that way. But that's just how it is:

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: when upper-class people want to demean themselves, then they grow—-

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: mean! But she's splendid! Magnificent! Oh, such shoulders! And--and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: so on!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Oh, well, don't brag too much! I've heard Clara talking,

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: who tends to her dressing.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Pooh, Clara! You're always jealous of each other. I, who have

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: been out riding with her--And then the way she dances!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Say, Jean, won't you dance with me when I'm done?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Of course I will.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Do you promise?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Promise? When I say so, I'll do it. Well, here's thanks for

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the good food. It tasted fine! [Puts the cork back into the bottle.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Appears in the doorway, speaking to somebody on the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: outside] I'll be back in a minute. You go right on in the meantime.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: respectfully.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Enters and goes over to CHRISTINE by the wash-stand] Well,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: is it done yet?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Gallantly] The ladies are having secrets, I believe.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Strikes him in the face with her handkerchief] That's for

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: you, Mr. Pry!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, what a delicious odor that violet has!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [With coquetry] Impudent! So you know something about

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: perfumes also? And know pretty well how to dance--Now don't peep!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Go away!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [With polite impudence] Is it some kind of witches' broth the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: ladies are cooking on Midsummer Eve--something to tell fortunes by

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: and bring out the lucky star in which one's future love is seen?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Sharply] If you can see that, you'll have good eyes,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: indeed! [To CHRISTINE] Put it in a pint bottle and cork it well.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Come and dance a _schottische_ with me now, Jean.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Hesitatingly] I don't want to be impolite, but I had

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: promised to dance with Christine this time—-

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Well, she can get somebody else--can't you, Christine? Won't

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: you let me borrow Jean from you?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: That isn't for me to say. When Miss Julia is so

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: gracious, it isn't for him to say no. You just go along, and be

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: thankful for the honour, too!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Frankly speaking, but not wishing to offend in any way, I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: cannot help wondering if it's wise for Miss Julia to dance twice in

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: succession with the same partner, especially as the people here are

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: not slow in throwing out hints--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Flaring up] What is that? What kind of hints? What do you

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: mean?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Submissively] As you don't want to understand, I have to

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: speak more plainly. It don't look well to prefer one servant to all

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the rest who are expecting to be honoured in the same unusual way--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Prefer! What ideas! I'm surprised! I, the mistress of the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: house, deign to honour this dance with my presence, and when it so

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: happens that I actually want to dance, I want to dance with one who

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: knows how to lead, so that I am not made ridiculous.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: As you command, Miss Julia! I am at your service!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Softened] Don't take it as a command. To-night we should

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: enjoy ourselves as a lot of happy people, and all rank should be

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: forgotten. Now give me your arm. Don't be afraid, Christine! I'll

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: return your beau to you!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: PANTOMIME

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Must be acted as if the actress were really alone in the place.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: When necessary she turns her back to the public. She should not

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: look in the direction of the spectators, and she should not hurry

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: as if fearful that they might become impatient.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: CHRISTINE is alone. A _schottische_ tune played on a violin is

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: heard faintly in the distance.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: While humming the tune, CHRISTINE clears o$ the table after JEAN,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: washes the plate at the kitchen table, wipes it, and puts it away

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: in a cupboard.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Then she takes of her apron, pulls out a small mirror from one of

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: the table-drawers and leans it against the flower jar on the table;

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: lights a tallow candle and heats a hairpin, which she uses to curl

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: her front hair.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Then she goes to the door and stands there listening. Returns to

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: the table. Discovers the handkerchief which MISS JULIA has left

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: behind, picks it up, and smells it, spreads it out absent-mindedly

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: and begins to stretch it, smooth it, fold it up, and so forth.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Enters alone] Crazy, that's what she is! The way she dances!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And the people stand behind the doors and grill at her. What do you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: think of it, Christine?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Oh, she has her time now, and then she is always a

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: little queer like that. But are you going to dance with me now?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You are not mad at me because I disappointed you?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: No!--Not for a little thing like that, you know! And

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: also, I know my place--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Putting his arm around her waist] You are a, sensible girl,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Christine, and I think you'll make a good wife--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Enters and is unpleasantly surprised; speaks with forced

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: gayety] Yes, you are a fine partner--running away from your lady!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: On the contrary, Miss Julia. I have, as you see, looked up

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the one I deserted.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Changing tone] Do you know, there is nobody that dances

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: like you!--But why do you wear your livery on an evening like this?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Take it off at once!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Then I must ask you to step outside for a moment, as my black

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: coat is hanging right here. [Points toward the right and goes in

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: that direction.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Are you bashful on my account? Just to change a coat? Why

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: don't you go into your own room and come back again? Or, you can

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: stay right here, and I'll turn my back on you.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: With your permission, Miss Julia. [Goes further over to the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: right; one of his arms can be seen as he changes his coat.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: JULIA [To CHRISTINE] Are you and Jean engaged, that he's so

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: familiar with you?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Engaged? Well, in a way. We call it that.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Call it?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Well, Miss Julia, you have had a fellow of your own, and--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: We were really engaged--

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: But it didn't come to anything just the same--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: _Très gentil, Monsieur Jean! Très gentil!_

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: _Vous voulez plaisanter, Madame!_

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: _Et vous voulez parler français!_ Where did you learn it?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: In Switzerland, while I worked as _sommelier_ in one of the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: big hotels at Lucerne.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: But you look like a real gentleman in your frock coat!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Charming! [Sits down at the table.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, you flatter me.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Offended] Flatter--you!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: My natural modesty does not allow me to believe that you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: could be paying genuine compliments to one like me, and so I dare

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to assume that you are exaggerating, or, as we call it, flattering.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Where did you learn to use your words like that? You must

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: have been to the theatre a great deal?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: That, too. I have been to a lot of places.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: But you were born in this neighbourhood?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: My father was a cotter on the county attorney's property

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: right by here, and I can recall seeing you as a child, although

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you, of course, didn't notice me.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: No, really!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, and I remember one time in particular--but of that I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: can't speak.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh, yes, do! Why--just for once.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, really, I cannot do it now. Another time, perhaps.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Another time is no time. Is it as bad as that?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: It isn't bad, but it comes a little hard. Look at that one!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: She'll make a pleasant wife. And perhaps she snores, too.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, she doesn't, but she talks in her sleep.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Cynically] How do you know?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Insolently] I have heard it.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Why don't you sit down?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: It wouldn't be proper in your presence.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: But if I order you to do it?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Then I obey.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Sit down, then!--But wait a moment! Can you give me

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: something to drink first?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I don't know what we have got in the icebox. I fear it is

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: nothing but beer.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And you call that nothing? My taste is so simple that I

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: prefer it to wine.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Takes a bottle of beer from the icebox and opens it; gets a
