SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: glass and a plate from the cupboard, and serves the beer] Allow me!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Thank you. Don't you want some yourself?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I don't care very much for beer, but if it is a command, of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: course--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Command?--I should think a polite gentleman might keep his

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: lady company.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, that's the way it should be. [Opens another bottle and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: takes out a glass.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Drink my health now!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Are you bashful--a big, grown-up man?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Kneels with mock solemnity and raises his glass] To the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: health of my liege lady!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Bravo!--And now you must also kiss my shoe in order to get

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: it just right.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: touches it lightly with his lips.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Excellent! You should have been on the stage.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Rising to his feet] This won't do any longer, Miss Julia.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Somebody might see us.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: What would that matter?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, it would set the people talking--that's all! And if you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: only knew how their tongues were wagging up there a while ago—-

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: What did they have to say? Tell me--Sit down now!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Sits down] I don't want to hurt you, but they were using

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: expressions--which cast reflections of a kind that--oh, you know it

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: yourself! You are not a child, and when a lady is seen alone with a

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: man, drinking--no matter if he's only a servant--and at night-—then--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Then what? And besides, we are not alone. Isn't Christine

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: with us?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes--asleep!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Then I'll wake her. [Rising] Christine, are you asleep?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [In her sleep] Blub-blub-blub-blub!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Christine!--Did you ever see such a sleeper.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [In her sleep] The count's boots are polished--put on

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: the coffee--yes, yes, yes--my-my--pooh!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Pinches her nose] Can't you wake up?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Sternly] You shouldn't bother those that sleep.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Sharply] What's that?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: One who has stood by the stove all day has a right to be

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: tired at night. And sleep should be respected.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Changing tone] It is fine to think like that, and it does

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: you honour--I thank you for it. [Gives JEAN her hand] Come now and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: pick some lilacs for me.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: still asleep and goes out to the right in order to go to bed.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: With you, Miss Julia?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: With me!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: But it won't do! Absolutely not!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I can't understand what you are thinking of. You couldn't

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: possibly imagine--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, not I, but the people.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: What? That I am fond of the valet?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I am not at all conceited, but such things have happened--and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to the people nothing is sacred.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You are an aristocrat, I think.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, I am.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And I am stepping down--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Take my advice, Miss Julia, don't step down. Nobody will

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: believe you did it on purpose. The people will always say that you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: fell down.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I think better of the people than you do. Come and see if I

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: am not right. Come along! [She ogles him.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You're mighty queer, do you know!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Perhaps. But so are you. And for that matter, everything is

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: queer. Life, men, everything--just a mush that floats on top of the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: water until it sinks, sinks down! I have a dream that comes back to

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: me ever so often. And just now I am reminded of it. I have climbed

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to the top of a column and sit there without being able to tell how

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to get down again. I get dizzy when I look down, and I must get

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: down, but I haven't the courage to jump off. I cannot hold on, and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I am longing to fall, and yet I don't fall. But there will be no

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: rest for me until I get down, no rest until I get down, down on the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: ground. And if I did reach the ground, I should want to get still

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: further down, into the ground itself--Have you ever felt like that?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, my dream is that I am lying under a tall tree in a dark

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: wood. I want to get up, up to the top, so that I can look out over

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the smiling landscape, where the sun is shining, and so that I can

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: rob the nest in which lie the golden eggs. And I climb and climb,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: but the trunk is so thick and smooth, and it is so far to the first

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: branch. But I know that if I could only reach that first branch,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: then I should go right on to the top as on a ladder. I have not

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: reached it yet, but I am going to, if it only be in my dreams.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Here I am chattering to you about dreams! Come along! Only

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: into the park! [She offers her arm to him, and they go toward the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: door.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: We must sleep on nine midsummer flowers to-night, Miss Julia—-

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: then our dreams will come true.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: eyes.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Let me see what you have got in your eye.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, nothing--just some dirt--it will soon be gone.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: It was my sleeve that rubbed against it. Sit down and let me

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: help you. [Takes him by the arm and makes him sit down; takes hold

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: of his head and bends it backwards; tries to get out the dirt with

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: a corner of her handkerchief] Sit still now, absolutely still!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: are shaking—-a big, strong fellow like you! [Feels his biceps] And

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: with such arms!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Ominously] Miss Julia!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Yes, Monsieur Jean.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: _Attention! Je ne suis qu'un homme._

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Can't you sit still!--There now! Now it's gone. Kiss my hand

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: now, and thank me.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Rising] Miss Julia, listen to me. Christine has gone to bed

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: now--Won't you listen to me?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Kiss my hand first.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Listen to me!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Kiss my hand first!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: All right, but blame nobody but yourself!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: For what?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: For what? Are you still a mere child at twenty-five? Don't

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you know that it is dangerous to play with fire?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Not for me. I am insured.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Boldly] No, you are not. And even if you were, there are

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: inflammable surroundings to be counted with.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: That's you, I suppose?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes. Not because I am I, but because I am a young man--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Of handsome appearance--what an incredible conceit! A Don

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Juan, perhaps. Or a Joseph? On my soul, I think you are a Joseph!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Do you?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I fear it almost.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to kiss her.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Gives him a cuff on the ear] Shame!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Was that in play or in earnest?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: In earnest.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Then you were in earnest a moment ago also. Your playing is

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: too serious, and that's the dangerous thing about it. Now I am

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: tired of playing, and I ask to be excused in order to resume my

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: work. The count wants his boots to be ready for him, and it is

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: after midnight already.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Put away the boots.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, it's my work, which I am bound to do. But I have not

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: undertaken to be your playmate. It's something I can never become—-

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I hold myself too good for it.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You're proud!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: In some ways, and not in others.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Have you ever been in love?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: We don't use that word. But I have been fond of a lot of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: girls, and once I was taken sick because I couldn't have the one I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: wanted: sick, you know, like those princes in the Arabian Nights

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: who cannot eat or drink for sheer love.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Who was it?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Who was it?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You cannot make me tell you.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: If I ask you as an equal, ask you as--a friend: who was it?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: It was you.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Sits down] How funny!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, as you say--it was ludicrous. That was the story, you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: see, which I didn't want to tell you a while ago. But now I am

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: going to tell it. Do you know how the world looks from below--no,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you don't. No more than do hawks and falcons, of whom we never see

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the back because they are always floating about high up in the sky.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I lived in the cotter's hovel, together with seven other children,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: and a pig--out there on the grey plain, where there isn't a single

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: tree. But from our windows I could see the wall around the count's

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: park, and apple-trees above it. That was the Garden of Eden, and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: many fierce angels were guarding it with flaming swords.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Nevertheless I and some other boys found our way to the Tree of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Life--now you despise me?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh, stealing apples is something all boys do.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You may say so now, but you despise me nevertheless. However—-

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: once I got into the Garden of Eden with my mother to weed the onion

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: beds. Near by stood a Turkish pavillion, shaded by trees and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: covered with honeysuckle. I didn't know what it was used for, but I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: had never seen a more beautiful building. People went in and came

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: out again, and one day the door was left wide open. I stole up and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: saw the walls covered with pictures of kings and emperors, and the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: windows were hung with red, fringed curtains--now you know what I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: mean. I--[breaks off a lilac sprig and holds it under MISS JULIA's

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: nose]--I had never been inside the manor, and I had never seen

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: anything but the church--and this was much finer. No matter where

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: my thoughts ran, they returned always--to that place. And gradually

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: a longing arose within me to taste the full pleasure of--_enfin_! I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: sneaked in, looked and admired. Then I heard somebody coming. There

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: was only one way out for fine people, but for me there was another,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: and I could do nothing else but choose it.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Then I started to run, plunged through a hedge of raspberry

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: bushes, chased right across a strawberry plantation, and came out

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: on the terrace where the roses grow. There I caught sight of a pink

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: dress and pair of white stockings--that was you! I crawled under a

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: pile of weeds--right into it, you know--into stinging thistles and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: wet, ill-smelling dirt. And I saw you walking among the roses, and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I thought: if it be possible for a robber to get into heaven and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: dwell with the angels, then it is strange that a cotter's child,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: here on God's own earth, cannot get into the park and play with the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: count's daughter.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Sentimentally] Do you think all poor children have the same

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: thoughts as you had in this case?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Hesitatingly at first; then with conviction] If _all_ poor—-

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: yes—-of course. Of course!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: It must be a dreadful misfortune to be poor.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [In a tone of deep distress and with rather exaggerated

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: emphasis] Oh, Miss Julia! Oh!--A dog may lie on her ladyship's

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: sofa; a horse may have his nose patted by the young lady's hand,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: but a servant--[changing his tone]--oh well, here and there you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: meet one made of different stuff, and he makes a way for himself in

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the world, but how often does it happen?--However, do you know what

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I did? I jumped into the mill brook with my clothes on, and was

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: pulled out, and got a licking. But the next Sunday, when my father

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: and the rest of the people were going over to my grandmother's, I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: fixed it so that I could stay at home. And then I washed myself

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: with soap and hot water, and put on my best clothes, and went to

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: church, where I could see you. I did see you, and went home

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: determined to die. But I wanted to die beautifully and pleasantly,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: without any pain. And then I recalled that it was dangerous to

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: sleep under an elder bush. We had a big one that was in full bloom.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I robbed it of all its flowers, and then I put them in the big box

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: where the oats were kept and lay down in them. Did you ever notice

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the smoothness of oats? Soft to the touch as the skin of the human

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: body! However, I pulled down the lid and closed my eyes--fell

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: asleep and was waked up a very sick boy. But I didn't die, as you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: can see. What I wanted--that's more than I can tell. Of course,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: there was not the least hope of winning you—-but you symbolised the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: hopelessness of trying to get out of the class into which I was

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: born.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You narrate splendidly, do you know! Did you ever go to

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: school?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: A little. But I have read a lot of novels and gone to the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: theatre a good deal. And besides, I have listened to the talk of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: better-class people, and from that I have learned most of all.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Do you stand around and listen to what we are saying?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Of course! And I have heard a lot, too, when I was on the box

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: of the carriage, or rowing the boat. Once I heard you, Miss Julia,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: and one of your girl friends--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh!--What was it you heard then?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, it wouldn't be easy to repeat. But I was rather

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: surprised, and I couldn't understand where you had learned all

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: those words. Perhaps, at bottom, there isn't quite so much

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: difference as they think between one kind of people and another.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You ought to be ashamed of yourself! We don't live as you do

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: when we are engaged.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Looking hard at her] Is it so certain?--Well, Miss Julia, it

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: won't pay to make yourself out so very innocent to me—-

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: The man on whom I bestowed my love was a scoundrel.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: That's what you always say--afterwards.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Always?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Always, I believe, for I have heard the same words used

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: several times before, on similar occasions.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: What occasions?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Like the one of which we were speaking. The last time--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Rising] Stop! I don't want to hear any more!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Nor did _she_--curiously enough! Well, then I ask permission

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to go to bed.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Gently] Go to bed on Midsummer Eve?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, for dancing with that mob out there has really no

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: attraction for me.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Get the key to the boat and take me out on the lake--I want

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to watch the sunrise.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Would that be wise?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: It sounds as if you were afraid of your reputation.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Why not? I don't care to be made ridiculous, and I don't care

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to be discharged without a recommendation, for I am trying to get

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: on in the world. And then I feel myself under a certain obligation

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to Christine.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: So it's Christine now

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, but it's you also--Take my advice and go to bed!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Am I to obey you?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: For once--and for your own sake! The night is far gone.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Sleepiness makes us drunk, and the head grows hot. Go to bed! And

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: besides--if I am not mistaken—-I can hear the crowd coming this way

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to look for me. And if we are found together here, you are lost!

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: [Is heard approaching]:

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Through the fields come two ladies a-walking,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Treederee-derallah, treederee-derah.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: And one has her shoes full of water,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Treederee-derallah-lah.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: They're talking of hundreds of dollars,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Treederee-derallah, treederee-derah.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But have not between them a dollar

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Treederee-derallah-lah.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: This wreath I give you gladly,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Treederee-derallah, treederee-derah.

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: But love another madly,

SPEAKER: CHORUS
TEXT: Treederee-derallah-lah.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I know the people, and I love them, just as they love me.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Let them come, and you'll see.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, Miss Julia, they don't love you. They take your food and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: spit at your back. Believe me. Listen to me--can't you hear what

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: they are singing?--No, don't pay any attention to it!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Listening] What is it they are singing?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, something scurrilous. About you and me.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: How infamous! They ought to be ashamed! And the treachery of

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: it!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: The mob is always cowardly. And in such a fight as this there

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: is nothing to do but to run away.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Run away? Where to? We cannot get out. And we cannot go into

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Christine's room.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, we cannot? Well, into my room, then! Necessity knows no

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: law. And you can trust me, for I am your true and frank and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: respectful friend.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: But think only-think if they should look for you in there!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I shall bolt the door. And if they try to break it I open,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I'll shoot!--Come! [Kneeling before her] Come!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Meaningly] And you promise me--?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I swear!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: eagerly.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: BALLET

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: The peasants enter. They are decked out in their best and carry

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: flowers in their hats. A fiddler leads them. On the table they

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: place a barrel of small-beer and a keg of "brännvin," or white

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Swedish whiskey, both of them decorated with wreathes woven out of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: leaves. First they drink. Then they form in ring and sing and dance

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to the melody heard before:

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: "Through the fields come two ladies a-walking."

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: The dance finished, they leave singing.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Enters alone. On seeing the disorder in the kitchen, she

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: claps her hands together. Then she takes out a powder-puff and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: begins to powder her face.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Enters in a state of exaltation] There you see! And you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: heard, didn't you? Do you think it possible to stay here?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: No, I don't think so. But what are we to do?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Run away, travel, far away from here.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Travel? Yes-but where?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: To Switzerland, the Italian lakes--you have never been there?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: No. Is the country beautiful?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh! Eternal summer! Orange trees! Laurels! Oh!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: But then-what are we to do down there?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I'll start a hotel, everything first class, including the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: customers?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Hotel?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: That's the life, I tell you! Constantly new faces and new

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: languages. Never a minute free for nerves or brooding. No trouble

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: about what to do--for the work is calling to be done: night and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: day, bells that ring, trains that whistle, 'busses that come and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: go; and gold pieces raining on the counter all the time. That's the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: life for you!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Yes, that is life. And I?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: The mistress of everything, the chief ornament of the house.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: With your looks--and your manners--oh, success will be assured!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Enormous! You'll sit like a queen in the office and keep the slaves

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: going by the touch of an electric button. The guests will pass in

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: review before your throne and timidly deposit their treasures on

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: your table. You cannot imagine how people tremble when a bill is

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: presented to them--I'll salt the items, and you'll sugar them with

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: your sweetest smiles. Oh, let us get away from here--[pulling a

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: time-table from his pocket]--at once, with the next train! We'll be

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: in Malmö at 6.30; in Hamburg at 8.40 to-morrow morning; in Frankfort

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: and Basel a day later. And to reach Como by way of the St. Gotthard

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: it will take us--let me see--three days. Three days!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: All that is all right. But you must give me some courage—

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Jean. Tell me that you love me. Come and take me in your arms.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Reluctantly] I should like to--but I don't dare. Not in this

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: house again. I love you--beyond doubt--or, can you doubt it, Miss

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Julia?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [With modesty and true womanly feeling] Miss? Call me Julia.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Between us there can be no barriers here after. Call me Julia!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Disturbed] I cannot! There will be barriers between us as

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: long as we stay in this house--there is the past, and there is the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: count-—and I have never met another person for whom I felt such

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: respect. If I only catch sight of his gloves on a chair I feel

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: small. If I only hear that bell up there, I jump like a shy horse.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And even now, when I see his boots standing there so stiff and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: perky, it is as if something made my back bend. [Kicking at the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: boots] It's nothing but superstition and tradition hammered into us

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: from childhood--but it can be as easily forgotten again. Let us

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: only get to another country, where they have a republic, and you'll

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: see them bend their backs double before my liveried porter. You

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: see, backs have to be bent, but not mine. I wasn't born to that

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: kind of thing. There's better stuff in me--character--and if I only

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: get hold of the first branch, you'll see me do some climbing.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: To-day I am a valet, but next year I'll be a hotel owner. In ten

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: years I can live on the money I have made, and then I'll go to

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Roumania and get myself an order. And I may--note well that I say

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: _may_--end my days as a count.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Splendid, splendid!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, in Roumania the title of count can be had for cash, and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: so you'll be a countess after all. My countess!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: What do I care about all I now cast behind me! Tell me that

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: you love me: otherwise--yes, what am I otherwise?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I will tell you so a thousand times--later. But not here. And

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: above all, no sentimentality, or everything will be lost. We must

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: look at the matter in cold blood, like sensible people. [Takes out

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: a cigar, cuts of the point, and lights it] Sit down there now, and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I'll sit here, and then we'll talk as if nothing had happened.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [In despair] Good Lord! Have you then no feelings at all?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I? No one is more full of feeling than I am. But I know how

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to control myself.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: A while ago you kissed my shoe--and now!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Severely] Yes, that was then. Now we have other things to

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: think of.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Don't speak harshly to me!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, but sensibly. One folly has been committed--don't let us

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: commit any more! The count may be here at any moment, and before he

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: comes our fate must be settled. What do you think of my plans for

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the future? Do you approve of them?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: They seem acceptable, on the whole. But there is one

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: question: a big undertaking of that kind will require a big capital

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: have you got it?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Chewing his cigar] I? Of course! I have my expert knowledge,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: my vast experience, my familiarity with several languages. That's

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the very best kind of capital, I should say.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: But it won't buy you a railroad ticket even.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: That's true enough. And that is just why I am looking for a

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: backer to advance the needful cash.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Where could you get one all of a sudden?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: It's for you to find him if you want to become my partner.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I cannot do it, and I have nothing myself. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, then that's off--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And—-

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Everything remains as before.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Do you think I am going to stay under this roof as your

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: concubine? Do you think I'll let the people point their fingers at

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: me? Do you think I can look my father in the face after this? No,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: take me away from here, from all this humiliation and disgrace!—

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh, what have I done? My God, my God! [Breaks into tears.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: So we have got around to that tune now!--What you have done?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Nothing but what many others have done before you.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Crying hysterically] And now you're despising me!--I'm

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: falling, I'm falling!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Fall down to me, and I'll lift you up again afterwards.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: What horrible power drew me to you? Was it the attraction

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: which the strong exercises on the weak--the one who is rising on

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: one who is falling? Or was it love? This love! Do you know what

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: love is?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I? Well, I should say so! Don't you think I have been there

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: before?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh, the language you use, and the thoughts you think!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, that's the way I was brought up, and that's the way I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: am. Don't get nerves now and play the exquisite, for now one of us

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: is just as good as the other. Look here, my girl, let me treat you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to a glass of something superfine. [He opens the table-drawer,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: takes out the wine bottle and fills up two glasses that have

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: already been used.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Where did you get that wine?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: In the cellar.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: My father's Burgundy!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, isn't it good enough for the son-in-law?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And I am drinking beer--I!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: It shows merely that I have better taste than you.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Thief!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Do you mean to tell on me?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh, oh! The accomplice of a house thief! Have I been drunk,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: or have I been dreaming all this night? Midsummer Eve! The feast of

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: innocent games—-

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Innocent--hm!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Walking back and forth] Can there be another human being on

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: earth so unhappy as I am at this moment'

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: But why should you be? After such a conquest? Think of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Christine in there. Don't you think she has feelings also?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I thought so a while ago, but I don't think so any longer.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: No, a menial is a menial--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And a whore a whore!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [On her knees, with folded hands] O God in heaven, make an

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: end of this wretched life! Take me out of the filth into which I am

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: sinking! Save me! Save me!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I cannot deny that I feel sorry for you. When I was lying

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: among the onions and saw you up there among the roses--I'll tell

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you now--I had the same nasty thoughts that all boys have.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And you who wanted to die for my sake!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Among the oats. That was nothing but talk.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Lies in other words!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Beginning to feel sleepy] Just about. I think I read the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: story in a paper, and it was about a chimney-sweep who crawled into

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: a wood-box full of lilacs because a girl had brought suit against

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: him for not supporting her kid—-

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: So that's the sort you are--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, I had to think of something--for it's the high-faluting

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: stuff that the women bite on.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Scoundrel!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Rot!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And now you have seen the back of the hawk--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, I don't know--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And I was to be the first branch--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: But the branch was rotten--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I was to be the sign in front of the hotel--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And I the hotel--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Sit at your counter, and lure your customers, and doctor

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: your bills--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, that I should have done myself--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: That a human soul can be so steeped in dirt!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, wash it off!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You lackey, you menial, stand up when I talk to you!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You lackey-love, you mistress of a menial--shut up and get

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: out of here! You're the right one to come and tell me that I am

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: vulgar. People of my kind would never in their lives act as

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: vulgarly as you have acted to-night. Do you think any servant girl

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: would go for a man as you did? Did you ever see a girl of my class

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: throw herself at anybody in that way? I have never seen the like of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: it except among beasts and prostitutes.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Crushed] That's right: strike me, step on me--I haven't

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: deserved any better! I am a wretched creature. But help me! Help

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: me out of this, if there be any way to do so!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [In a milder tone] I don't want to lower myself by a denial

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: of my share in the honour of seducing. But do you think a person in

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: my place would have dared to raise his eyes to you, if the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: invitation to do so had not come from yourself? I am still sitting

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: here in a state of utter surprise--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And pride--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, why not? Although I must confess that the victory was

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: too easy to bring with it any real intoxication.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Strike me some more!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Rising] No! Forgive me instead what I have been saying. I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: don't want to strike one who is disarmed, and least of all a lady.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: On one hand I cannot deny that it has given me pleasure to discover

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: that what has dazzled us below is nothing but cat-gold; that the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: hawk is simply grey on the back also; that there is powder on the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: tender cheek; that there may be black borders on the polished

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: nails; and that the handkerchief may be dirty, although it smells

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: of perfume. But on the other hand it hurts me to have discovered

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: that what I was striving to reach is neither better nor more

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: genuine. It hurts me to see you sinking so low that you are far

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: beneath your own cook--it hurts me as it hurts to see the Fall

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: flowers beaten down by the rain and turned into mud.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You speak as if you were already above me?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, so I am. Don't you see: I could have made a countess of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you, but you could never make me a count.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: But I am born of a count, and that's more than you can ever

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: achieve.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: That's true. But I might be the father of counts—if--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: But you are a thief--and I am not.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Thief is not the worst. There are other kinds still farther

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: down. And then, when I serve in a house, I regard myself in a sense

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: as a member of the family, as a child of the house, and you don't

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: call it theft when children pick a few of the berries that load

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: down the vines. [His passion is aroused once more] Miss Julia, you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: are a magnificent woman, and far too good for one like me. You were

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: swept along by a spell of intoxication, and now you want to cover

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: up your mistake by making yourself believe that you are in love

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: with me. Well, you are not, unless possibly my looks might tempt

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you-—in which case your love is no better than mine. I could never

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: rest satisfied with having you care for nothing in me but the mere

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: animal, and your love I can never win.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Are you so sure of that?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You mean to say that it might be possible? That I might love

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you: yes, without doubt--for you are beautiful, refined, [goes up

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to her and takes hold of her hand] educated, charming when you want

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to be so, and it is not likely that the flame will ever burn out in

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: a man who has once been set of fire by you. [Puts his arm around

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: her waist] You are like burnt wine with strong spices in it, and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: one of your kisses--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: hold.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Leave me alone! In that way you cannot win me.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: How then?--Not in that way! Not by caresses and sweet words!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Not by thought for the future, by escape from disgrace! How then?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: How? How? I don't know--Not at all! I hate you as I hate

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: rats, but I cannot escape from you!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Escape with me!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Straightening up] Escape? Yes, we must escape!--But I am so

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: tired. Give me a glass of wine.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Looks at her watch] But we must have a talk first. We have

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: still some time left. [Empties her glass and holds it out for more.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Don't drink so much. It will go to your head.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: What difference would that make?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: What difference would it make? It's vulgar to get drunk--What

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: was it you wanted to tell me?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: We must get away. But first we must have a talk--that is, I

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: must talk, for so far you have done all the talking. You have told

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: me about your life. Now I must tell you about mine, so that we know

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: each other right to the bottom before we begin the journey together.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: One moment, pardon me! Think first, so that you don't regret

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: it afterwards, when you have already given up the secrets of your

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: life.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Are you not my friend?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, at times--but don't rely on me.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You only talk like that--and besides, my secrets are known

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to everybody. You see, my mother was not of noble birth, but came

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: of quite plain people. She was brought up in the ideas of her time

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: about equality, and woman's independence, and that kind of thing.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And she had a decided aversion to marriage. Therefore, when my

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: father proposed to her, she said she wouldn't marry him--and then

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: she did it just the same. I came into the world--against my

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: mother's wish, I have come to think. Then my mother wanted to bring

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: me up in a perfectly natural state, and at the same time I was to

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: learn everything that a boy is taught, so that I might prove that a

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: woman is just as good as a man. I was dressed as a boy, and was

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: taught how to handle a horse, but could have nothing to do with the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: cows. I had to groom and harness and go hunting on horseback. I was

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: even forced to learn something about agriculture. And all over the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: estate men were set to do women's work, and women to do men's--with

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: the result that everything went to pieces and we became the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: laughing-stock of the whole neighbourhood. At last my father must

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: have recovered from the spell cast over him, for he rebelled, and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: everything was changed to suit his own ideas. My mother was taken

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: sick--what kind of sickness it was I don't know, but she fell often

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: into convulsions, and she used to hide herself in the garret or in

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: the garden, and sometimes she stayed out all night. Then came the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: big fire, of which you have heard. The house, the stable, and the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: barn were burned down, and this under circumstances which made it

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: look as if the fire had been set on purpose. For the disaster

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: occurred the day after our insurance expired, and the money sent

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: for renewal of the policy had been delayed by the messenger's

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: carelessness, so that it came too late. [She fills her glass again

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: and drinks.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Don't drink any more.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh, what does it matter!--We were without a roof over our

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: heads and had to sleep in the carriages. My father didn't know

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: where to get money for the rebuilding of the house. Then my mother

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: suggested that he try to borrow from a childhood friend of hers, a

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: brick manufacturer living not far from here. My father got the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: loan, but was not permitted to pay any interest, which astonished

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: him. And so the house was built up again. [Drinks again] Do you

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: know who set fire to the house?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Her ladyship, your mother!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Do you know who the brick manufacturer was?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Your mother's lover?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Do you know to whom the money belonged?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Wait a minute--no, that I don't know.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: To my mother.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: In other words, to the count, if there was no settlement.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: There was no settlement. My mother possessed a small fortune

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: of her own which she did not want to leave in my father's control,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: so she invested it with--her friend.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Who copped it.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Exactly! He kept it. All this came to my father's knowledge.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: He couldn't bring suit; he couldn't pay his wife's lover; he

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: couldn't prove that it was his wife's money. That was my mother's

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: revenge because he had made himself master in his own house. At

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: that time he came near shooting himself--it was even rumoured that

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: he had tried and failed. But he took a new lease of life, and my

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: mother had to pay for what she had done. I can tell you that those

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: were five years I'll never forget! My sympathies were with my

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: father, but I took my mother's side because I was not aware of the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: true circumstances. From her I learned to suspect and hate men--for

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: she hated the whole sex, as you have probably heard--and I promised

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: her on my oath that I would never become a man's slave.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And so you became engaged to the County Attorney.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Yes, in order that he should be my slave.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And he didn't want to?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh, he wanted, but I wouldn't let him. I got tired of him.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, I saw it--in the stable-yard.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: What did you see?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Just that--how he broke the engagement.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: That's a lie! It was I who broke it. Did he say he did it,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: the scoundrel?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, he was no scoundrel, I guess. So you hate men, Miss

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Julia?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Yes! Most of the time. But now and then--when the weakness

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: comes over me--oh, what shame!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And you hate me too?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Beyond measure! I should like to kill you like a wild beast--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: As you make haste to shoot a mad dog. Is that right?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: That's right!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: But now there is nothing to shoot with--and there is no dog.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: What are we to do then?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Go abroad.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: In order to plague each other to death?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: No-in order to enjoy ourselves: a couple of days, a week, as

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: long as enjoyment is possible. And then--die!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Die? How silly! Then I think it's much better to start a

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: hotel.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Without listening to JEAN]--At Lake Como, where the sun is

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: always shining, and the laurels stand green at Christmas, and the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: oranges are glowing.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Lake Como is a rainy hole, and I could see no oranges except

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: in the groceries. But it is a good place for tourists, as it has a

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: lot of villas that can be rented to loving couples, and that's a

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: profitable business--do you know why? Because they take a lease for

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: six months--and then they leave after three weeks.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Naïvely] Why after three weeks?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Because they quarrel, of course. But the rent has to be paid

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: just the same. And then you can rent the house again. And that way

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: it goes on all the time, for there is plenty of love--even if it

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: doesn't last long.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You don't want to die with me?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I don't want to die at all. Both because I am fond of living,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: and because I regard suicide as a crime against the Providence

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: which has bestowed life on us.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Do you mean to say that you believe in God?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Of course, I do. And I go to church every other Sunday.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Frankly speaking, now I am tired of all this, and now I am going to

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: bed.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: So! And you think that will be enough for me? Do you know

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: what you owe a woman that you have spoiled?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Takes out his purse and throws a silver coin on the table]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You're welcome! I don't want to be in anybody's debt.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Pretending not to notice the insult] Do you know what the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: law provides--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Unfortunately the law provides no punishment for a woman

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: who seduces a man.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [As before] Can you think of any escape except by our

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: going abroad and getting married, and then getting a divorce?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Suppose I refuse to enter into this _mésaillance_?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: _Mésaillance_--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, for me. You see, I have better ancestry than you, for

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: nobody in my family was ever guilty of arson.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: How do you know?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, nothing is known to the contrary, for we keep no

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Pedigrees--except in the police bureau. But I have read about your

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: pedigree in a book that was lying on the drawing-room table. Do you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: know who was your first ancestor? A miller who let his wife sleep

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: with the king one night during the war with Denmark. I have no such

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: ancestry. I have none at all, but I can become an ancestor myself.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: That's what I get for unburdening my heart to one not worthy

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: of it; for sacrificing my family's honour--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Dishonour! Well, what was it I told you? You shouldn't drink,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: for then you talk. And you must not talk!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh, how I regret what I have done! How I regret it! If at

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: least you loved me!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: For the last time: what do you mean? Am I to weep? Am I to

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: jump over your whip? Am I to kiss you, and lure you down to Lake

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Como for three weeks, and so on? What am I to do? What do you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: expect? This is getting to be rather painful! But that's what comes

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: from getting mixed up with women. Miss Julia! I see that you are

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: unhappy; I know that you are suffering; but I cannot understand

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you. We never carry on like that. There is never any hatred between

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: us. Love is to us a play, and we play at it when our work leaves us

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: time to do so. But we have not the time to do so all day and all

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: night, as you have. I believe you are sick--I am sure you are sick.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You should be good to me--and now you speak like a human

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: being.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: All right, but be human yourself. You spit on me, and then

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you won't let me wipe myself--on you!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Help me, help me! Tell me only what I am to do--where I am

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to turn?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: O Lord, if I only knew that myself!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I have been exasperated, I have been mad, but there ought to

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: be some way of saving myself.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Stay right here and keep quiet. Nobody knows anything.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Impossible! The people know, and Christine knows.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: They don't know, and they would never believe it possible.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Hesitating] But-it might happen again.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: That's true.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And the results?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Frightened] The results! Where was my head when I didn't

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: think of that! Well, then there is only one thing to do--you must

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: leave. At once! I can't go with you, for then everything would be

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: lost, so you must go alone--abroad--anywhere!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Alone? Where?--I can't do it.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You must! And before the count gets back. If you stay, then

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you know what will happen. Once on the wrong path, one wants to

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: keep on, as the harm is done anyhow. Then one grows more and more

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: reckless--and at last it all comes out. So you must get away! Then

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: you can write to the count and tell him everything, except that it

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: was me. And he would never guess it. Nor do I think he would be

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: very anxious to find out.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I'll go if you come with me.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Are you stark mad, woman? Miss Julia to run away with her

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: valet! It would be in the papers in another day, and the count

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: could never survive it.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: I can't leave! I can't stay! Help me! I am so tired, so

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: fearfully tired. Give me orders! Set me going, for I can no longer

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: think, no longer act—-

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Do you see now what good-for-nothings you are! Why do you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: strut and turn up your noses as if you were the lords of creation?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, I am going to give you orders. Go up and dress. Get some

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: travelling money, and then come back again.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [In an undertone] Come up with me!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: To your room? Now you're crazy again! [Hesitates a moment]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, you must go at once! [Takes her by the hand and leads her out.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [On her way out] Can't you speak kindly to me, Jean?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: An order must always sound unkind. Now you can find out how

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: it feels!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: out a note-book and a pencil; figures aloud from time to time; dumb

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: play until CHRISTINE enters dressed for church; she has a false

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: shirt front and a white tie in one of her hands.]

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Goodness gracious, how the place looks! What have you

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: been up to anyhow?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, it was Miss Julia who dragged in the people. Have you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: been sleeping so hard that you didn't hear anything at all?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: I have been sleeping like a log.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And dressed for church already?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Yes, didn't you promise to come with me to communion

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: to-day?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Oh, yes, I remember now. And there you've got the finery.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, come on with it. [Sits down; CHRISTINE helps him to put on

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the shirt front and the white tie.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Sleepily] What's the text to-day?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Oh, about John the Baptist beheaded, I guess.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: That's going to be a long story, I'm sure. My, but you choke

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: me! Oh, I'm so sleepy, so sleepy!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Well, what has been keeping you up all night? Why, man,

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: you're just green in the face!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I have been sitting here talking with Miss Julia.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: She hasn't an idea of what's proper, that creature!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Say, Christine.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Well?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Isn't it funny anyhow, when you come to think of it? Her!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: What is it that's funny?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Everything!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [Seeing the glasses on the table that are only

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: half-emptied] So you've been drinking together also?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Shame on you! Look me in the eye!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Is it possible? Is it possible?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [After a moment's thought] Yes, it is!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Ugh! That's worse than I could ever have believed. It's

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: awful!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You are not jealous of her, are you?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: No, not of her. Had it been Clara or Sophie, then I'd

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: have scratched your eyes out. Yes, that's the way I feel about it,

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: and I can't tell why. Oh my, but that was nasty!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Are you mad at her then?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: No, but at you! It was wrong of you, very wrong! Poor

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: girl! No, I tell you, I don't want to stay in this house any

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: longer, with people for whom it is impossible to have any respect.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Why should you have any respect for them?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: And you who are such a smarty can't tell that! You

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: wouldn't serve people who don't act decently, would you? It's to

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: lower oneself, I think.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, but it ought to be a consolation to us that they are not

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: a bit better than we.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: No, I don't think so. For if they're no better, then

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: it's no use trying to get up to them. And just think of the count!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Think of him who has had so much sorrow in his day! No, I don't

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: want to stay any longer in this house--And with a fellow like you,

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: too. If it had been the county attorney--if it had only been some

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: one of her own sort--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Now look here!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Yes, yes! You're all right in your way, but there's

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: after all some difference between one kind of people and another—-

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: No, but this is something I'll never get over!--And the young lady

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: who was so proud, and so tart to the men, that you couldn't believe

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: she would ever let one come near her--and such a one at that! And

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: she who wanted to have poor Diana shot because she had been running

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: around with the gate-keeper's pug!--Well, I declare!--But I won't

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: stay here any longer, and next October I get out of here.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And then?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Well, as we've come to talk of that now, perhaps it

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: would be just as well if you looked for something, seeing that

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: we're going to get married after all.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, what could I look for? As a married man I couldn't get

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: a place like this.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: No, I understand that. But you could get a job as a

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: janitor, or maybe as a messenger in some government bureau. Of

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: course, the public loaf is always short in weight, but it comes

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: steady, and then there is a pension for the widow and the children--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Making a face] That's good and well, but it isn't my style

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to think of dying all at once for the sake of wife and children. I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: must say that my plans have been looking toward something better

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: than that kind of thing.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Your plans, yes--but you've got obligations also, and

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: those you had better keep in mind!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Now don't you get my dander up by talking of obligations! I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: know what I've got to do anyhow. [Listening for some sound on the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: outside] However, we've plenty of time to think of all this. Go in

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: now and get ready, and then we'll go to church.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Who is walking around up there?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I don't know, unless it be Clara.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [Going out] It can't be the count, do you think, who's

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: come home without anybody hearing him?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Scared] The count? No, that isn't possible, for then he

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: would have rung for me.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [As she goes out] Well, God help us all! Never have I

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: seen the like of it!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: light changes gradually until it comes slantingly in through the

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: windows. JEAN goes to the door and gives a signal.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Enters in travelling dress and carrying a small birdcage

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: covered up with a towel; this she places on a chair] Now I am

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: ready.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Hush! Christine is awake.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Showing extreme nervousness during the following scene] Did

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: she suspect anything?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: She knows nothing at all. But, my heavens, how you look!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: How do I look?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You're as pale as a corpse, and--pardon me, but your face is

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: dirty.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Let me wash it then--Now! [She goes over to the washstand

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: and washes her face and hands] Give me a towel--Oh!--That's the sun

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: rising!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: And then the ogre bursts.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Yes, ogres and trolls were abroad last night!—But listen,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Jean. Come with me, for now I have the money.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Doubtfully] Enough?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Enough to start with. Come with me, for I cannot travel

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: alone to-day. Think of it--Midsummer Day, on a stuffy train, jammed

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: with people who stare at you--and standing still at stations when

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: you want to fly. No, I cannot! I cannot! And then the memories will

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: come: childhood memories of Midsummer Days, when the inside of the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: church was turned into a green forest--birches and lilacs; the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: dinner at the festive table with relatives and friends; the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: afternoon in the park, with dancing and music, flowers and games!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Oh, you may run and run, but your memories are in the baggage-car,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: and with them remorse and repentance!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: I'll go with you-but at once, before it's too late. This very

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: moment!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Well, get dressed then. [Picks up the cage.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: But no baggage! That would only give us away.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: No, nothing at all! Only what we can take with us in the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: car.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Has taken down his hat] What have you got there? What is it?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: It's only my finch. I can't leave it behind.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Did you ever! Dragging a bird-cage along with us! You must be

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: raving mad! Drop the cage!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: The only thing I take with me from my home! The only living

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: creature that loves me since Diana deserted me! Don't be cruel! Let

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: me take it along!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Drop the cage, I tell you! And don't talk so loud--Christine

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: can hear us.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: No, I won't let it fall into strange hands. I'd rather have

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: you kill it!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, give it to me, and I'll wring its neck.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Yes, but don't hurt it. Don't--no, I cannot!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Let me--I can!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Takes the bird out of the cage and kisses it] Oh, my little

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: birdie, must it die and go away from its mistress!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Don't make a scene, please. Don't you know it's a question of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: your life, of your future? Come, quick! [Snatches the bird away

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: from her, carries it to the chopping block and picks up an axe.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: MISS JULIA turns away.]

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You should have learned how to kill chickens instead of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: shooting with a revolver--[brings down the axe]--then you wouldn't

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: have fainted for a drop of blood.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Screaming] Kill me too! Kill me! You who can take the life

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: of an innocent creature without turning a hair! Oh, I hate and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: despise you! There is blood between us! Cursed be the hour when I

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: first met you! Cursed be the hour when I came to life in my

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: mother's womb!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Well, what's the use of all that cursing? Come on!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Approaching the chopping-block as if drawn to it against

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: her will] No, I don't want to go yet. I cannot—-I must see--Hush!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: There's a carriage coming up the road. [Listening without taking

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: her eyes of the block and the axe] You think I cannot stand the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: sight of blood. You think I am as weak as that--oh, I should like

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to see your blood, your brains, on that block there. I should like

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to see your whole sex swimming in blood like that thing there. I

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: think I could drink out of your skull, and bathe my feet in your

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: open breast, and eat your heart from the spit!--You think I am

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: weak; you think I love you because the fruit of my womb was

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: yearning for your seed; you think I want to carry your offspring

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: under my heart and nourish it with my blood--bear your children and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: take your name! Tell me, you, what are you called anyhow? I have

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: never heard your family name—-and maybe you haven't any. I should

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: become Mrs. "Hovel," or Mrs. "Backyard"--you dog there, that's

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: wearing my collar; you lackey with my coat of arms on your buttons--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: and I should share with my cook, and be the rival of my own

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: servant. Oh! Oh! Oh!--You think I am a coward and want to run away!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: No, now I'll stay--and let the lightning strike! My father will

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: come home--will find his chiffonier opened--the money gone! Then

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: he'll ring--twice for the valet--and then he'll send for the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: sheriff--and then I shall tell everything! Everything! Oh, but it

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: will be good to get an end to it--if it only be the end! And then

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: his heart will break, and he dies!--So there will be an end to all

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: of us--and all will be quiet—peace--eternal rest!--And then the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: coat of arms will be shattered on the coffin--and the count's line

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: will be wiped out--but the lackey's line goes on in the orphan

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: asylum--wins laurels in the gutter, and ends in jail.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: There spoke the royal blood! Bravo, Miss Julia! Now you put

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the miller back in his sack!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: her hand.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Hurries up to her and throws herself into her arms ax if

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: seeking protection] Help me, Christine! Help me against this man!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [Unmoved and cold] What kind of performance is this on

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: the Sabbath morning? [Catches sight of the chopping-block] My, what

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: a mess you have made!--What's the meaning of all this? And the way

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: you shout and carry on!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You are a woman, Christine, and you are my friend. Beware of

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: that scoundrel!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [A little shy and embarrassed] While the ladies are

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: discussing I'll get myself a shave. [Slinks out to the right.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You must understand me, and you must listen to me.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: No, really, I don't understand this kind of trolloping.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Where are you going in your travelling-dress--and he with his hat

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: on--what?--What?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Listen, Christine, listen, and I'll tell you everything--

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: I don't want to know anything--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: You must listen to me--

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: What is it about? Is it about this nonsense with Jean?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Well, I don't care about it at all, for it's none of my business.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: But if you're planning to get him away with you, we'll put a stop

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: to that!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Extremely nervous] Please try to be quiet, Christine, and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: listen to me. I cannot stay here, and Jean cannot stay here--and so

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: we must leave—-

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Hm, hm!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Brightening. up] But now I have got an idea, you know.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Suppose all three of us should leave--go abroad--go to Switzerland

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: and start a hotel together--I have money, you know--and Jean and I

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: could run the whole thing--and you, I thought, could take charge of

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: the kitchen--Wouldn't that be fine!--Say yes, now! And come along

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: with us! Then everything is fixed!--Oh, say yes!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [Coldly and thoughtfully] Hm, hm!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Presto tempo] You have never travelled, Christine--you must

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: get out and have a look at the world. You cannot imagine what fun

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: it is to travel on a train--constantly new people--new countries—-

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: and then we get to Hamburg and take in the Zoological Gardens in

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: passing--that's what you like--and then we go to the theatres and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to the opera--and when we get to Munich, there, you know, we have a

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: lot of museums, where they keep Rubens and Raphael and all those

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: big painters, you know--Haven't you heard of Munich, where King

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Louis used to live--the king, you know, that went mad--And then

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: we'll have a look at his castle--he has still some castles that are

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: furnished just as in a fairy tale--and from there it isn't very far

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to Switzerland--and the Alps, you know--just think of the Alps,

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: with snow on top of them in the middle of the summer--and there you

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: have orange trees and laurels that are green all the year around--

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: which he holds between his teeth and his left hand; he listens to

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: the talk with a pleased mien and nods approval now and then.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Tempo prestissimo] And then we get a hotel--and I sit in

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: the office, while Jean is outside receiving tourists--and goes out

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: marketing--and writes letters--That's a life for you--Then the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: train whistles, and the 'bus drives up, and it rings upstairs, and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: it rings in the restaurant--and then I make out the bills--and I am

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: going to salt them, too--You can never imagine how timid tourists

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: are when they come to pay their bills! And you--you will sit like a

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: queen in the kitchen. Of course, you are not going to stand at the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: stove yourself. And you'll have to dress neatly and nicely in order

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to show yourself to people--and with your looks--yes, I am not

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: flattering you--you'll catch a husband some fine day--some rich

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Englishman, you know-—for those fellows are so easy [slowing down]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: to catch--and then we grow rich--and we build us a villa at Lake

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Como--of course, it is raining a little in that place now and then—-

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: but [limply] the sun must be shining sometimes--although it looks

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: dark--and--then--or else we can go home again--and come back--here—-

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: or some other place--

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Tell me, Miss Julia, do you believe in all that

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: yourself?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Crushed] Do I believe in it myself?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Exhausted] I don't know: I believe no longer in anything.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: the table] Nothing! Nothing at all!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: [Turns to the right, where JEAN is standing] So you were

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: going to run away!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Abashed, puts the razor on the table] Run away? Well, that's

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: putting it rather strong. You have heard what the young lady

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: proposes, and though she is tired out now by being up all night,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: it's a proposition that can be put through all right.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Now you tell me: did you mean me to act as cook for that

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: one there--?

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Sharply] Will you please use decent language in speaking to

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: your mistress! Do you understand?

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Mistress!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Well, well! Listen to him!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, it would be better for you to listen a little more and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: talk a little less. Miss Julia is your mistress, and what makes you

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: disrespectful to her now should snake you feel the same way about

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Oh, I have always had enough respect for myself--

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: stable!

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: You--you!

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: Are you coming with me to church? I think you need a

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: good sermon on top of such a deed.

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: through a needle's eye than for a rich man to get into heaven.

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE

SPEAKER: CHRISTINE
TEXT: if anybody should like to get away before the count comes home.

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Picking up the razor with a significant gesture] Like this?

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: It is the same--as--that between man and woman.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [With the razor in her hand] I want to, but I cannot!--My

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: father couldn't either, that time he should have done it.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, he should not have done it, for he had to get his revenge

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: first.

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: through me.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Have you not loved your father, Miss Julia?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Yes, immensely, but I must have hated him, too. I think I

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: man! Whose fault is it, this that has happened? My father's--my

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: mother's--my own? My own? Why, I have nothing that is my own. I

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: haven't a thought that didn't come from my father; not a passion

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: that didn't come from my mother; and now this last--this about all

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: human creatures being equal--I got that from him, my fiancé--whom I

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: call a scoundrel for that reason! How can it be my own fault? To

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: put the blame on Jesus, as Christine does--no, I am too proud for

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: that, and know too much--thanks to my father's teachings--And that

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: about a rich person not getting into heaven, it's just a lie, and

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Christine, who has money in the savings-bank, wouldn't get in

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: anyhow. Whose is the fault?--What does it matter whose it is? For

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: just the same I am the one who must bear the guilt and the results--

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Yes, but--

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: hour.

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: anything; can't repent, can't run away, can't stay, can't live—-

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: JULIA

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: it-—but--Oh, that damned menial is back in my spine again. I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: believe if the count should come down here, and if he should tell

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: me to cut my own throat--I'd do it on the spot!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: Make believe that you are he, and that I am you! You did

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: some fine acting when you were on your knees before me--then you

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: were the nobleman--or--have you ever been to a show and seen one

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: who could hypnotize people?

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: He says to his subject: get the broom. And the man gets it.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: He says: sweep. And the man sweeps.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: But then the other person must be asleep.

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Ecstatically] I am asleep already--there is nothing in the

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: whole room but a lot of smoke--and you look like a stove--that

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: looks like a man in black clothes and a high hat--and your eyes

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: glow like coals when the fire is going out--and your face is a lump

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: of white ashes. [The sunlight has reached the floor and is now

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: falling on JEAN] How warm and nice it is! [She rubs her hands as if

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: warming them before a fire.] And so light--and so peaceful!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Takes the razor and puts it in her hand] There's the broom!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Go now, while it is light--to the barn--and-- [Whispers something

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: in her ear.]

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: [Awake] Thank you! Now I shall have rest! But tell me first—-

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: that the foremost also receive the gift of grace. Say it, even if

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: you don't believe it.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: The foremost? No, I can't do that!--But wait--Miss Julia--I

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: know! You are no longer among the foremost--now when you are among

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the--last!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: That's right. I am among the last of all: I am the very

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: last. Oh!--But now I cannot go--Tell me once more that I must go!

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: No, now I can't do it either. I cannot!

SPEAKER: JULIA
TEXT: And those that are foremost shall be the last.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Don't think, don't think! Why, you are taking away my

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: strength, too, so that I become a coward--What? I thought I saw the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: bell moving!--To be that scared of a bell! Yes, but it isn't only

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: the bell--there is somebody behind it--a hand that makes it move—-

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Rings and rings, until you answer it--and then it's too late--then

SPEAKER: JEAN

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: [Shrinks together; then he straightens himself up] It's

SPEAKER: JEAN
