SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: THE STRONGER

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: INTRODUCTION

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Of Strindberg's dramatic works the briefest is "The Stronger." He

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: called it a "scene." It is a mere incident--what is called a

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: "sketch" on our vaudeville stage, and what the French so aptly have

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: named a "quart d'heure." And one of the two figures in the cast

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: remains silent throughout the action, thus turning the little play

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: practically into a monologue. Yet it has all the dramatic intensity

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: which we have come to look upon as one of the main characteristics

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: of Strindberg's work for the stage. It is quivering with mental

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: conflict, and because of this conflict human destinies may be seen

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: to change while we are watching. Three life stories are laid bare

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: during the few minutes we are listening to the seemingly aimless,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: yet so ominous, chatter of _Mrs. X._--and when she sallies forth at

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: last, triumphant in her sense of possession, we know as much about

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: her, her husband, and her rival, as if we had been reading a

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: three-volume novel about them.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Small as it is, the part of _Mrs. X._ would befit a "star," but an

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: actress of genius and discernment might prefer the dumb part of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: _Miss Y_. One thing is certain: that the latter character has few

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: equals in its demand on the performer's tact and skill and

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: imagination. This wordless opponent of _Mrs. X._ is another of

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: those vampire characters which Strindberg was so fond of drawing,

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: and it is on her the limelight is directed with merciless

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: persistency.

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: "The Stronger" was first published in 1890, as part of the

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: collection of miscellaneous writings which their author named

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: "Things Printed and Unprinted." The present English version was

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: made by me some years ago--in the summer of 1906--when I first

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: began to plan a Strindberg edition for this country. At that time

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: it appeared in the literary supplement of the _New York Evening

SPEAKER: JEAN
TEXT: Post_.

TEXT: THE STRONGER

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: "Blame that cook who can't learn how to make coffee." Or: "The

SPEAKER: MRS

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: Then there is a draught through the floor and his feet get cold:

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: "Gee, but it's freezing, and those blanked idiots don't even know

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: enough to keep the house warm." [She rubs the sole of one slipper

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: against the instep of the other.]

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: X. And then he comes home and has to hunt for his slippers--

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: Mary has pushed them under the bureau. Well, perhaps it is not

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: right to be making fun of one's own husband. He's pretty good for

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: all that--a real dear little hubby, that's what he is. You should

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: have such a husband--what are you laughing at? Can't you tell?

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: Then, you see, I know he is faithful. Yes, I know, for he has told

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: me himself--what in the world makes you giggle like that? That

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: nasty Betty tried to get him away from me while I was on the road—-

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: can you think of anything more infamous? [Pause] But I'd have

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: scratched the eyes out of her face, that's what I'd have done if I

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: had been at home when she tried it. [Pause] I'm glad Bob told me

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: all about it, so I didn't have to hear it first from somebody else.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: know why it is, but all women seem to be crazy after my husband. It

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: must be because they imagine his government position gives him

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: something to say about the engagements. Perhaps you've tried it

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: yourself--you may have set your traps for him, too? Yes, I don't

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: trust you very far--but I know he never cared for you--and then I

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: have been thinking you rather had a grudge against him.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: X. Amèlia, spend the evening with us, won't you? Just to show

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: that you are not angry--not with me, at least. I cannot tell

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: exactly why, but it seems so awfully unpleasant to have you--you

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: for an enemy. Perhaps because I got in your way that time

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: X. [Thoughtfully] It was so peculiar, the way our acquaintance--

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: why, I was afraid of you when I first met you; so afraid that I did

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: not dare to let you out of sight. It didn't matter where I tried to

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: go--I always found myself near you. I didn't have the courage to be

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: your enemy--and so I became your friend. But there was always

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: something discordant in the air when you called at our home, for I

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: saw that my husband didn't like you--and it annoyed me just as it

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: does when a dress won't fit. I tried my very best to make him

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: appear friendly to you at least, but I couldn't move him--not until

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: you were engaged. Then you two became such fast friends that it

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: almost looked as if you had not dared to show your real feelings

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: before, when it was not safe--and later--let me see, now! I didn't

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: get jealous--strange, was it not? And I remember the baptism--you

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: were acting as godmother, and I made him kiss you--and he did, but

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: both of you looked terribly embarrassed--that is, I didn't think of

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: it then--or afterwards, even--I never thought of it—-till--_now_!

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: uttered a single word all this time. You've just let me go on

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: talking. You've been sitting there staring at me only, and your

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: eyes have drawn out of me all these thoughts which were lying in me

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: like silk in a cocoon--thoughts--bad thoughts maybe--let me think.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: Why did you break your engagement? Why have you never called on us

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: afterward? Why don't you want to be with us to-night?

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: X. No, you don't need to say anything at all. All is clear to

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: me now. So, that's the reason of it all. Yes, yes! Everything fits

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: together now. Shame on you! I don't want to sit at the same table

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: with you. [Moves her things to another table] That's why I must put

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: those hateful tulips on his slippers--because you love them.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: summer in the mountains--because you can't bear the salt smell of

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: the ocean; that's why my boy had to be called Eskil--because that

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: was your father's name; that's why I had to wear your colour, and

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: read your books, and eat your favourite dishes, and drink your

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: drinks--this chocolate, for instance; that's why--great heavens!--

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: it's terrible to think of it--it's terrible! Everything was forced

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: on me by you—-even your passions. Your soul bored itself into mine

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: as a worm into an apple, and it ate and ate, and burrowed and

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: burrowed, till nothing was left but the outside shell and a little

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: black dust. I wanted to run away from you, but I couldn't. You were

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: always on hand like a snake with your black eyes to charm me--I

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: felt how my wings beat the air only to drag me down--I was in the

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: water, with my feet tied together, and the harder I worked with my

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: arms, the further down I went--down, down, till I sank to the

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: bottom, where you lay in wait like a monster crab to catch me with

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: your claws--and now I'm there! Shame on you! How I hate you, hate

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: you, hate you! But you, you just sit there, silent and calm and

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: indifferent, whether the moon is new or full; whether it's

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: Christmas or mid-summer; whether other people are happy or unhappy.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: You are incapable of hatred, and you don't know how to love. As a

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: cat in front of a mouse-hole, you are sitting there!--you can't

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: drag your prey out, and you can't pursue it, but you can outwait

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: it. Here you sit in this corner--do you know they've nicknamed it

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: "the mouse-trap" on your account? Here you read the papers to see

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: if anybody is in trouble, or if anybody is about to be discharged

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: from the theatre. Here you watch your victims and calculate your

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: chances and take your tributes. Poor Amèlia! Do you know, I pity

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: you all the same, for I know you are unhappy--unhappy as one who

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: has been wounded, and malicious because you are wounded. I ought to

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: be angry with you, but really I can't--you are so small after all--

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: and as to Bob, why that does not bother me in the least. What does

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: it matter to me anyhow? If you or somebody else taught me to drink

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: chocolate--what of that? [Takes a spoonful of chocolate; then

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: sententiously] They say chocolate is very wholesome. And if I have

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: learned from you how to dress--_tant mieux_!--it has only given me

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: a stronger hold on my husband--and you have lost where I have

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: gained. Yes, judging by several signs, I think you have lost him

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: already. Of course, you meant me to break with him--as you did, and

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: as you are now regretting--but, you see, _I_ never would do that.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: It won't do to be narrow-minded, you know. And why should I take

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: only what nobody else wants? Perhaps, after all, I am the stronger

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: now. You never got anything from me; you merely gave--and thus

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: happened to me what happened to the thief--I had what you missed

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: when you woke up. How explain in any other way that, in your hand,

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: everything proved worthless and useless? You were never able to

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: keep a man's love, in spite of your tulips and your passions--and I

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: could; you could never learn the art of living from the books--as I

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: learned it; you bore no little Eskil, although that was your

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: father's name. And why do you keep silent always and everywhere--

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: silent, ever silent? I used to think it was because you were so

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: strong; and maybe the simple truth was you never had anything to

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: say--because you were unable to-think! [Rises and picks up the

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: slippers] I'm going home now--I'll take the tulips with me—-your

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: tulips. You couldn't learn anything from others; you couldn't bend

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: and so you broke like a dry stem--and I didn't. Thank you, Amèlia,

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: for all your instructions. I thank you that you have taught me how

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: to love my husband. Now I'm going home--to him! [Exit.]

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: CREDITORS

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: INTRODUCTION

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: This is one of the three plays which Strindberg placed at the head

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: of his dramatic production during the middle ultra-naturalistic

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: period, the other two being "The Father" and "Miss Julia." It is,

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: in many ways, one of the strongest he ever produced. Its rarely

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: excelled unity of construction, its tremendous dramatic tension,

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: and its wonderful psychological analysis combine to make it a

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: masterpiece.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: In Swedish its name is "Fordringsägare." This indefinite form may

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: be either singular or plural, but it is rarely used except as a

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: plural. And the play itself makes it perfectly clear that the

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: proper translation of its title is "Creditors," for under this

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: aspect appear both the former and the present husband of _Tekla_.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: One of the main objects of the play is to reveal her indebtedness

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: first to one and then to the other of these men, while all the

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: time she is posing as a person of original gifts.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: I have little doubt that Strindberg, at the time he wrote this

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: play--and bear in mind that this happened only a year before he

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: finally decided to free himself from an impossible marriage by an

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: appeal to the law--believed _Tekla_ to be fairly representative of

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: womanhood in general. The utter unreasonableness of such a view

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: need hardly be pointed out, and I shall waste no time on it. A

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: question more worthy of discussion is whether the figure of _Tekla_

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: be true to life merely as the picture of a personality--as one out

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: of numerous imaginable variations on a type decided not by sex but

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: by faculties and qualities. And the same question may well be

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: raised in regard to the two men, both of whom are evidently

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: intended to win our sympathy: one as the victim of a fate stronger

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: than himself, and the other as the conqueror of adverse and

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: humiliating circumstances.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: Personally, I am inclined to doubt whether a _Tekla_ can be found

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: in the flesh--and even if found, she might seem too exceptional to

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: gain acceptance as a real individuality. It must be remembered,

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: however, that, in spite of his avowed realism, Strindberg did not

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: draw his men and women in the spirit generally designated as

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: impressionistic; that is, with the idea that they might step

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: straight from his pages into life and there win recognition as

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: human beings of familiar aspect. His realism is always mixed with

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: idealism; his figures are always "doctored," so to speak. And they

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: have been thus treated in order to enable their creator to drive

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: home the particular truth he is just then concerned with.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: Consciously or unconsciously he sought to produce what may be

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: designated as "pure cultures" of certain human qualities. But

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: these he took great pains to arrange in their proper psychological

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: settings, for mental and moral qualities, like everything else,

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: run in groups that are more or less harmonious, if not exactly

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: homogeneous. The man with a single quality, like Molière's

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: _Harpagon_, was much too primitive and crude for Strindberg's art,

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: as he himself rightly asserted in his preface to "Miss Julia."

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: When he wanted to draw the genius of greed, so to speak, he did it

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: by setting it in the midst of related qualities of a kind most

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: likely to be attracted by it.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: _Tekla_ is such a "pure culture" of a group of naturally correlated

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: mental and moral qualities and functions and tendencies--of a

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: personality built up logically around a dominant central note.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: There are within all of us many personalities, some of which

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: remain for ever potentialities. But it is conceivable that any one

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: of them, under circumstances different from those in which we have

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: been living, might have developed into its severely logical

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: consequence--or, if you please, into a human being that would be

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: held abnormal if actually encountered.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: This is exactly what Strindberg seems to have done time and again,

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: both in his middle and final periods, in his novels as well as in

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: his plays. In all of us a _Tekla_, an _Adolph_, a _Gustav_--or a

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: _Jean_ and a _Miss Julia_--lie more or less dormant. And if we search

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: our souls unsparingly, I fear the result can only be an admission

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: that--had the needed set of circumstances been provided--we might

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: have come unpleasantly close to one of those Strindbergian

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: creatures which we are now inclined to reject as unhuman.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: Here we have the secret of what I believe to be the great Swedish

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: dramatist's strongest hold on our interest. How could it otherwise

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: happen that so many critics, of such widely differing temperaments,

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: have recorded identical feelings as springing from a study of his

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: work: on one side an active resentment, a keen unwillingness to

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: be interested; on the other, an attraction that would not be denied

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: in spite of resolute resistance to it! For Strindberg _does_ hold

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: us, even when we regret his power of doing so. And no one familiar

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: with the conclusions of modern psychology could imagine such a

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: paradox possible did not the object of our sorely divided feelings

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: provide us with something that our minds instinctively recognise as

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: true to life in some way, and for that reason valuable to the art of

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: living.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: There are so many ways of presenting truth. Strindberg's is only

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: one of them--and not the one commonly employed nowadays. Its main

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: fault lies perhaps in being too intellectual, too abstract. For

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: while Strindberg was intensely emotional, and while this fact

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: colours all his writings, he could only express himself through

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: his reason. An emotion that would move another man to murder would

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: precipitate Strindberg into merciless analysis of his own or

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: somebody else's mental and moral make-up. At any rate, I do not

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: proclaim his way of presenting truth as the best one of all

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: available. But I suspect that this decidedly strange way of

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: Strindberg's--resulting in such repulsively superior beings as

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: _Gustav_, or in such grievously inferior ones as _Adolph_--may come

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: nearer the temper and needs of the future than do the ways of much

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: more plausible writers. This does not need to imply that the

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: future will imitate Strindberg. But it may ascertain what he aimed

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: at doing, and then do it with a degree of perfection which he, the

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: pioneer, could never hope to attain.

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: CREDITORS

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: A TRAGICOMEDY

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: PERSONS

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: TEKLA

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: ADOLPH, her husband, a painter

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: GUSTAV, her divorced husband, a high-school teacher (who is

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: travelling under an assumed name)

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: SCENE

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: door opening on a veranda, beyond which is seen a landscape. To

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: the right of the door stands a table with newspapers on it. There

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: is a chair on the left side of the stage. To the right of the

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: table stands a sofa. A door on the right leads to an adjoining

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: room.)

SPEAKER: MRS
TEXT: the right.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [At work on a wax figure on a miniature modelling stand;

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: his crutches are placed beside him]--and for all this I have to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: thank you!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Smoking a cigar] Oh, nonsense!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Why, certainly! During the first days after my wife had

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: gone, I lay helpless on a sofa and did nothing but long for her.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: It was as if she had taken away my crutches with her, so that I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: couldn't move from the spot. When I had slept a couple of days, I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: seemed to come to, and began to pull myself together. My head

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: calmed down after having been working feverishly. Old thoughts

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: from days gone by bobbed up again. The desire to work and the

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: instinct for creation came back. My eyes recovered their faculty

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: of quick and straight vision--and then you showed up.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I admit you were in a miserable condition when I first met

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you, and you had to use your crutches when you walked, but this is

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: not to say that my presence has been the cause of your recovery.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: You needed a rest, and you had a craving for masculine company.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, that's true enough, like everything you say. Once I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: used to have men for friends, but I thought them superfluous after

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I married, and I felt quite satisfied with the one I had chosen.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Later I was drawn into new circles and made a lot of acquaintances,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: but my wife was jealous of them--she wanted to keep me to herself:

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: worse still--she wanted also to keep my friends to herself. And so

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I was left alone with my own jealousy.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, you have a strong tendency toward that kind of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: disease.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I was afraid of losing her--and I tried to prevent it.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: There is nothing strange in that. But I was never afraid that she

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: might be deceiving me--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, that's what married men are never afraid of.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, isn't it queer? What I really feared was that her

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: friends would get such an influence over her that they would begin

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: to exercise some kind of indirect power over me--and _that_ is

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: something I couldn't bear.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: So your ideas don't agree--yours and your wife's?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Seeing that you have heard so much already, I may as well

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: tell you everything. My wife has an independent nature--what are

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: you smiling at?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Go on! She has an independent nature--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Which cannot accept anything from me--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: But from everybody else.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [After a pause] Yes.--And it looked as if she especially

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: hated my ideas because they were mine, and not because there was

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: anything wrong about them. For it used to happen quite often that

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: she advanced ideas that had once been mine, and that she stood up

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: for them as her own. Yes, it even happened that friends of mine

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: gave her ideas which they had taken directly from me, and then

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: they seemed all right. Everything was all right except what came

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: from me.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Which means that you are not entirely happy?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh yes, I am happy. I have the one I wanted, and I have

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: never wanted anybody else.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And you have never wanted to be free?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, I can't say that I have. Oh, well, sometimes I have

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: imagined that it might seem like a rest to be free. But the moment

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: she leaves me, I begin to long for her--long for her as for my own

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: arms and legs. It is queer that sometimes I have a feeling that

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: she is nothing in herself, but only a part of myself--an organ

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: that can take away with it my will, my very desire to live. It

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: seems almost as if I had deposited with her that centre of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: vitality of which the anatomical books tell us.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Perhaps, when we get to the bottom of it, that is just

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: what has happened.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: How could it be so? Is she not an independent being, with

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: thoughts of her own? And when I met her I was nothing--a child of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: an artist whom she undertook to educate.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: But later you developed her thoughts and educated her,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: didn't you?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, she stopped growing and I pushed on.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, isn't it strange that her "authoring" seemed to fall

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: off after her first book--or that it failed to improve, at least?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: But that first time she had a subject which wrote itself--for I

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: understand she used her former husband for a model. You never knew

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: him, did you? They say he was an idiot.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I never knew him, as he was away for six months at a time.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: But he must have been an arch-idiot, judging by her picture of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: him. [Pause] And you may feel sure that the picture was correct.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I do!--But why did she ever take him?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Because she didn't know him well enough. Of course, you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: never _do_ get acquainted until afterward!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And for that reason one ought not to marry until--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: afterward.--And he was a tyrant, of course?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Of course?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Why, so are all married men. [Feeling his way] And you not

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the least.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I? Who let my wife come and go as she pleases--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, that's nothing. You couldn't lock her up, could you?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: But do you like her to stay away whole nights?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, really, I don't.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: There, you see! [With a change of tactics] And to tell the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: truth, it would only make you ridiculous to like it.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Ridiculous? Can a man be ridiculous because he trusts his

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: wife?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Of course he can. And it's just what you are already--and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: thoroughly at that!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Convulsively] I! It's what I dread most of all--and

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: there's going to be a change.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Don't get excited now--or you'll have another attack.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: But why isn't she ridiculous when I stay out all night?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, why? Well, it's nothing that concerns you, but that's

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the way it is. And while you are trying to figure out why, the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: mishap has already occurred.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: What mishap?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: However, the first husband was a tyrant, and she took him

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: only to get her freedom. You see, a girl cannot have freedom

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: except by providing herself with a chaperon--or what we call a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: husband.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Of course not.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And now you are the chaperon.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Since you are her husband.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Am I not right?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Uneasily] I don't know. You live with a woman for years,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and you never stop to analyse her, or your relationship with her,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and then--then you begin to think--and there you are!--Gustav, you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: are my friend. The only male friend I have. During this last week

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: you have given me courage to live again. It is as if your own

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: magnetism had been poured into me. Like a watchmaker, you have

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: fixed the works in my head and wound up the spring again. Can't

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: you hear, yourself, how I think more clearly and speak more to the

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: point? And to myself at least it seems as if my voice had

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: recovered its ring.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: So it seems to me also. And why is that?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I shouldn't wonder if you grew accustomed to lower your

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: voice in talking to women. I know at least that Tekla always used

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: to accuse me of shouting.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And so you toned down your voice and accepted the rule of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the slipper?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: That isn't quite the way to put it. [After some

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: reflection] I think it is even worse than that. But let us talk of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: something else!--What was I saying?--Yes, you came here, and you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: enabled me to see my art in its true light. Of course, for some

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: time I had noticed my growing lack of interest in painting, as it

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: didn't seem to offer me the proper medium for the expression of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: what I wanted to bring out. But when you explained all this to me,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and made it clear why painting must fail as a timely outlet for

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: the creative instinct, then I saw the light at last--and I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: realised that hereafter it would not be possible for me to express

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: myself by means of colour only.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Are you quite sure now that you cannot go on painting--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: that you may not have a relapse?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Perfectly sure! For I have tested myself. When I went to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: bed that night after our talk, I rehearsed your argument point by

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: point, and I knew you had it right. But when I woke up from a good

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: night's sleep and my head was clear again, then it came over me in

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: a flash that you might be mistaken after all. And I jumped out of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: bed and got hold of my brushes and paints--but it was no use!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Every trace of illusion was gone--it was nothing but smears of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: paint, and I quaked at the thought of having believed, and having

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: made others believe, that a painted canvas could be anything but a

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: painted canvas. The veil had fallen from my eyes, and it was just

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: as impossible for me to paint any more as it was to become a child

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: again.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And then you saw that the realistic tendency of our day,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: its craving for actuality and tangibility, could only find its

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: proper form in sculpture, which gives you body, extension in all

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: three dimensions--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Vaguely] The three dimensions--oh yes, body, in a word!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And then you became a sculptor yourself. Or rather, you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: have been one all your life, but you had gone astray, and nothing

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: was needed but a guide to put you on the right road--Tell me, do

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you experience supreme joy now when you are at work?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Now I am living!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: May I see what you are doing?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: A female figure.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Without a model? And so lifelike at that!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Apathetically] Yes, but it resembles somebody. It is

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: remarkable that this woman seems to have become a part of my body

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: as I of hers.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, that's not so very remarkable. Do you know what

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: transfusion is?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Of blood? Yes.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And you seem to have bled yourself a little too much. When

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I look at the figure here I comprehend several things which I

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: merely guessed before. You have loved her tremendously!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, to such an extent that I couldn't tell whether she

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: was I or I she. When she is smiling, I smile also. When she is

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: weeping, I weep. And when she--can you imagine anything like it?--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: when she was giving life to our child--I felt the birth pangs

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: within myself.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Do you know, my dear friend--I hate to speak of it, but

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you are already showing the first symptoms of epilepsy.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Agitated] I! How can you tell?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Because I have watched the symptoms in a younger brother

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of mine who had been worshipping Venus a little too excessively.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: How--how did it show itself--that thing you spoke of?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and ADOLPH listens so intently that, unconsciously, he imitates

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: many of GUSTAV'S gestures.]

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: It was dreadful to witness, and if you don't feel strong

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: enough I won't inflict a description of it on you.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Nervously] Yes, go right on--just go on!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, the boy happened to marry an innocent little

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: creature with curls, and eyes like a turtle-dove; with the face of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: a child and the pure soul of an angel. But nevertheless she

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: managed to usurp the male prerogative--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: What is that?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Initiative, of course. And with the result that the angel

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: nearly carried him off to heaven. But first he had to be put on

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the cross and made to feel the nails in his flesh. It was

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: horrible!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Breathlessly] Well, what happened?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Lingering on each word] We might be sitting together

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: talking, he and I--and when I had been speaking for a while his

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: face would turn white as chalk, his arms and legs would grow

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: stiff, and his thumbs became twisted against the palms of his

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: hands--like this. [He illustrates the movement and it is imitated

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: by ADOLPH] Then his eyes became bloodshot, and he began to chew--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: like this. [He chews, and again ADOLPH imitates him] The saliva

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: was rattling in his throat. His chest was squeezed together as if

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: it had been closed in a vice. The pupils of his eyes flickered

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: like gas-jets. His tongue beat the saliva into a lather, and he

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: sank--slowly--down--backward--into the chair--as if he were

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: drowning. And then--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [In a whisper] Stop now!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And then--Are you not feeling well?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Gets a glass of water for him] There: drink now. And

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: we'll talk of something else.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Feebly] Thank you! Please go on!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well--when he came to he couldn't remember anything at

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: all. He had simply lost consciousness. Has that ever happened to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, I have had attacks of vertigo now and then, but my

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: physician says it's only anaemia.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, that's the beginning of it, you know. But, believe

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: me, it will end in epilepsy if you don't take care of yourself.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: What can I do?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: To begin with, you will have to observe complete

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: abstinence.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: For how long?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: For half a year at least.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I cannot do it. That would upset our married life.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Good-bye to you then!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Covers up the wax figure] I cannot do it!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Can you not save your own life?--But tell me, as you have

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: already given me so much of your confidence--is there no other

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: canker, no secret wound, that troubles you? For it is very rare to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: find only one cause of discord, as life is so full of variety and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: so fruitful in chances for false relationships. Is there not a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: corpse in your cargo that you are trying to hide from yourself?--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: For instance, you said a minute ago that you have a child which

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: has been left in other people's care. Why don't you keep it with

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: My wife doesn't want us to do so.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And her reason? Speak up now!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Because, when it was about three years old, it began to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: look like him, her former husband.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well? Have you seen her former husband?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, never. I have only had a casual glance at a very poor

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: portrait of him, and then I couldn't detect the slightest

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: resemblance.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh, portraits are never like the original, and, besides,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: he might have changed considerably since it was made. However, I

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: hope it hasn't aroused any suspicions in you?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Not at all. The child was born a year after our marriage,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and the husband was abroad when I first met Tekla--it happened

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: right here, in this very house even, and that's why we come here

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: every summer.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, then there can be no cause for suspicion. And you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: wouldn't have had any reason to trouble yourself anyhow, for the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: children of a widow who marries again often show a likeness to her

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: dead husband. It is annoying, of course, and that's why they used

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: to burn all widows in India, as you know.--But tell me: have you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: ever felt jealous of him--of his memory? Would it not sicken you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: to meet him on a walk and hear him, with his eyes on your Tekla,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: use the word "we" instead of "I"?--We!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I cannot deny that I have been pursued by that very

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: thought.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: There now!--And you'll never get rid of it. There are

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: discords in this life which can never be reduced to harmony. For

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: this reason you had better put wax in your ears and go to work. If

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you work, and grow old, and pile masses of new impressions on the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: hatches, then the corpse will stay quiet in the hold.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Pardon me for interrupting you, but--it is wonderful how

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: you resemble Tekla now and then while you are talking. You have a

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: way of blinking one eye as if you were taking aim with a gun, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: your eyes have the same influence on me as hers have at times.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, really?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: And now you said that "no, really" in the same indifferent

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: way that she does. She also has the habit of saying "no, really"

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: quite often.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Perhaps we are distantly related, seeing that all human

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: beings are said to be of one family. At any rate, it will be

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: interesting to make your wife's acquaintance to see if what you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: say is true.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: And do you know, she never takes an expression from me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: She seems rather to avoid my vocabulary, and I have never caught

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: her using any of my gestures. And yet people as a rule develop

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: what is called "marital resemblance."

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And do you know why this has not happened in your case?--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: That woman has never loved you.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: What do you mean?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I hope you will excuse what I am saying--but woman's love

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: consists in taking, in receiving, and one from whom she takes

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: nothing does not have her love. She has never loved you!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Don't you think her capable of loving more than once?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, for we cannot be deceived more than once. Then our

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: eyes are opened once for all. You have never been deceived, and so

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you had better beware of those that have. They are dangerous, I

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: tell you.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Your words pierce me like knife thrusts, and I fool as if

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: something were being severed within me, but I cannot help it. And

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: this cutting brings a certain relief, too. For it means the

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: pricking of ulcers that never seemed to ripen.--She has never

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: loved me!--Why, then, did she ever take me?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Tell me first how she came to take you, and whether it was

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you who took her or she who took you?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Heaven only knows if I can tell at all!--How did it

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: happen? Well, it didn't come about in one day.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Would you like to have me tell you how it did happen?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: That's more than you can do.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh, by using the information about yourself and your wife

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: that you have given me, I think I can reconstruct the whole event.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Listen now, and you'll hear. [In a dispassionate tone, almost

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: humorously] The husband had gone abroad to study, and she was

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: alone. At first her freedom seemed rather pleasant. Then came a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: sense of vacancy, for I presume she was pretty empty when she had

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: lived by herself for a fortnight. Then _he_ appeared, and by and by

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the vacancy was filled up. By comparison the absent one seemed to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: fade out, and for the simple reason that he was at a distance--you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: know the law about the square of the distance? But when they felt

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: their passions stirring, then came fear--of themselves, of their

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: consciences, of him. For protection they played brother and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: sister. And the more their feelings smacked of the flesh, the more

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: they tried to make their relationship appear spiritual.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Brother and sister? How could you know that?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I guessed it. Children are in the habit of playing papa

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: and mamma, but when they grow up they play brother and sister--in

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: order to hide what should be hidden!--And then they took the vow

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of chastity--and then they played hide-and-seek--until they got

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: in a dark corner where they were sure of not being seen by

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: anybody. [With mock severity] But they felt that there was _one_

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: whose eye reached them in the darkness--and they grew frightened--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: and their fright raised the spectre of the absent one--his figure

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: began to assume immense proportions--it became metamorphosed:

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: turned into a nightmare that disturbed their amorous slumbers; a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: creditor who knocked at all doors. Then they saw his black hand

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: between their own as these sneaked toward each other across the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: table; and they heard his grating voice through that stillness of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the night that should have been broken only by the beating of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: their own pulses. He did not prevent them from possessing each

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: other but he spoiled their happiness. And when they became aware

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of his invisible interference with their happiness; when they took

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: flight at last--a vain flight from the memories that pursued them,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: from the liability they had left behind, from the public opinion

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: they could not face--and when they found themselves without the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: strength needed to carry their own guilt, then they had to send

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: out into the fields for a scapegoat to be sacrificed. They were

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: free-thinkers, but they did not have the courage to step forward

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: and speak openly to him the words: "We love each other!" To sum it

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: up, they were cowards, and so the tyrant had to be slaughtered. Is

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: that right?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, but you forget that she educated me, that she filled

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: my head with new thoughts--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I have not forgotten it. But tell me: why could she not

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: educate the other man also--into a free-thinker?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, he was an idiot!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh, of course--he was an idiot! But that's rather an

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: ambiguous term, and, as pictured in her novel, his idiocy seems

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: mainly to have consisted in failure to understand her. Pardon me a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: question: but is your wife so very profound after all? I have

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: discovered nothing profound in her writings.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Neither have I.--But then I have also to confess a certain

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: difficulty in understanding her. It is as if the cogs of our brain

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: wheels didn't fit into each other, and as if something went to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: pieces in my head when I try to comprehend her.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Maybe you are an idiot, too?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I don't _think_ so! And it seems to me all the time as if

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: she were in the wrong--Would you care to read this letter, for

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: instance, which I got today?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Glancing through the letter] Hm! The handwriting seems

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: strangely familiar.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Rather masculine, don't you think?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, I know at least _one_ man who writes that kind of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: hand--She addresses you as "brother." Are you still playing

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: comedy to each other? And do you never permit yourselves any

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: greater familiarity in speaking to each other?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, it seems to me that all mutual respect is lost in that

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: way.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And is it to make you respect her that she calls herself

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: your sister?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I want to respect her more than myself. I want her to be

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: the better part of my own self.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Why don't you be that better part yourself? Would it be

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: less convenient than to permit somebody else to fill the part? Do

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you want to place yourself beneath your wife?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, I do. I take a pleasure in never quite reaching up to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: her. I have taught her to swim, for example, and now I enjoy

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: hearing her boast that she surpasses me both in skill and daring.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: To begin with, I merely pretended to be awkward and timid in order

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: to raise her courage. And so it ended with my actually being her

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: inferior, more of a coward than she. It almost seemed to me as if

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: she had actually taken my courage away from me.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Have you taught her anything else?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes--but it must stay between us--I have taught her how to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: spell, which she didn't know before. But now, listen: when she

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: took charge of our domestic correspondence, I grew out of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: habit of writing. And think of it: as the years passed on, lack of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: practice made me forget a little here and there of my grammar. But

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: do you think she recalls that I was the one who taught her at the

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: start? No--and so I am "the idiot," of course.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: So you _are_ an idiot already?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, it's just a joke, of course!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Of course! But this is clear cannibalism, I think. Do you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: know what's behind that sort of practice? The savages eat their

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: enemies in order to acquire their useful qualities. And this woman

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: has been eating your soul, your courage, your knowledge--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: And my faith! It was I who urged her to write her first

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: book--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Making a face] Oh-h-h!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: It was I who praised her, even when I found her stuff

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: rather poor. It was I who brought her into literary circles where

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: she could gather honey from our most ornamental literary flowers.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: It was I who used my personal influence to keep the critics from

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: her throat. It was I who blew her faith in herself into flame;

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: blew on it until I lost my own breath. I gave, gave, gave--until I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: had nothing left for myself. Do you know--I'll tell you everything

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: now--do you know I really believe--and the human soul is so

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: peculiarly constituted--I believe that when my artistic successes

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: seemed about to put her in the shadow--as well as her reputation--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: then I tried to put courage into her by belittling myself, and by

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: making my own art seem inferior to hers. I talked so long about

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: the insignificant part played by painting on the whole--talked so

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: long about it, and invented so many reasons to prove what I said,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: that one fine day I found myself convinced of its futility. So all

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: you had to do was to breathe on a house of cards.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Pardon me for recalling what you said at the beginning of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: our talk--that she had never taken anything from you.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: She doesn't nowadays. Because there is nothing more to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: take.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: The snake being full, it vomits now.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Perhaps she has been taking a good deal more from me than

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I have been aware of?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: You can be sure of that. She took when you were not

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: looking, and that is called theft.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Perhaps she never did educate me?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: But you her? In all likelihood! But it was her trick to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: make it appear the other way to you. May I ask how she set about

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: educating you?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, first of all--hm!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Well, I--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, we were speaking of her.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Really, I cannot tell now.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Do you see!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: However--she devoured my faith also, and so I sank further

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and further down, until you came along and gave me a new faith.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Smiling] In sculpture?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Doubtfully] Yes.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And have you really faith in it? In this abstract,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: antiquated art that dates back to the childhood of civilisation?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Do you believe that you can obtain your effect by pure form--by

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the three dimensions--tell me? That you can reach the practical

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: mind of our own day, and convey an illusion to it, without the use

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of colour--without colour, mind you--do you really believe that?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Crushed] No!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, I don't either.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Why, then, did you say you did?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Because I pitied you.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, I am to be pitied! For now I am bankrupt! Finished!--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: And worst of all: not even she is left to me!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, what could you do with her?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, she would be to me what God was before I became an

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: atheist: an object that might help me to exercise my sense of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: veneration.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Bury your sense of veneration and let something else grow

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: on top of it. A little wholesome scorn, for instance.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I cannot live without having something to respect--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Slave!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: --without a woman to respect and worship!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh, HELL! Then you had better take back your God--if you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: needs must have something to kow-tow to! You're a fine atheist,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: with all that superstition about woman still in you! You're a fine

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: free-thinker, who dare not think freely about the dear ladies! Do

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you know what that incomprehensible, sphinx-like, profound

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: something in your wife really is? It is sheer stupidity!--Look

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: here: she cannot even distinguish between th and t. And that, you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: know, means there is something wrong with the mechanism. When you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: look at the case, it looks like a chronometer, but the works

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: inside are those of an ordinary cheap watch.--Nothing but the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: skirts-that's all! Put trousers on her, give her a pair of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: moustaches of soot under her nose, then take a good, sober look at

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: her, and listen to her in the same manner: you'll find the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: instrument has another sound to it. A phonograph, and nothing

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: else--giving yon back your own words, or those of other people--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: and always in diluted form. Have you ever looked at a naked woman--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: oh yes, yes, of course! A youth with over-developed breasts; an

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: under-developed man; a child that has shot up to full height and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: then stopped growing in other respects; one who is chronically

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: anaemic: what can you expect of such a creature?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Supposing all that to be true--how can it be possible that

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I still think her my equal?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Hallucination--the hypnotising power of skirts! Or--the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: two of you may actually have become equals. The levelling process

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: has been finished. Her capillarity has brought the water in both

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: tubes to the same height.--Tell me [taking out his watch]: our

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: talk has now lasted six hours, and your wife ought soon to be

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: here. Don't you think we had better stop, so that you can get a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: rest?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, don't leave me! I don't dare to be alone!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh, for a little while only--and then the lady will come.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, she is coming!--It's all so queer! I long for her,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: but I am afraid of her. She pets me, she is tender to me, but

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: there is suffocation in her kisses--something that pulls and

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: numbs. And I feel like a circus child that is being pinched by the

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: clown in order that it may look rosy-cheeked when it appears

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: before the public.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I feel very sorry for you, my friend. Without being a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: physician, I can tell that you are a dying man. It is enough to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: look at your latest pictures in order to see that.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: You think so? How can you see it?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Your colour is watery blue, anaemic, thin, so that the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: cadaverous yellow of the canvas shines through. And it impresses

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: me as if your own hollow, putty-coloured checks were showing

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: beneath--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, stop, stop!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, this is not only my personal opinion. Have you read

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: to-day's paper?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Shrinking] No!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: It's on the table here.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Reaching for the paper without daring to take hold of it]

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Do they speak of it there?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Read it--or do you want me to read it to you?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I'll leave you, if you want me to.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, no, no!--I don't know--it seems as if I were beginning

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: to hate you, and yet I cannot let you go.--You drag me out of the

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: hole into which I have fallen, but no sooner do you get me on firm

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: ice, than you knock me on the head and shove me into the water

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: again. As long as my secrets were my own, I had still something

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: left within me, but now I am quite empty. There is a canvas by an

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Italian master, showing a scene of torture--a saint whose

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: intestines are being torn out of him and rolled on the axle of a

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: windlass. The martyr is watching himself grow thinner and thinner,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: while the roll on the axle grows thicker.--Now it seems to me as

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: if you had swelled out since you began to dig in me; and when you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: leave, you'll carry away my vitals with you, and leave nothing but

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: an empty shell behind.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: How you do let your fancy run away with you!--And

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: besides, your wife is bringing back your heart.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, not since you have burned her to ashes. Everything is

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: in ashes where you have passed along: my art, my love, my hope, my

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: faith!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: All of it was pretty nearly finished before I came along.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, but it might have been saved. Now it's too late--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: incendiary!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: We have cleared some ground only. Now we'll sow in the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: ashes.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I hate you! I curse you!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Good symptoms! There is still some strength left in you.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And now I'll pull you up on the ice again. Listen now! Do you want

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: to listen to me, and do you want to obey me?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Do with me what you will--I'll obey you!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Rising] Look at me!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Looking at GUSTAV] Now you are looking at me again with

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: that other pair of eyes which attracts me.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And listen to me!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, but speak of yourself. Don't talk of me any longer: I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: am like an open wound and cannot bear being touched.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, there is nothing to say about me. I am a teacher of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: dead languages, and a widower--that's all! Take my hand.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: What terrible power there must be in you! It feels as if I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: were touching an electrical generator.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And bear in mind that I have been as weak as you are now.--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Stand up!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Rises, but keeps himself from falling only by throwing

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: his arms around the neck of GUSTAV] I am like a boneless baby, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: my brain seems to lie bare.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Take a turn across the floor!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I cannot!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Do what I say, or I'll strike you!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Straightening himself up] What are you saying?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I'll strike you, I said.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Leaping backward in a rage] You!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: That's it! Now you have got the blood into your head, and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: your self-assurance is awake. And now I'll give you some

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: electriticy: where is your wife?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Where is she?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: She is--at--a meeting.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Sure?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Absolutely!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: What kind of meeting?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, something relating to an orphan asylum.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Did you part as friends?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [With some hesitation] Not as friends.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: As enemies then!--What did you say that provoked her?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: You are terrible. I am afraid of you. How could you know?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: It's very simple: I possess three known factors, and with

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: their help I figure out the unknown one. What did you say to her?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I said--two words only, but they were dreadful, and I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: regret them--regret them very much.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Don't do it! Tell me now?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I said: "Old flirt!"

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: What more did you say?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Nothing at all.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, you did, but you have forgotten it--perhaps because

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you don't dare remember it. You have put it away in a secret

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: drawer, but you have got to open it now!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I can't remember!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: But I know. This is what you said: "You ought to be

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: ashamed of flirting when you are too old to have any more lovers!"

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Did I say that? I must have said it!--But how can you know

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: that I did?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I heard her tell the story on board the boat as I came

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: here.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: To whom?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: To four young men who formed her company. She is already

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: developing a taste for chaste young men, just like--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: But there is nothing wrong in that?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No more than in playing brother and sister when you are

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: papa and mamma.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: So you have seen her then?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, I have. But you have never seen her when you didn't--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I mean, when you were not present. And there's the reason, you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: see, why a husband can never really know his wife. Have you a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: portrait of her?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: aroused curiosity on his face.)

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: You were not present when this was taken?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Look at it. Does it bear much resemblance to the portrait

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you painted of her? Hardly any! The features are the same, but the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: expression is quite different. But you don't see this, because

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: your own picture of her creeps in between your eyes and this one.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Look at it now as a painter, without giving a thought to the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: original. What does it represent? Nothing, so far as I can see,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: but an affected coquette inviting somebody to come and play with

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: her. Do you notice this cynical line around the mouth which you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: are never allowed to see? Can you see that her eyes are seeking

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: out some man who is not you? Do you observe that her dress is cut

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: low at the neck, that her hair is done up in a different way, that

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: her sleeve has managed to slip back from her arm? Can you see?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes--now I see.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Look out, my boy!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: For what?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: For her revenge! Bear in mind that when you said she could

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: not attract a man, you struck at what to her is most sacred--the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: one thing above all others. If you had told her that she wrote

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: nothing but nonsense, she would have laughed at your poor taste.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: But as it is--believe me, it will not be her fault if her desire

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: for revenge has not already been satisfied.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I must know if it is so!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Find out!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Find out?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Watch--I'll assist you, if you want me to.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: As I am to die anyhow--it may as well come first as last!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: What am I to do?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: First of all a piece of information: has your wife any

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: vulnerable point?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Hardly! I think she must have nine lives, like a cat.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: There--that was the boat whistling at the landing--now

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: she'll soon be here.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Then I must go down and meet her.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, you are to stay here. You have to be impolite. If

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: her conscience is clear, you'll catch it until your ears tingle.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: If she is guilty, she'll come up and pet you.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Are you so sure of that?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Not quite, because a rabbit will sometimes turn and run in

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: loops, but I'll follow. My room is nest to this. [He points to the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: door on the right] There I shall take up my position and watch you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: while you are playing the game in here. But when you are done,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: we'll change parts: I'll enter the cage and do tricks with the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: snake while you stick to the key-hole. Then we meet in the park to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: compare notes. But keep your back stiff. And if you feel yourself

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: weakening, knock twice on the floor with a chair.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: All right!--But don't go away. I must be sure that you are

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: in the next room.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: You can be quite sure of that. But don't get scared

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: afterward, when you watch me dissecting a human soul and laying

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: out its various parts on the table. They say it is rather hard on

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: a beginner, but once you have seen it done, you never want to miss

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: it.--And be sure to remember one thing: not a word about having

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: met me, or having made any new acquaintance whatever while she was

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: away. Not one word! And I'll discover her weak point by myself.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Hush, she has arrived--she is in her room now. She's humming to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: herself. That means she is in a rage!--Now, straight in the back,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: please! And sit down on that chair over there, so that she has to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: sit here--then I can watch both of you at the same time.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: It's only fifteen minutes to dinner--and no new guests

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: have arrived--for I haven't heard the bell ring. That means we

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: shall be by ourselves--worse luck!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Are you weak?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I am nothing at all!--Yes, I am afraid of what is now

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: coming! But I cannot keep it from coming! The stone has been set

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: rolling--and it was not the first drop of water that started it--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: nor wad it the last one--but all of them together.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Let it roll then--for peace will come in no other way.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Good-bye for a while now! [Goes out]

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: photograph in his hand. Now he tears it up and flings the pieces

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: under the table. Then he sits down on a chair, pulls nervously at

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: his tie, runs his fingers through his hair, crumples his coat

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: lapel, and so on.)

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Enters, goes straight up to him and gives him a kiss; her

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: manner is friendly, frank, happy, and engaging] Hello, little

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: brother! How is he getting on?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Almost won over; speaking reluctantly and as if in jest]

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: What mischief have you been up to now that makes you come and kiss

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: me?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I'll tell you: I've spent an awful lot of money.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: You have had a good time then?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Very! But not exactly at that crèche meeting. That was

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: plain piffle, to tell the truth.--But what has little brother

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: found to divert himself with while his Pussy was away?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: somebody or sniffing something.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I've simply been bored.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: And no company at all?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Quite by myself.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Watching him; she sits down on the sofa] Who has been

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: sitting here? ADOLPH. Over there? Nobody.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: That's funny! The seat is still warm, and there is a hollow

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: here that looks as if it had been made by an elbow. Have you had

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: lady callers?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I? You don't believe it, do you?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But you blush. I think little brother is not telling the

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: truth. Come and tell Pussy now what he has on his conscience.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: resting in her lap.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: You're a little devil--do you know that?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, I don't know anything at all about myself.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: You never think about yourself, do you?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Sniffing and taking notes] I think of nothing but myself--

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I am a dreadful egoist. But what has made you turn so philosophical

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: all at once?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Put your hand on my forehead.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Prattling as if to a baby] Has he got ants in his head

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: again? Does he want me to take them away, does he? [Kisses him on

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: the forehead] There now! Is it all right now?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Now it's all right. [Pause]

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Well, tell me now what you have been doing to make the time

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: go? Have you painted anything?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, I am done with painting.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What? Done with painting?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, but don't scold me for it. How can I help it that I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: can't paint any longer!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What do you mean to do then?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I'll become a sculptor.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What a lot of brand new ideas again!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, but please don't scold! Look at that figure over

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: there.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Uncovering the wax figure] Well, I declare!--Who is that

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: meant for?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Guess!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Is it Pussy? Has he got no shame at all?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Is it like?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: How can I tell when there is no face?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, but there is so much else--that's beautiful!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Taps him playfully on the cheek] Now he must keep still or

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I'll have to kiss him.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Holding her back] Now, now!--Somebody might come!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Well, what do I care? Can't I kiss my own husband, perhaps?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh yes, that's my lawful right.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, but don't you know--in the hotel here, they don't

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: believe we are married, because we are kissing each other such a

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: lot. And it makes no difference that we quarrel now and then, for

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: lovers are said to do that also.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Well, but what's the use of quarrelling? Why can't he

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: always be as nice as he is now? Tell me now? Can't he try? Doesn't

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: he want us to be happy?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Do I want it? Yes, but--

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: There we are again! Who has put it into his head that he is

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: not to paint any longer?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Who? You are always looking for somebody else behind me

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and my thoughts. Are you jealous?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Yes, I am. I'm afraid somebody might take him away from me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Are you really afraid of that? You who know that no other

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: woman can take your place, and that I cannot live without you!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Well, I am not afraid of the women--it's your friends that

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: fill your head with all sorts of notions.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Watching her] You are afraid then? Of what are you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: afraid?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Getting up] Somebody has been here. Who has been here?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Don't you wish me to look at you?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Not in that way: it's not the way you are accustomed to

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: look at me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: How was I looking at you then?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Way up under my eyelids.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Under your eyelids--yes, I wanted to see what is behind

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: them.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: See all you can! There is nothing that needs to be hidden.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But--you talk differently, too--you use expressions--[studying

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: him] you philosophise--that's what you do! [Approaches him

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: threateningly] Who has been here?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Nobody but my physician.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Your physician? Who is he?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: That doctor from Strömstad.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What's his name?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Sjöberg.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What did he have to say?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: He said--well--among other things he said--that I am on

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: the verge of epilepsy--

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Among other things? What more did he say?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Something very unpleasant.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Tell me!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: He forbade us to live as man and wife for a while.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh, that's it! Didn't I just guess it! They want to

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: separate us! That's what I have understood a long time!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: You can't have understood, because there was nothing to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: understand.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh yes, I have!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: How can you see what doesn't exist, unless your fear of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: something has stirred up your fancy into seeing what has never

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: existed? What is it you fear? That I might borrow somebody else's

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: eyes in order to see you as you are, and not as you seem to be?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Keep your imagination in check, Adolph! It is the beast

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: that dwells in man's soul.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Where did you learn that? From those chaste young men on

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: the boat--did you?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Not at all abashed] Yes, there is something to be learned

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: from youth also.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I think you are already beginning to have a taste for

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: youth?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I have always liked youth. That's why I love you. Do you

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: object?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, but I should prefer to have no partners.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Prattling roguishly] My heart is so big, little brother,

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: that there is room in it for many more than him.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: But little brother doesn't want any more brothers.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Come here to Pussy now and get his hair pulled because he

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: is jealous--no, envious is the right word for it!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: GUSTAV is.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, I don't want to play now. I want to talk seriously.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Prattling] Mercy me, does he want to talk seriously?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Dreadful, how serious he's become! [Takes hold of his head and

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: kisses him] Smile a little--there now!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Smiling against his will] Oh, you're the--I might almost

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: think you knew how to use magic!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
