TEXT: Well, can't he see now? That's why he shouldn't start any

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: trouble--or I might use my magic to make him invisible!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Gets up] Will you sit for me a moment, Tekla? With the

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: side of your face this way, so that I can put a face on my figure.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Of course, I will.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Gazes hard at her while pretending to work at the figure]

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Don't think of me now--but of somebody else.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I'll think of my latest conquest.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: That chaste young man?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Exactly! He had a pair of the prettiest, sweetest

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: moustaches, and his cheek looked like a peach--it was so soft and

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: rosy that you just wanted to bite it.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Darkening] Please keep that expression about the mouth.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What expression?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: A cynical, brazen one that I have never seen before.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Making a face] This one?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Just that one! [Getting up] Do you know how Bret Harte

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: pictures an adulteress?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Smiling] No, I have never read Bret Something.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: As a pale creature that cannot blush.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Not at all? But when she meets her lover, then she must

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: blush, I am sure, although her husband or Mr. Bret may not be

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: allowed to see it.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Are you so sure of that?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [As before] Of course, as the husband is not capable of

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: bringing the blood up to her head, he cannot hope to behold the

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: charming spectacle.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Enraged] Tekla!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh, you little ninny!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Tekla!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: He should call her Pussy--then I might get up a pretty

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: little blush for his sake. Does he want me to?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Disarmed] You minx, I'm so angry with you, that I could

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: bite you!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Playfully] Come and bite me then!--Come!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Puts his hands around her neck and kisses her] Yes, I'll

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: bite you to death!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Teasingly] Look out--somebody might come!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Well, what do I care! I care for nothing else in the world

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: if I can only have you!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: And when, you don't have me any longer?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Then I shall die!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But you are not afraid of losing me, are you--as I am too

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: old to be wanted by anybody else?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: You have not forgotten my words yet, Tekla! I take it all

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: back now!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Can you explain to me why you are at once so jealous and so

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: cock-sure?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, I cannot explain anything at all. But it's possible

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: that the thought of somebody else having possessed you may still

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: be gnawing within me. At times it appears to me as if our love

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: were nothing but a fiction, an attempt at self-defence, a passion

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: kept up as a matter of honor--and I can't think of anything that

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: would give me more pain than to have _him_ know that I am unhappy.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, I have never seen him--but the mere thought that a person

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: exists who is waiting for my misfortune to arrive, who is daily

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: calling down curses on my head, who will roar with laughter when I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: perish--the mere idea of it obsesses me, drives me nearer to you,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: fascinates me, paralyses me!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Do you think I would let him have that joy? Do you think I

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: would make his prophecy come true?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, I cannot think you would.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Why don't you keep calm then?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, you upset me constantly by your coquetry. Why do you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: play that kind of game?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: It is no game. I want to be admired--that's all!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, but only by men!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Of course! For a woman is never admired by other women.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Tell me, have you heard anything--from him--recently?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Not in the last sis months.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Do you ever think of him?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No!--Since the child died we have broken off our

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: correspondence.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: And you have never seen him at all?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, I understand he is living somewhere down on the West

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Coast. But why is all this coming into your head just now?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I don't know. But during the last few days, while I was

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: alone, I kept thinking of him--how he might have felt when he was

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: left alone that time.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Are you having an attack of bad conscience?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I am.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: You feel like a thief, do you?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Almost!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Isn't that lovely! Women can be stolen as you steal

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: children or chickens? And you regard me as his chattel or personal

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: property. I am very much obliged to you!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, I regard you as his wife. And that's a good deal more

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: than property--for there can be no substitute. TEKLA. Oh, yes! If

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: you only heard that he had married again, all these foolish

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: notions would leave you.--Have you not taken his place with me?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Well, have I?--And did you ever love him?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Of course, I did!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: And then--

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I grew tired of him!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: And if you should tire of me also?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But I won't!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: If somebody else should turn up--one who had all the

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: qualities you are looking for in a man now--suppose only--then you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: would leave me?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: If he captivated you? So that you couldn't live without

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: him? Then you would leave me, of course?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, that doesn't follow.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: But you couldn't love two at the same time, could you?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Yes! Why not?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: That's something I cannot understand.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But things exist although you do not understand them. All

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: persons are not made in the same way, you know.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I begin to see now!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, really!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, really? [A pause follows, during which he seems to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: struggle with some--memory that will not come back] Do you know,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Tekla, that your frankness is beginning to be painful?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: And yet it used to be my foremost virtue In your mind, and

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: one that you taught me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, but it seems to me as if you were hiding something

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: behind that frankness of yours.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: That's the new tactics, you know.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I don't know why, but this place has suddenly become

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: offensive to me. If you feel like it, we might return home--this

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: evening!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What kind of notion is that? I have barely arrived and I

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: don't feel like starting on another trip.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: But I want to.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Well, what's that to me?--You can go!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: But I demand that you take the next boat with me!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Demand?--What arc you talking about?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Do you realise that you are my wife?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Do you realise that you are my husband?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Well, there's a difference between those two things.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh, that's the way you are talking now!--You have never

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: loved me!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Haven't I?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, for to love is to give.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: To love like a man is to give; to love like a woman is to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: take.--And I have given, given, given!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Pooh! What have you given?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Everything!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: That's a lot! And if it be true, then I must have taken it.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Are you beginning to send in bills for your gifts now? And if I

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: have taken anything, this proves only my love for you. A woman

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: cannot receive anything except from her lover.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Her lover, yes! There you spoke the truth! I have been

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: your lover, but never your husband.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Well, isn't that much more agreeable--to escape playing

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: chaperon? But if you are not satisfied with your position, I'll

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: send you packing, for I don't want a husband.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, that's what I have noticed. For a while ago, when you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: began to sneak away from me like a thief with his booty, and when

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: you began to seek company of your own where you could flaunt my

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: plumes and display my gems, then I felt, like reminding you of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: your debt. And at once I became a troublesome creditor whom you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: wanted to get rid of. You wanted to repudiate your own notes, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: in order not to increase your debt to me, you stopped pillaging my

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: safe and began to try those of other people instead. Without

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: having done anything myself, I became to you merely the husband.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: And now I am going to be your husband whether you like it or not,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: as I am not allowed to be your lover any longer,

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Playfully] Now he shouldn't talk nonsense, the sweet

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: little idiot!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Look out: it's dangerous to think everybody an idiot but

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: oneself!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But that's what everybody thinks.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: And I am beginning to suspect that he--your former

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: husband--was not so much of an idiot after all.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Heavens! Are you beginning to sympathise with--him?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, not far from it,

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Well, well! Perhaps you would like to make his acquaintance

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: and pour out your overflowing heart to him? What a striking

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: picture! But I am also beginning to feel drawn to him, as I am

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: growing more and more tired of acting as wetnurse. For he was at

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: least a man, even though he had the fault of being married to me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: There, you see! But you had better not talk so loud--we

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: might be overheard.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What would it matter if they took us for married people?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: So now you are getting fond of real male men also, and at

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: the same time you have a taste for chaste young men?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: There are no limits to what I can like, as you may see. My

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: heart is open to everybody and everything, to the big and the

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: small, the handsome and the ugly, the new and the old--I love the

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: whole world.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Do you know what that means?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, I don't know anything at all. I just _feel_.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: It means that old age is near.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: There you are again! Take care!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Take care yourself!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Of what?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Of the knife!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Prattling] Little brother had better not play with such

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: dangerous things.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I have quit playing.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh, it's earnest, is it? Dead earnest! Then I'll show you

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: that--you are mistaken. That is to say--you'll never see it, never

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: know it, but all the rest of the world will know It. And you'll

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: suspect it, you'll believe it, and you'll never have another

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: moment's peace. You'll have the feeling of being ridiculous, of

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: being deceived, but you'll never get any proof of it. For that's

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: what married men never get.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: You hate me then?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, I don't. And I don't think I shall either. But that's

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: probably because you are nothing to me but a child.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: At this moment, yes. But do you remember how it was while

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: the storm swept over us? Then you lay there like an infant in arms

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and just cried. Then you had to sit on my lap, and I had to kiss

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: your eyes to sleep. Then I had to be your nurse; had to see that

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: you fixed your hair before going out; had to send your shoes to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: the cobbler, and see that there was food in the house. I had to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: sit by your side, holding your hand for hours at a time: you were

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: afraid, afraid of the whole world, because you didn't have a

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: single friend, and because you were crushed by the hostility of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: public opinion. I had to talk courage into you until my mouth was

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: dry and my head ached. I had to make myself believe that I was

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: strong. I had to force myself into believing in the future. And so

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I brought you back to life, when you seemed already dead. Then you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: admired me. Then I was the man--not that kind of athlete you had

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: just left, but the man of will-power, the mesmerist who instilled

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: new nervous energy into your flabby muscles and charged your empty

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: brain with a new store of electricity. And then I gave you back

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: your reputation. I brought you new friends, furnished you with a

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: little court of people who, for the sake of friendship to me, let

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: themselves be lured into admiring you. I set you to rule me and my

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: house. Then I painted my best pictures, glimmering with reds and

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: blues on backgrounds of gold, and there was not an exhibition then

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: where I didn't hold a place of honour. Sometimes you were St.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Cecilia, and sometimes Mary Stuart--or little Karin, whom King

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Eric loved. And I turned public attention in your direction. I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: compelled the clamorous herd to see yon with my own infatuated

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: vision. I plagued them with your personality, forced you literally

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: down their throats, until that sympathy which makes everything

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: possible became yours at last--and you could stand on your own

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: feet. When you reached that far, then my strength was used up, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I collapsed from the overstrain--in lifting you up, I had pushed

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: myself down. I was taken ill, and my illness seemed an annoyance

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: to you at the moment when all life had just begun to smile at you--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and sometimes it seemed to me as if, in your heart, there was a

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: secret desire to get rid of your creditor and the witness of your

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: rise. Your love began to change into that of a grown-up sister,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and for lack of better I accustomed myself to the new part of

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: little brother. Your tenderness for me remained, and even

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: increased, but it was mingled with a suggestion of pity that had

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: in it a good deal of contempt. And this changed into open scorn as

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: my talent withered and your own sun rose higher. But in some

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: mysterious way the fountainhead of your inspiration seemed to dry

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: up when I could no longer replenish it--or rather when you wanted

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: to show its independence of me. And at last both of us began to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: lose ground. And then you looked for somebody to put the blame on.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: A new victim! For you are weak, and you can never carry your own

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: burdens of guilt and debt. And so you picked me for a scapegoat

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: and doomed me to slaughter. But when you cut my thews, you didn't

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: realise that you were also crippling yourself, for by this time

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: our years of common life had made twins of us. You were a shoot

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: sprung from my stem, and you wanted to cut yourself loose before

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: the shoot had put out roots of its own, and that's why you

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: couldn't grow by yourself. And my stem could not spare its main

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: branch--and so stem and branch must die together.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What you mean with all this, of course, is that you have

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: written my books.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, that's what you want me to mean in order to make me

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: out a liar. I don't use such crude expressions as you do, and I

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: spoke for something like five minutes to get in all the nuances,

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: all the halftones, all the transitions--but your hand-organ has

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: only a single note in it.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Yes, but the summary of the whole story is that you have

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: written my books.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: No, there is no summary. You cannot reduce a chord into a

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: single note. You cannot translate a varied life into a sum of one

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: figure. I have made no blunt statements like that of having

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: written your books.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But that's what you meant!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Beyond himself] I did not mean it.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But the sum of it--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Wildly] There can be no sum without an addition. You get

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: an endless decimal fraction for quotient when your division does

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: not work out evenly. I have not added anything.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But I can do the adding myself.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: I believe it, but then I am not doing it.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No. but that's what you wanted to do.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Exhausted, closing his eyes] No, no, no--don't speak to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: me--you'll drive me into convulsions. Keep silent! Leave me alone!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: You mutilate my brain with your clumsy pincers--you put your claws

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: into my thoughts and tear them to pieces!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: his thumbs are bent inward against the palms of his hands.)

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Tenderly] What is it? Are you sick?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Adolph!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Adolph.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Do you admit that you were unjust a moment ago?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, yes, yes, yes, I admit!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: And do you ask my pardon?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, yes, yes, I ask your pardon--if you only won't speak

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: to me!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Kiss my hand then!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [Kissing her hand] I'll kiss your hand--if you only don't

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: speak to me!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: And now you had better go out for a breath of fresh air

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: before dinner.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Yes, I think I need it. And then we'll pack and leave.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: [On his feet] Why? There must be a reason.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: The reason is that I have promised to be at the concert to-

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: night.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, that's it!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Yes, that's it. I have promised to attend--

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Promised? Probably you said only that you might go, and

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: that wouldn't prevent you from saying now that you won't go.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, I am not like you: I keep my word.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Of course, promises should be kept, but we don't have to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: live up to every little word we happen to drop. Perhaps there is

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: somebody who has made you promise to go.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Yes.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Then you can ask to be released from your promise because

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: your husband is sick.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: TEKLA, No, I don't want to do that, and you are not sick enough to

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: be kept from going with me.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Why do you always want to drag me along? Do you feel safer

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: then?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I don't know what you mean.

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: That's what you always say when you know I mean something

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: that--doesn't please you.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: So-o! What is it now that doesn't please me?

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: Oh, I beg you, don't begin over again--Good-bye for a

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: while!

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: right.)

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: straight up to the table as if looking for a newspaper. He

SPEAKER: ADOLPH
TEXT: pretends not to see TEKLA.)

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Shows agitation, but manages to control herself] Oh, is it

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: you?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, it's me--I beg your pardon!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Which way did you come?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: By land. But--I am not going to stay, as--

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh, there is no reason why you shouldn't.--Well, it was

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: some time ago--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, some time.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: You have changed a great deal.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And you are as charming as ever, A little younger, if

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: anything. Excuse me, however--I am not going to spoil your

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: happiness by my presence. And if I had known you were here, I

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: should never--

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: If you don't think it improper, I should like you to stay.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: On my part there could be no objection, but I fear--well,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: whatever I say, I am sure to offend you.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Sit down a moment. You don't offend me, for you possess

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: that rare gift--which was always yours--of tact and politeness.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: It's very kind of you. But one could hardly expect--that

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: your husband might regard my qualities in the same generous light

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: as you.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: On the contrary, he has just been speaking of you in very

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: sympathetic terms.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh!--Well, everything becomes covered up by time, like

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: names cut in a tree--and not even dislike can maintain itself

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: permanently in our minds.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: He has never disliked you, for he has never seen you. And

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: as for me, I have always cherished a dream--that of seeing you

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: come together as friends--or at least of seeing you meet for once

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: in my presence--of seeing you shake hands--and then go your

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: different ways again.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: It has also been my secret longing to see her whom I used

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: to love more than my own life--to make sure that she was in good

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: hands. And although I have heard nothing but good of him, and am

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: familiar with all his work, I should nevertheless have liked,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: before it grew too late, to look into his eyes and beg him to take

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: good care of the treasure Providence has placed in his possession.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: In that way I hoped also to lay the hatred that must have

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: developed instinctively between us; I wished to bring some peace

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: and humility into my soul, so that I might manage to live through

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the rest of my sorrowful days.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: You have uttered my own thoughts, and you have understood

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: me. I thank you for it!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh, I am a man of small account, and have always been too

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: insignificant to keep you in the shadow. My monotonous way of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: living, my drudgery, my narrow horizons--all that could not

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: satisfy a soul like yours, longing for liberty. I admit it. But

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you understand--you who have searched the human soul--what it cost

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: me to make such a confession to myself.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: It is noble, it is splendid, to acknowledge one's own

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: shortcomings--and it's not everybody that's capable of it. [Sighs]

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: But yours has always been an honest, and faithful, and reliable

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: nature--one that I had to respect--but--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Not always--not at that time! But suffering purifies,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: sorrow ennobles, and--I have suffered!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Poor Gustav! Can you forgive me? Tell me, can you?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Forgive? What? I am the one who must ask you to forgive.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Changing tone] I believe we are crying, both of us--we who

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: are old enough to know better!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Feeling his way] Old? Yes, I am old. But you--you grow

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: younger every day.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: left and sits down on it, whereupon TEKLA sits down on the sofa.)

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Do you think so?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And then you know how to dress.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I learned that from you. Don't you remember how you figured

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: out what colors would be most becoming to me?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Yes, don't you remember--hm!--I can even recall how you

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: used to be angry with me whenever I failed to have at least a

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: touch of crimson about my dress.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, not angry! I was never angry with you.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh, yes, when you wanted to teach me how to think--do you

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: remember? For that was something I couldn't do at all.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Of course, you could. It's something every human being

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: does. And you have become quite keen at it--at least when you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: write.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Unpleasantly impressed; hurrying her words] Well, my dear

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Gustav, it is pleasant to see you anyhow, and especially in a

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: peaceful way like this.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, I can hardly be called a troublemaker, and you had a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: pretty peaceful time with me.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Perhaps too much so.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh! But you see, I thought you wanted me that way. It was

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: at least the impression you gave me while we were engaged.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Do you think one really knows what one wants at that time?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: And then the mammas insist on all kinds of pretensions, of course.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, now you must be having all the excitement you can

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: wish. They say that life among artists is rather swift, and I

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: don't think your husband can be called a sluggard.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: You can get too much of a good thing.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Trying a new tack] What! I do believe you are still

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: wearing the ear-rings I gave you?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Embarrassed] Why not? There was never any quarrel between

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: us--and then I thought I might wear them as a token--and a

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: reminder--that we were not enemies. And then, you know, it is

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: impossible to buy this kind of ear-rings any longer. [Takes off

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: one of her ear-rings.]

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh, that's all right, but what does your husband say of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: it?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Why should I mind what he says?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Don't you mind that?--But you may be doing him an injury.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: It is likely to make him ridiculous.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Brusquely, as if speaking to herself almost] He was that

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: before!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Rises when he notes her difficulty in putting back the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: ear-ring] May I help you, perhaps?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh--thank you!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Pinching her ear] That tiny ear!--Think only if your

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: husband could see us now!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Wouldn't he howl, though!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Is he jealous also?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Is he? I should say so!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Who lives in that room?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I don't know.--But tell me how you are getting along and

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: what you are doing?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Tell me rather how you are getting along?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: doing, she takes the cover off the wax figure.)

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Hello! What's that?--Well!--It must be you!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I don't believe so.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: But it is very like you.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Cynically] Do you think so?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: That reminds me of the story--you know it--"How could

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: your majesty see that?"

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: TEKLA, [Laughing aloud] You are impossible!--Do you know any new

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: stories?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, but you ought to have some.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh, I never hear anything funny nowadays.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Is he modest also?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh--well--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Not an everything?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: He isn't well just now.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Well, why should little brother put his nose into other

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: people's hives?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Laughing] You crazy thing!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Poor chap!--Do you remember once when we were just

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: married--we lived in this very room. It was furnished differently

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: in those days. There was a chest of drawers against that wall

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: there--and over there stood the big bed.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Now you stop!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Look at me!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Well, why shouldn't I?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Do you think a person can ever forget anything that has

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: made a very deep impression on him?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No! And our memories have a tremendous power. Particularly

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: the memories of our youth.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Do you remember when I first met you? Then you were a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: pretty little girl: a slate on which parents and governesses had

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: made a few scrawls that I had to wipe out. And then I filled it

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: with inscriptions that suited my own mind, until you believed the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: slate could hold nothing more. That's the reason, you know, why I

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: shouldn't care to be in your husband's place--well, that's his

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: business! But it's also the reason why I take pleasure in meeting

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you again. Our thoughts fit together exactly. And as I sit here

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: and chat with you, it seems to me like drinking old wine of my own

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: bottling. Yes, it's my own wine, but it has gained a great deal in

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: flavour! And now, when I am about to marry again, I have purposely

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: picked out a young girl whom I can educate to suit myself. For the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: woman, you know, is the man's child, and if she is not, he becomes

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: hers, and then the world turns topsy-turvy.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Are you going to marry again?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, I want to try my luck once more, but this time I am

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: going to make a better start, so that it won't end again with a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: spill.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Is she good looking?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, to me. But perhaps I am too old. It's queer--now when

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: chance has brought me together with you again--I am beginning to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: doubt whether it will be possible to play the game over again.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: How do you mean?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I can feel that my roots stick in your soil, and the old

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: wounds are beginning to break open. You are a dangerous woman,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Tekla!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Am I? And my young husband says that I can make no more

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: conquests.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: That means he has ceased to love you.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Well, I can't quite make out what love means to him.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: You have been playing hide and seek so long that at last

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you cannot find each other at all. Such things do happen. You have

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: had to play the innocent to yourself, until he has lost his

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: courage. There _are_ some drawbacks to a change, I tell you--there

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: are drawbacks to it, indeed.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Do you mean to reproach--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Not at all! Whatever happens is to a certain extent

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: necessary, for if it didn't happen, something else would--but now

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: it did happen, and so it had to happen.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: _You_ are a man of discernment. And I have never met anybody

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: with whom I liked so much to exchange ideas. You are so utterly

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: free from all morality and preaching, and you ask so little of

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: people, that it is possible to be oneself in your presence. Do you

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: know, I am jealous of your intended wife!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And do you realise that I am jealous of your husband?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Rising] And now we must part! Forever!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, we must part! But not without a farewell--or what do

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you say?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Agitated] No!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Following after her] Yes!--Let us have a farewell! Let us

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: drown our memories--you know, there are intoxications so deep that

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: when you wake up all memories are gone. [Putting his arm around

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: her waist] You have been dragged down by a diseased spirit, who is

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: infecting you with his own anaemia. I'll breathe new life into

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you. I'll make your talent blossom again in your autumn days, like

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: a remontant rose. I'll---

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the veranda. They look surprised. Then they point at those within,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: laugh, and disappear.)

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Freeing herself] Who was that?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Indifferently] Some tourists.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Leave me alone! I am afraid of you!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Why?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: You take my soul away from me!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And give you my own in its place! And you have no soul for

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: that matter--it's nothing but a delusion.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: You have a way of saying impolite things so that nobody can

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: be angry with you.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: It's because you feel that I hold the first mortgage on

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you--Tell me now, when--and--where?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, it wouldn't be right to him. I think he is still in

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: love with me, and I don't want to do any more harm.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: He does not love you! Do you want proofs?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: TEKLA, Where can you get them?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Picking up the pieces of the photograph from the floor]

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Here! See for yourself!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh, that's an outrage!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Do you see? Now then, when? And where?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: The false-hearted wretch!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: When?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: He leaves to-night, with the eight-o'clock boat.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And then--

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: At nine! [A noise is heard from the adjoining room] Who can

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: be living in there that makes such a racket?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Let's see! [Goes over and looks through the keyhole]

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: There's a table that has been upset, and a smashed water caraffe--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: that's all! I shouldn't wonder if they had left a dog locked up in

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: there.--At nine o'clock then?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: All right! And let him answer for it himself.--What a depth

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: of deceit! And he who has always preached about truthfulness,

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: and tried to teach me to tell the truth!--But wait a little—how

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: was it now? He received me with something like hostility--didn't

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: meet me at the landing--and then--and then he made some remark

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: about young men on board the boat, which I pretended not to hear—-

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: but how could he know? Wait--and then he began to philosophise

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: about women--and then the spectre of you seemed to be haunting

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: him--and he talked of becoming a sculptor, that being the art

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: of the time--exactly in accordance with your old speculations!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No, really!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No, really?--Oh, now I understand! Now I begin to see what

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: a hideous creature you are! You have been here before and stabbed

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: him to death! It was you who had been sitting there on the sofa;

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: it was you who made him think himself an epileptic--that he had to

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: live in celibacy; that he ought to rise in rebellion against his

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: wife; yes, it was you!--How long have you been here?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I have been here a week.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: It was you, then, I saw on board the boat?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: It was.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: And now you were thinking you could trap me?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: It has been done.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Not yet!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Like a wolf you went after my lamb. You came here with a

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: villainous plan to break up my happiness, and you were carrying it

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: out, when my eyes were opened, and I foiled you.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Not quite that way, if you please. This is how it happened

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: in reality. Of course, it has been my secret hope that disaster

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: might overtake you. But I felt practically certain that no

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: interference on my part was required. And besides, I have been far

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: too busy to have any time left for intriguing. But when I happened

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: to be moving about a bit, and happened to see you with those young

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: men on board the boat, then I guessed the time had come for me to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: take a look at the situation. I came here, and your lamb threw

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: itself into the arms of the wolf. I won his affection by some sort

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of reminiscent impression which I shall not be tactless enough to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: explain to you. At first he aroused my sympathy, because he seemed

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: to be in the same fix as I was once. But then he happened to touch

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: old wounds--that book, you know, and "the idiot"--and I was seized

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: with a wish to pick him to pieces, and to mix up these so

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: thoroughly that they couldn't be put together again--and I

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: succeeded, thanks to the painstaking way in which you had done the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: work of preparation. Then I had to deal with you. For you were the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: spring that had kept the works moving, and you had to be taken

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: apart--and what a buzzing followed!--When I came in here, I didn't

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: know exactly what to say. Like a chess-player, I had laid a number

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of tentative plans, of course, but my play had to depend on your

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: moves. One thing led to the other, chance lent me a hand, and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: finally I had you where I wanted you.--Now you are caught!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: No!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, you are! What you least wanted has happened. The

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: world at large, represented by two lady tourists--whom I had not

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: sent for, as I am not an intriguer--the world has seen how you

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: became reconciled to your former husband, and how you sneaked back

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: repentantly into his faithful arms. Isn't that enough?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: It ought to be enough for your revenge--But tell me, how

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: can you, who are so enlightened and so right-minded--how is it

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: possible that you, who think whatever happens must happen, and

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: that all our actions are determined in advance--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Correcting her] To a certain extent determined.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: That's the same thing!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: No!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Disregarding him] How is it possible that you, who hold me

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: guiltless, as I was driven by my nature and the circumstances into

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: acting as I did--how can you think yourself entitled to revenge--?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: For that very reason--for the reason that my nature and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the circumstances drove me into seeking revenge. Isn't that giving

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: both sides a square deal? But do you know why you two had to get

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the worst of it in this struggle?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And why you were doomed to be fooled? Because I am

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: stronger than you, and wiser also. You have been the idiot--and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: he! And now you may perceive that a man need not be an idiot

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: because he doesn't write novels or paint pictures. It might be

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: well for you to bear this in mind.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Are you then entirely without feelings?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Entirely! And for that very reason, you know, I am capable

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of thinking--in which you have had no experience whatever-and of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: acting--in which you have just had some slight experience.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: And all this merely because I have hurt your vanity?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Don't call that MERELY! You had better not go around

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: hurting other people's vanity. They have no more sensitive spot

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: than that.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Vindictive wretch--shame on you!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Dissolute wretch--shame on you!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Oh, that's my character, is it?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Oh, that's my character, is it?--You ought to learn

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: something about human nature in others before you give your own

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: nature free rein. Otherwise you may get hurt, and then there will

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: be wailing and gnashing of teeth.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: You can never forgive:--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Yes, I have forgiven you!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: You!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Of course! Have I raised a hand against you during all

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: these years? No! And now I came here only to have a look at you,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: and it was enough to burst your bubble. Have I uttered a single

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: reproach? Have I moralised or preached sermons? No! I played a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: joke or two on your dear consort, and nothing more was needed to

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: finish him.--But there is no reason why I, the complainant,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: should be defending myself as I am now--Tekla! Have you nothing at

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: all to reproach yourself with?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Nothing at all! Christians say that our actions are

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: governed by Providence; others call it Fate; in either case, are

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: we not free from all liability?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: In a measure, yes; but there is always a narrow margin

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: left unprotected, and there the liability applies in spite of all.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And sooner or later the creditors make their appearance.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Guiltless, but accountable! Guiltless in regard to one who is no

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: more; accountable to oneself and one's fellow beings.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: So you came here to dun me?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I came to take back what you had stolen, not what you had

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: received as a gift. You had stolen my honour, and I could recover

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: it only by taking yours. This, I think, was my right--or was it

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: not?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Honour? Hm! And now you feel satisfied?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Now I feel satisfied. [Rings for a waiter.]

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: And now you are going home to your fiancee?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I have no fiancee! Nor am I ever going to have one. I am

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: not going home, for I have no home, and don't want one.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Get me my bill--I am leaving by the eight o'clock boat.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Without making up?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Making up? You use such a lot of words that have lost

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: their--meaning. Why should we make up? Perhaps you want all three

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of us to live together? You, if anybody, ought to make up by

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: making good what you took away, but this you cannot do. You just

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: took, and what you took you consumed, so that there is nothing

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: left to restore.--Will it satisfy you if I say like this: forgive

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: me that you tore my heart to pieces; forgive me that you disgraced

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: me; forgive me that you made me the laughing-stock of my pupils

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: through every week-day of seven long years; forgive me that I set

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: you free from parental restraints, that I released you from the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: tyranny of ignorance and superstition, that I set you to rule my

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: house, that I gave you position and friends, that I made a woman

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: out of the child you were before? Forgive me as I forgive you!--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Now I have torn up your note! Now you can go and settle your

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: account with the other one!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: What have you done with him? I am beginning to suspect--

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: something terrible!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: With him? Do you still love him?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Yes!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And a moment ago it was me! Was that also true?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: It was true.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Do you know what you are then?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: You despise me?

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I pity you. It is a trait--I don't call it a fault--just

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: a trait, which is rendered disadvantageous by its results. Poor

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Tekla! I don't know--but it seems almost as if I were feeling a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: certain regret, although I am as free from any guilt--as you! But

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: perhaps it will be useful to you to feel what I felt that time.--

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Do you know where your husband is?

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: I think I know now--he is in that room in there! And he has

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: heard everything! And seen everything! And the man who sees his

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: own wraith dies!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: white as a sheet, and there is a bleeding scratch on one cheek.

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: His eyes are staring and void of all expression. His lips are

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: covered with froth.)

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: [Shrinking back] No, there he is!--Now you can settle with

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: him and see if he proves as generous as I have been.--Good-bye!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Goes to meet ADOLPH with open arms] Adolph!

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: floor.)

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: [Throwing herself upon his prostrate body and caressing

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: him] Adolph! My own child! Are you still alive--oh, speak, speak!--

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: Please forgive your nasty Tekla! Forgive me, forgive me, forgive

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: me!--Little brother must say something, I tell him!--No, good God,

SPEAKER: TEKLA
TEXT: he doesn't hear! He is dead! O God in heaven! O my God! Help!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Why, she really must have loved _him_, too!--Poor creature!

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: PARIAH

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: INTRODUCTION

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Both "Creditors" and "Pariah" were written in the winter of 1888-

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: 89 at Holte, near Copenhagen, where Strindberg, assisted by his

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: first wife, was then engaged in starting what he called a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: "Scandinavian Experimental Theatre." In March, 1889, the two plays

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: were given by students from the University of Copenhagen, and with

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Mrs. von Essen Strindberg as _Tekla_. A couple of weeks later the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: performance was repeated across the Sound, in the Swedish city of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Malmö, on which occasion the writer of this introduction, then a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: young actor, assisted in the stage management. One of the actors

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: was Gustav Wied, a Danish playwright and novelist, whose exquisite

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: art since then has won him European fame. In the audience was Ola

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Hansson, a Swedish novelist and poet who had just published a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: short story from which Strindberg, according to his own

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: acknowledgment on playbill and title-page, had taken the name and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the theme of "Pariah."

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Mr. Hansson has printed a number of letters (_Tilskueren_,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Copenhagen, July, 1912) written to him by Strindberg about that

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: time, as well as some very informative comments of his own.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Concerning the performance of Malmö he writes: "It gave me a very

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: unpleasant sensation. What did it mean? Why had Strindberg turned

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: my simple theme upsidedown so that it became unrecognisable? Not a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: vestige of the 'theme from Ola Hansson' remained. Yet he had even

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: suggested that he and I act the play together, I not knowing that

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: it was to be a duel between two criminals. And he had at first

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: planned to call it 'Aryan and Pariah'--which meant, of course,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: that the strong Aryan, Strindberg, was to crush the weak Pariah,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Hansson, _coram populo_."

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: In regard to his own story Mr. Hansson informs us that it dealt

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: with "a man who commits a forgery and then tells about it, doing

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: both in a sort of somnambulistic state whereby everything is left

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: vague and undefined." At that moment "Raskolnikov" was in the air,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: so to speak. And without wanting in any way to suggest imitation,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: I feel sure that the groundnote of the story was distinctly

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Dostoievskian. Strindberg himself had been reading Nietzsche and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: was--largely under the pressure of a reaction against the popular

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: disapproval of his anti-feministic attitude--being driven more and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: more into a superman philosophy which reached its climax in the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: two novels "Chandalah" (1889) and "At the Edge of the Sea" (1890).

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: The Nietzschean note is unmistakable in the two plays contained in

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the present volume.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: But these plays are strongly colored by something else--by

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: something that is neither Hansson-Dostoievski nor Strindberg-

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Nietzsche. The solution of the problem is found in the letters

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: published by Mr. Hansson. These show that while Strindberg was

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: still planning "Creditors," and before he had begun "Pariah," he

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: had borrowed from Hansson a volume of tales by Edgar Allan Poe. It

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: was his first acquaintance with the work of Poe, though not with

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: American literature--for among his first printed work was a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: series of translations from American humourists; and not long ago

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: a Swedish critic (Gunnar Castrén in _Samtiden_, Christiania, June,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: 1912) wrote of Strindberg's literary beginnings that "he had

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: learned much from Swedish literature, but probably more from Mark

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Twain and Dickens."

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: The impression Poe made on Strindberg was overwhelming. He returns

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: to it in one letter after another. Everything that suits his mood

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of the moment is "Poesque" or "E. P-esque." The story that seems

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: to have made the deepest impression of all was "The Gold Bug,"

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: though his thought seems to have distilled more useful material

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: out of certain other stories illustrating Poe's theories about

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: mental suggestion. Under the direct influence of these theories,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Strindberg, according to his own statements to Hansson, wrote the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: powerful one-act play "Simoom," and made _Gustav_ in "Creditors"

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: actually _call forth_ the latent epileptic tendencies in _Adolph_.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: And on the same authority we must trace the method of: psychological

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: detection practised by _Mr. X._ in "Pariah" directly to "The Gold

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Bug."

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Here we have the reason why Mr. Hansson could find so little of

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: his story in the play. And here we have the origin of a theme

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: which, while not quite new to him, was ever afterward to remain a

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: favourite one with Strindberg: that of a duel between intellect

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: and cunning. It forms the basis of such novels as "Chandalah" and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: "At the Edge of the Sea," but it recurs in subtler form in works

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: of much later date. To readers of the present day, _Mr. X._--that

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: striking antithesis of everything a scientist used to stand for in

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: poetry--is much less interesting as a superman _in spe_ than as an

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: illustration of what a morally and mentally normal man can do with

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the tools furnished him by our new understanding of human ways and

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: human motives. And in giving us a play that holds our interest as

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: firmly as the best "love plot" ever devised, although the stage

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: shows us only two men engaged in an intellectual wrestling match,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Strindberg took another great step toward ridding the drama of its

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: old, shackling conventions.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: The name of this play has sometimes been translated as "The

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Outcast," whereby it becomes confused with "The Outlaw," a much

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: earlier play on a theme from the old Sagas. I think it better,

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: too, that the Hindu allusion in the Swedish title be not lost, for

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: the best of men may become an outcast, but the baseness of the

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: Pariah is not supposed to spring only from lack of social

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: position.

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: PARIAH

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: AN ACT

SPEAKER: GUSTAV
TEXT: PERSONS

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X., an archaeologist, Middle-aged man.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y., an American traveller, Middle-aged man.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: SCENE

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: in the background open on a landscape. In the middle of the room

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: stands a big dining-table, covered at one end by books, writing

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: materials, and antiquities; at the other end, by a microscope,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: insect cases, and specimen jars full of alchohol.)

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that of a well-to-do farmer.)

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: a botany-can. He goes straight up to the bookshelf and takes down

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: a book, which he begins to read on the spot.)

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: sunlight. The ringing of church bells indicates that the morning

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: services are just over. Now and then the cackling of hens is heard

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: from the outside.)

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: upside-down, and pretends to be looking for another volume.)

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. This heat is horrible. I guess we are going to have a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: thunderstorm.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. What makes you think so?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. The bells have a kind of dry ring to them, the flies are

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: sticky, and the hens cackle. I meant to go fishing, but I couldn't

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: find any worms. Don't you feel nervous?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Cautiously] I?--A little.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Well, for that matter, you always look as if you were

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: expecting thunderstorms.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [With a start] Do I?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Now, you are going away tomorrow, of course, so it is not

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: to be wondered at that you are a little "journey-proud."--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Anything new?--Oh, there's the mail! [Picks up some letters from

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the table] My, I have palpitation of the heart every time I open a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: letter! Nothing but debts, debts, debts! Have you ever had any

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: debts?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [After some reflection] N-no.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Well, then you don't know what it means to receive a lot of

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: overdue bills. [Reads one of the letters] The rent unpaid--the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: landlord acting nasty--my wife in despair. And here am I sitting

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: waist-high in gold! [He opens an iron-banded box that stands on

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the table; then both sit down at the table, facing each other]

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Just look--here I have six thousand crowns' worth of gold which I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: have dug up in the last fortnight. This bracelet alone would bring

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: me the three hundred and fifty crowns I need. And with all of it I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: might make a fine career for myself. Then I could get the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: illustrations made for my treatise at once; I could get my work

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: printed, and--I could travel! Why don't I do it, do you suppose?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. I suppose you are afraid to be found out.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. That, too, perhaps. But don't you think an intelligent

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: fellow like myself might fix matters so that he was never found

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: out? I am alone all the time--with nobody watching me--while I am

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: digging out there in the fields. It wouldn't be strange if I put

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: something in my own pockets now and then.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Yes, but the worst danger lies in disposing of the stuff.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Pooh! I'd melt it down, of course--every bit of it--and

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: then I'd turn it into coins--with just as much gold in them as

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: genuine ones, of course--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Of course!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Well, you can easily see why. For if I wanted to dabble in

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: counterfeits, then I need not go digging for gold first. [Pause]

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: It is a strange thing anyhow, that if anybody else did what I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: cannot make myself do, then I'd be willing to acquit him--but I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: couldn't possibly acquit myself. I might even make a brilliant

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: speech in defence of the thief, proving that this gold was _res

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: nullius_, or nobody's, as it had been deposited at a time when

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: property rights did not yet exist; that even under existing rights

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: it could belong only to the first finder of it, as the ground-owner

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: has never included it in the valuation of his property; and so on.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. And probably it would be much easier for you to do this if

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the--hm!--the thief had not been prompted by actual need, but by a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: mania for collecting, for instance--or by scientific aspirations--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: by the ambition to keep a discovery to himself. Don't you think

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: so?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. You mean that I could not acquit him if actual need had

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: been the motive? Yes, for that's the only motive which the law

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: will not accept in extenuation. That motive makes a plain theft of

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: it.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. And this you couldn't excuse?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Oh, excuse--no, I guess not, as the law wouldn't. On the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: other hand, I must admit that it would be hard for me to charge a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: collector with theft merely because he had appropriated some

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: specimen not yet represented in his own collection.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. So that vanity or ambition might excuse what could not be

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: excused by need?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. And yet need ought to be the more telling excuse--the only

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: one, in fact? But I feel as I have said. And I can no more change

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: this feeling than I can change my own determination not to steal

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: under any circumstances whatever.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. And I suppose you count it a great merit that you cannot--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: hm!--steal?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. No, my disinclination to steal is just as irresistible as

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the inclination to do so is irresistible with some people. So it

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: cannot be called a merit. I cannot do it, and the other one cannot

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: refrain!--But you understand, of course, that I am not without a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: desire to own this gold. Why don't I take it then? Because I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: cannot! It's an inability--and the lack of something cannot be

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: called a merit. There!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: on the landscape and darkened the room now and then. Now it grows

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: quite dark as when a thunderstorm is approaching.]

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. How close the air is! I guess the storm is coming all

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: right.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Are you afraid of thunder?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. It's just as well to be careful.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. You're a curious chap! Here you come dropping down like a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: bomb a fortnight ago, introducing yourself as a Swedish-American

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: who is collecting flies for a small museum--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Oh, never mind me now!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. That's what you always say when I grow tired of talking

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: about myself and want to turn my attention to you. Perhaps that

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: was the reason why I took to you as I did--because you let me

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: talk about myself? All at once we seemed like old friends. There

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: were no angles about you against which I could bump myself, no

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: pins that pricked. There was something soft about your whole

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: person, and you overflowed with that tact which only well-educated

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: people know how to show. You never made a noise when you came home

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: late at night or got up early in the morning. You were patient in

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: small things, and you gave in whenever a conflict seemed

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: threatening. In a word, you proved yourself the perfect companion!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: But you were entirely too compliant not to set me wondering about

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: you in the long run--and you are too timid, too easily frightened.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: It seems almost as if you were made up of two different

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: personalities. Why, as I sit here looking at your back in the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: mirror over there--it is as if I were looking at somebody else.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. No, you cannot get a glimpse of your own back, man!--In

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: front you appear like a fearless sort of fellow, one meeting his

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: fate with bared breast, but from behind--really, I don't want to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: be impolite, but--you look as if you were carrying a burden, or as

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: if you were crouching to escape a raised stick. And when I look at

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that red cross your suspenders make on your white shirt--well, it

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: looks to me like some kind of emblem, like a trade-mark on a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: packing-box--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. I feel as if I'd choke--if the storm doesn't break soon--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. It's coming--don't you worry!--And your neck! It looks as

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: if there ought to be another kind of face on top of it, a face

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: quite different in type from yours. And your ears come so close

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: together behind that sometimes I wonder what race you belong to.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that might have struck the sheriff's house!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Alarmed] The sheriff's!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Oh, it just looked that way. But I don't think we'll get

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: much of this storm. Sit down now and let us have a talk, as you

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: are going away to-morrow. One thing I find strange is that you,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: with whom I have become so intimate in this short time--that yon

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: are one of those whose image I cannot call up when I am away from

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: them. When you are not here, and I happen to think of you, I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: always get the vision of another acquaintance--one who does not

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: resemble you, but with whom you have certain traits in common.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Who is he?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. I don't want to name him, but--I used for several years to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: take my meals at a certain place, and there, at the side-table

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: where they kept the whiskey and the otter preliminaries, I met a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: little blond man, with blond, faded eyes. He had a wonderful

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: faculty for making his way through a crowd, without jostling

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: anybody or being jostled himself. And from his customary place

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: down by the door he seemed perfectly able to reach whatever he

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: wanted on a table that stood some six feet away from him. He

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: seemed always happy just to be in company. But when he met anybody

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: he knew, then the joy of it made him roar with laughter, and he

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: would hug and pat the other fellow as if he hadn't seen a human

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: face for years. When anybody stepped on his foot, he smiled as if

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: eager to apologise for being in the way. For two years I watched

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: him and amused myself by guessing at his occupation and character.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: But I never asked who he was; I didn't want to know, you see, for

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: then all the fun would have been spoiled at once. That man had

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: just your quality of being indefinite. At different times I made

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: him out to be a teacher who had never got his licence, a non-

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: commissioned officer, a druggist, a government clerk, a detective--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: and like you, he looked as if made out of two pieces, for the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: front of him never quite fitted the back. One day I happened to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: read in a newspaper about a big forgery committed by a well-known

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: government official. Then I learned that my indefinite gentleman

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: had been a partner of the forger's brother, and that his name was

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Strawman. Later on I learned that the aforesaid Strawman used to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: run a circulating library, but that he was now the police reporter

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: of a big daily. How in the world could I hope to establish a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: connection between the forgery, the police, and my little man's

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: peculiar manners? It was beyond me; and when I asked a friend

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: whether Strawman had ever been punished for something, my friend

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: couldn't answer either yes or no--he just didn't know! [Pause.]

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Well, had he ever been--punished?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. No, he had not. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. And that was the reason, you think, why the police had such

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: an attraction for him, and why he was so afraid of offending

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: people?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Exactly!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. And did you become acquainted with him afterward?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. No, I didn't want to. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Would you have been willing to make his acquaintance if he

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: had been--punished?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Perfectly!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Sit still! Why can't you sit still?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. How did you get your liberal view of human conditions? Are

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: you a Christian?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Oh, can't you see that I am not?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. The Christians require forgiveness. But I require

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: punishment in order that the balance, or whatever you may call it,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: be restored. And you, who have served a term, ought to know the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: difference.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Stands motionless and stares at MR. X., first with wild,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: hateful eyes, then with surprise and admiration] How--could--you--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: know--that?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Why, I could see it.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. How? How could you see it?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X, Oh, with a little practice. It is an art, like many others.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: But don't let us talk of it any more. [He looks at his watch,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: arranges a document on the table, dips a pen in the ink-well, and

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: hands it to MR. Y.] I must be thinking of my tangled affairs.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Won't you please witness my signature on this note here? I am

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: going to turn it in to the bank at Malmo tomorrow, when I go to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the city with you.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. I am not going by way of Malmo.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Oh, you are not?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. No.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. But that need not prevent you from witnessing my signature.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. N-no!--I never write my name on papers of that kind--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X.--any longer! This is the fifth time you have refused to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: write your own name. The first time nothing more serious was

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: involved than the receipt for a registered letter. Then I began to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: watch you. And since then I have noticed that you have a morbid

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: fear of a pen filled with ink. You have not written a single

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: letter since you came here--only a post-card, and that you wrote

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: with a blue pencil. You understand now that I have figured out the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: exact nature of your slip? Furthermore! This is something like the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: seventh time you have refused to come with me to Malmo, which

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: place you have not visited at all during all this time. And yet

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: you came the whole way from America merely to have a look at

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Malmo! And every morning you walk a couple of miles, up to the old

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: mill, just to get a glimpse of the roofs of Malmo in the distance.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: And when you stand over there at the right-hand window and look

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: out through the third pane from the bottom on the left side, yon

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: can see the spired turrets of the castle and the tall chimney of

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the county jail.--And now I hope you see that it's your own

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: stupidity rather than my cleverness which has made everything

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: clear to me.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. This means that you despise me?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Oh, no!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Yes, you do--you cannot but do it!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. No--here's my hand.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. [Drawing back his hand] Don't lick hands like a dog!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Pardon me, sir, but you are the first one who has let me

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: touch his hand after learning--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. And now you call me "sir!"--What scares me about you is

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that you don't feel exonerated, washed clean, raised to the old

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: level, as good as anybody else, when you have suffered your

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: punishment. Do you care to tell me how it happened? Would you?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Twisting uneasily] Yes, but you won't believe what I say.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: But I'll tell you. Then you can see for yourself that I am no

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: ORDINARY criminal. You'll become convinced, I think, that there

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: are errors which, so to speak, are involuntary--[twisting again]

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: which seem to commit themselves--spontaneously--without being

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: willed by oneself, and for which one cannot be held responsible--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: May I open the door a little now, since the storm seems to have

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: passed over?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Suit yourself.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Opens the door; then he sits down at the table and begins

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: to speak with exaggerated display of feeling, theatrical gestures,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: and a good deal of false emphasis] Yes, I'll tell you! I was a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: student in the university at Lund, and I needed to get a loan from

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: a bank. I had no pressing debts, and my father owned some

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: property--not a great deal, of course. However, I had sent the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: note to the second man of the two who were to act as security,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: and, contrary to expectations, it came back with a refusal. For a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: while I was completely stunned by the blow, for it was a very

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: unpleasant surprise--most unpleasant! The note was lying in front

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: of me on the table, and the letter lay beside it. At first my eyes

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: stared hopelessly at those lines that pronounced my doom--that is,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: not a death-doom, of course, for I could easily find other

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: securities, as many as I wanted--but as I have already said, it

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: was very annoying just the same. And as I was sitting there quite

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: unconscious of any evil intention, my eyes fastened upon the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: signature of the letter, which would have made my future secure if

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: it had only appeared in the right place. It was an unusually well-

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: written signature--and you know how sometimes one may absent-

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: mindedly scribble a sheet of paper full of meaningless words. I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: had a pen in my hand--[picks up a penholder from the table] like

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: this. And somehow it just began to run--I don't want to claim that

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: there was anything mystical--anything of a spiritualistic nature

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: back of it--for that kind of thing I don't believe in! It was a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: wholly unreasoned, mechanical process--my copying of that

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: beautiful autograph over and over again. When all the clean space

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: on the letter was used up, I had learned to reproduce the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: signature automatically--and then--[throwing away the penholder

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: with a violent gesture] then I forgot all about it. That night I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: slept long and heavily. And when I woke up, I could feel that I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: had been dreaming, but I couldn't recall the dream itself. At

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: times it was as if a door had been thrown ajar, and then I seemed

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: to see the writing-table with the note on it as in a distant

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: memory--and when I got out of bed, I was forced up to the table,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: just as if, after careful deliberation, I had formed an

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: irrevocable decision to sign the name to that fateful paper. All

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: thought of the consequences, of the risk involved, had disappeared—

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: no hesitation remained--it was almost as if I was fulfilling

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: some sacred duty--and so I wrote! [Leaps to his feet] What could

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: it be? Was it some kind of outside influence, a case of mental

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: suggestion, as they call it? But from whom could it come? I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: was sleeping alone in that room. Could it possibly be my primitive

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: self--the savage to whom the keeping of faith is an unknown thing--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: which pushed to the front while my consciousness was asleep--

SPEAKER: MR
