TEXT: together with the criminal will of that self, and its inability to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: calculate the results of an action? Tell me, what do you think of

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: it?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. [As if he had to force the words out of himself] Frankly

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: speaking, your story does not convince me--there are gaps in it,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: but these may depend on your failure to recall all the details--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: and I have read something about criminal suggestion--or I think I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: have, at least--hm! But all that is neither here nor there! You

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: have taken your medicine--and you have had the courage to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: acknowledge your fault. Now we won't talk of it any more.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Yes, yes, yes, we must talk of it--till I become sure of my

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: innocence.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Well, are you not?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. No, I am not!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. That's just what bothers me, I tell you. It's exactly what

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: is bothering me!--Don't you feel fairly sure that every human

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: being hides a skeleton in his closet? Have we not, all of us,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: stolen and lied as children? Undoubtedly! Well, now there are

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: persons who remain children all their lives, so that they cannot

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: control their unlawful desires. Then comes the opportunity, and

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: there you have your criminal.--But I cannot understand why you

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: don't feel innocent. If the child is not held responsible, why

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: should the criminal be regarded differently? It is the more

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: strange because--well, perhaps I may come to repent it later.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: suffered any qualms on account of it.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Very much interested] Have--you?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X, Yes, I, and none else! Perhaps you don't care to shake

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: hands with a murderer?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Pleasantly] Oh, what nonsense!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Yes, but I have not been punished,

SPEAKER: ME
TEXT: Y. [Growing more familiar and taking on a superior tone] So

SPEAKER: ME
TEXT: much the better for you!--How did you get out of it?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. There was nobody to accuse me, no suspicions, no witnesses.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: This is the way it happened. One Christmas I was invited to hunt

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: with a fellow-student a little way out of Upsala. He sent a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: besotted old coachman to meet me at the station, and this fellow

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: went to sleep on the box, drove the horses into a fence, and upset

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the whole _equipage_ in a ditch. I am not going to pretend that my

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: life was in danger. It was sheer impatience which made me hit him

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: across the neck with the edge of my hand--you know the way--just

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: to wake him up--and the result was that he never woke up at all,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: but collapsed then and there.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Craftily] And did you report it?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. No, and these were my reasons for not doing so. The man

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: left no family behind him, or anybody else to whom his life could

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: be of the slightest use. He had already outlived his allotted

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: period of vegetation, and his place might just as well be filled

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: by somebody more in need of it. On the other hand, my life was

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: necessary to the happiness of my parents and myself, and perhaps

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: also to the progress of my science. The outcome had once for all

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: cured me of any desire to wake up people in that manner, and I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: didn't care to spoil both my own life and that of my parents for

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the sake of an abstract principle of justice.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Oh, that's the way you measure the value of a human life?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. In the present case, yes.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. But the sense of guilt--that balance you were speaking of?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. I had no sense of guilt, as I had committed no crime. As a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: boy I had given and taken more than one blow of the same kind, and

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the fatal outcome in this particular case was simply caused by my

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: ignorance of the effect such a blow might have on an elderly

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: person.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Yes, but even the unintentional killing of a man is

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: punished with a two-year term at hard labour--which is exactly

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: what one gets for--writing names.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Oh, you may be sure I have thought of it. And more than one

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: night I have dreamt myself in prison. Tell me now--is it really as

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: bad as they say to find oneself behind bolt and bar?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. You bet it is!--First of all they disfigure you by cutting

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: off your hair, and if you don't look like a criminal before, you

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: are sure to do so afterward. And when you catch sight of yourself

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: in a mirror you feel quite sure that you are a regular bandit.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Isn't it a mask that is being torn off, perhaps? Which

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: wouldn't be a bad idea, I should say.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Yes, you can have your little jest about it!--And then they

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: cut down your food, so that every day and every hour you become

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: conscious of the border line between life and death. Every vital

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: function is more or less checked. You can feel yourself shrinking.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: And your soul, which was to be cured and improved, is instead put

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: on a starvation diet--pushed back a thousand years into outlived

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: ages. You are not permitted to read anything but what was written

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: for the savages who took part in the migration of the peoples. You

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: hear of nothing but what will never happen in heaven; and what

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: actually does happen on the earth is kept hidden from you. You are

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: torn out of your surroundings, reduced from your own class, put

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: beneath those who are really beneath yourself. Then you get a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: sense of living in the bronze age. You come to feel as if you were

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: dressed in skins, as if you were living in a cave and eating out

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: of a trough--ugh!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. But there is reason back of all that. One who acts as if he

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: belonged to the bronze age might surely be expected to don the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: proper costume.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Irately] Yes, you sneer! You who have behaved like a man

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: from the stone age--and who are permitted to live in the golden

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: age.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. [Sharply, watching him closely] What do you mean with that

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: last expression--the golden age?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [With a poorly suppressed snarl] Nothing at all.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Now you lie--because you are too much of a coward to say

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: all you think.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Am I a coward? You think so? But I was no coward when I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: dared to show myself around here, where I had had to suffer as I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: did.--But can you tell what makes one suffer most while in there?--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: It is that the others are not in there too!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. What others?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Those that go unpunished.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Are you thinking of me?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. I am.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. But I have committed no crime.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Oh, haven't you?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. No, a misfortune is no crime.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. So, it's a misfortune to commit murder?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. I have not committed murder.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Is it not murder to kill a person?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Not always. The law speaks of murder, manslaughter, killing

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: in self-defence--and it makes a distinction between intentional

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: and unintentional killing. However--now you really frighten me,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: for it's becoming plain to me that you belong to the most

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: dangerous of all human groups--that of the stupid.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. So you imagine that I am stupid? Well, listen--would you

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: like me to show you how clever I am?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Come on!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. I think you'll have to admit that there is both logic and

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: wisdom in the argument I'm now going to give you. You have

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: suffered a misfortune which might have brought you two years at

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: hard labor. You have completely escaped the disgrace of being

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: punished. And here you see before you a man--who has also suffered

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: a misfortune--the victim of an unconscious impulse--and who has

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: had to stand two years of hard labor for it. Only by some great

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: scientific achievement can this man wipe off the taint that has

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: become attached to him without any fault of his own--but in order

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: to arrive at some such achievement, he must have money--a lot of

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: money--and money this minute! Don't you think that the other one,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: the unpunished one, would bring a little better balance into these

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: unequal human conditions if he paid a penalty in the form of a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: fine? Don't you think so?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. [Calmly] Yes.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Then we understand each other.--Hm! [Pause] What do you

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: think would be reasonable?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Reasonable? The minimum fine in such a case is fixed by the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: law at fifty crowns. But this whole question is settled by the

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: fact that the dead man left no relatives.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Apparently you don't want to understand. Then I'll have to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: speak plainly: it is to me you must pay that fine.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. I have never heard that forgers have the right to collect

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: fines imposed for manslaughter. And, besides, there is no

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: prosecutor.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. There isn't? Well--how would I do?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Oh, _now_ we are getting the matter cleared up! How much do

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: you want for becoming my accomplice?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Six thousand crowns.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. That's too much. And where am I to get them?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. No, I don't want to do that. I don't want to become a

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: thief.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Oh, don't put on any airs now! Do you think I'll believe

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that you haven't helped yourself out of that box before?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. [As if speaking to himself] Think only, that I could let

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: myself be fooled so completely. But that's the way with these soft

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: natures. You like them, and then it's so easy to believe that they

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: like you. And that's the reason why I have always been on my guard

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: against people I take a liking to!--So you are firmly convinced

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that I have helped myself out of the box before?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Certainly! MR. X. And you are going to report me if you

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: don't get six thousand crowns?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Most decidedly! You can't get out of it, so there's no use

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: trying.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. You think I am going to give my father a thief for son, my

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: wife a thief for husband, my children a thief for father, my

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: fellow-workers a thief for colleague? No, that will never happen!--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Now I am going over to the sheriff to report the killing myself.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Jumps up and begins to pick up his things] Wait a moment!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. For what?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Stammering] Oh, I thought--as I am no longer needed--it

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: wouldn't be necessary for me to stay--and I might just as well

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: leave.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. No, you may not!--Sit down there at the table, where you

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: sat before, and we'll have another talk before you go.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Sits down after having put on a dark coat] What are you up

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: to now?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. [Looking into the mirror back of MR. Y.] Oh, now I have it!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Oh-h-h!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Alarmed] What kind of wonderful things are you discovering

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: now?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. I see in the mirror that you are a thief--a plain, ordinary

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: thief! A moment ago, while you had only the white shirt on, I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: could notice that there was something wrong about my book-shelf. I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: couldn't make out just what it was, for I had to listen to you and

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: watch you. But as my antipathy increased, my vision became more

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: acute. And now, with your black coat to furnish the needed color

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: contrast For the red back of the book, which before couldn't be

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: seen against the red of your suspenders--now I see that you have

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: been reading about forgeries in Bernheim's work on mental

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: suggestion--for you turned the book upside-down in putting it back.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: So even that story of yours was stolen! For tins reason I think

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: myself entitled to conclude that your crime must have been

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: prompted by need, or by mere love of pleasure.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. By need! If you only knew--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. If _you_ only knew the extent of the need I have had to face

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: and live through! But that's another story! Let's proceed with

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: your case. That you have been in prison--I take that for granted.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: But it happened in America, for it was American prison life you

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: described. Another thing may also be taken for granted, namely,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that you have not borne your punishment on this side.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. How can you imagine anything of the kind?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Wait until the sheriff gets here, and you'll learn all

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: about it.

SPEAKER: ME
TEXT: X. There you see! The first time I mentioned the sheriff, in

SPEAKER: ME
TEXT: connection with the storm, you wanted also to run away. And when a

SPEAKER: ME
TEXT: person has served out his time he doesn't care to visit an old

SPEAKER: ME
TEXT: mill every day just to look at a prison, or to stand by the

SPEAKER: ME
TEXT: window--in a word, you are at once punished and unpunished. And

SPEAKER: ME
TEXT: that's why it was so hard to make you out. [Pause.]

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Completely beaten] May I go now?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Now you can go.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Putting his things together] Are you angry at me?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Yes--would you prefer me to pity you?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Sulkily] Pity? Do you think you're any better than I?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Of course I do, as I AM better than you. I am wiser, and I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: am less of a menace to prevailing property rights.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. You think you are clever, but perhaps I am as clever as

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: you. For the moment you have me checked, but in the next move I

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: can mate you--all the same!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. [Looking hard at MR. Y.] So we have to have another bout!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: What kind of mischief are you up to now?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. That's my secret.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Just look at me--oh, you mean to write my wife an anonymous

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: letter giving away MY secret!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. Well, how are you going to prevent it? You don't dare to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: have me arrested. So you'll have to let me go. And when I am gone,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: I can do what I please.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. You devil! So you have found my vulnerable spot! Do you

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: want to make a real murderer out of me?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. That's more than you'll ever become--coward!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. There you see how different people are. You have a feeling

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that I cannot become guilty of the same kind of acts as you. And

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that gives you the upper hand. But suppose you forced me to treat

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: you as I treated that coachman?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. [Staring MR. X. straight in the face] You can't! It's too

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: much for one who couldn't save himself by means of the box over

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: there.

SPEAKER: ME
TEXT: X. So you don't think I have taken anything out of the box?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. You were too cowardly--just as you were too cowardly to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: tell your wife that she had married a murderer.

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. You are a different man from what I took you to be--if

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: stronger or weaker, I cannot tell--if more criminal or less,

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: that's none of my concern--but decidedly more stupid; that much is

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: quite plain. For stupid you were when you wrote another person's

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: name instead of begging--as I have had to do. Stupid you were when

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: you stole things out of my book--could you not guess that I might

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: have read my own books? Stupid you were when you thought yourself

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: cleverer than me, and when you thought that I could be lured into

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: becoming a thief. Stupid you were when you thought balance could

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: be restored by giving the world two thieves instead of one. But

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: most stupid of all you were when you thought I had failed to

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: provide a safe corner-stone for my happiness. Go ahead and write

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: my wife as many anonymous letters as you please about her husband

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: having killed a man--she knew that long before we were married!--

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Have you had enough now?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: Y. May I go?

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: X. Now you _have_ to go! And at once! I'll send your things

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: after you!--Get out of here!

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: End of the Project Gutenberg EBook of Plays by August Strindberg, Second

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: series, by August Strindberg

SPEAKER: MR
TEXT: *** END OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK 14347 ***
